item.title: Make it Personal: Inexpensive Handmade Valentine Cards
item.dc:creator: Ashley McCann
item.description: Crafts are fun! Holidays are fun! Giving is fun! So making Valentine cards for the class should be a blast, right? Right. item.content:encoded:
Crafts are fun! Holidays are fun! Giving is fun! So making Valentine cards for the class should be a blast, right? Right.

But sometimes, when you find yourself up late in a Pinterest-induced frenzy, covered in glitter and blaming your Kindergarten teacher for your inability to cut straight lines, the generic multi-pack of cards at the convenience store seems like sheer genius, worthy of a mom-awarded Nobel prize of sorts. (We’ve all been there, right? No? Just me?)

There’s nothing wrong with the multi-pack, but if you’re hoping to accomplish something mostly kid-created, homemade and cost effective, there are possibilities that don’t have to involve late nights and glitter.

The dollar store can be a mom’s best friend on a mission like this. Stock up on index cards, markers, a stapler and staples, glue, baggies and maybe some construction paper and stickers if you’re feeling really inspired. Ideally, you’d have some sort of craft box with all of these supplies neatly filed away somewhere for projects like this, so if you haven’t checked that off of the list yet, grab a bin and some extra supplies for stocking up. If you have young children, you have a lifetime of arts and crafts ahead and may as well be prepared.

Your next stop is the party supply section. This is a great spot to inexpensively buy items in bulk. Here are some ideas to use as inspiration:

Glow stick bracelets– Using scissors, make two small slits in an index card and thread the glow-in-the-dark bracelet through the holes. Print “You light up my life!” on the card and have your child sign their name and decorate.

Bouncy balls– Cut construction paper into quarters and write, “Hope you have a ball today!” on the bottom half of the paper along with your child’s signature. Fold the paper in half and staple it to the top of the bag with a ball in it.

Rulers or pencils–Yes, it’s practical and that’s often no fun, but the kids will get plenty of goodies and teachers will appreciate having the extra supplies around. Use tape, rubber cement, or cut slits into index cards to attach the treat and add a catchy phrase like, “You rule!” or “You’re just write!”

Fake mustaches– Ridiculous mustaches are all the rage lately and a great way to spread the silliness. Make up cards that say, “I mustache you a question? Will you be my valentine?” and affix a mustache to each, using double-sided tape or rubber cement. You may want to use a printer for this one because writing that out for an entire classroom of kids doesn’t sound like much fun.

Candy– If you’re set on sending something sweet, get extra creative by taking a photograph of your child reaching his or her closed fist toward the camera and then pick up the prints at your nearest convenience store. Make a small hole in the fist area of each photo and insert a lollipop to provide a three dimensional feel. Sure, it’s a little less kid-created and a little more involved than the other options but it’s also inexpensive fun. Feel free to take the easy route and give out a roll of Smarties candy with a card that says, “You’re such a Smartie!” or go organic and pick up honey straws from a nearby farmer’s market with a “Won’t you BEE mine?” card.

With some minor preparation and a plan, your family can enjoy a stress-free crafting session that can involve more love than labor this Valentine’s Day.

What other ideas do you have for unique Valentine’s cards and gifts on a budget? Share with us on Facebook and Twitter.

item.title: Unexpected Uses For Favorite Kitchen Gadgets
item.dc:creator: Sarah Caron
item.description: Do you really need that kitchen gadget? Some tools can only be used for a single purpose, and that can be a drain on cabinet and drawer space. But when gadgets can do double duty by performing tasks you may have never thought of, they become a great item to hang on to. Wondering if […]
item.content:encoded:
Do you really need that kitchen gadget? Some tools can only be used for a single purpose, and that can be a drain on cabinet and drawer space. But when gadgets can do double duty by performing tasks you may have never thought of, they become a great item to hang on to.

Wondering if your favorites have uses you haven’t thought of? Here are some unexpected ways to get more out of five common kitchen gadgets.

Whisks: Sure, you are used to using your handy whisks for whipping up fluffy eggs for omelets and sauces. But did you know that whisks are also super for quick and easy sifting of dry ingredients? Try using a whisk to sift together your flour, baking powder or soda and other ingredients when making breads, cookies, etc.

French Press: Don’t let that French press gather dust in the cabinet! Try adding warm milk to the press to create almost-instant milk foam for your at-home lattes (simply use the press to aerate the milk by raising and lowing it rapidly). Or add a little heavy cream, confectioners sugar and a dash of vanilla and use the press to make easy whipped cream. French presses can also be used to make loose tea (follow the same process as making coffee!).

Micro Handheld Graters: Sure, it might be meant for cheeses, but when you have a handheld grater with small grates, it becomes a fantastic multi-purpose tool. It can freshly grate your favorite hard cheeses for pastas, prepare fresh nutmeg (nutmeg is grated – and fresh is fabulous), fresh the zest from lemons, limes and oranges, grate ginger for recipes and even grate garlic for a quick garlic paste.

Muffin Tins: While these handy baking trays are great for whipping up muffins and cupcakes, there is so much more that you can use them for. For instance, did you know that hard cooked eggs can be made (super easily!) in a muffin tin in the oven? Just place the eggs in the muffin cups and bake at 350 degrees for 30 minutes.  You can also use muffin tins as a serving dish for special toppings for chili, salads and more. Just fill each cavity with a different topping (hint – muffin tins with six cavities work best for this).

Keurig Brewer: Your favorite morning brews aren’t the only thing that the Keurig can do for you. Skip the pod and use it to heat water for your favorite just-add-water dishes like instant oatmeal, instant noodles and more (hint: you can put bowls right under the spout for easy adding!).

What other uses have you found for common kitchen gadgets? Share with us on Facebook and Twitter.

item.title: 8 inexpensive activities the whole family can enjoy
item.dc:creator: Julie Bawden-Davis
item.description: Spending dedicated time as a family leads to precious memories and enjoyable traditions that last a lifetime. Though your budget may be stretched thin — especially during this post-holiday season — it’s still possible to enjoy fun, inexpensive activities together as a family, says Clare Levison, CPA, author of “Frugal Isn’t Cheap: Spend Less, Save […]
item.content:encoded:
Spending dedicated time as a family leads to precious memories and enjoyable traditions that last a lifetime. Though your budget may be stretched thin — especially during this post-holiday season — it’s still possible to enjoy fun, inexpensive activities together as a family, says Clare Levison, CPA, author of “Frugal Isn’t Cheap: Spend Less, Save More, and Live Better”.

“Quality time and wonderful memories don’t have to come with a big price tag,” says Levison, who has two children. “Enjoying inexpensive activities allows you to save money for things like a house down payment, college or retirement. And less strain on your budget means less stress for you and your family.”

The following inexpensive and free activities are sure to lead to family bonding experiences.

1. Get crafty
A wide variety of fun craft kits exist. Try a collaborative paint-by-number masterpiece with the whole family by assigning everyone their own numbers. Or use stamps to make holiday gift thank you cards for friends and family members. Clay creations are another fun activity. Mold masterpieces like colorful bowls and then dry them for future use. Make sure to have everyone put their names on the bottom of the bowls.

2. Play games
Have a puzzle contest to see who can complete their puzzle the fastest. Then take turns playing everyone’s favorite board games. Or create your own board game using poster board. Draw out the various stages of the game, raid the junk drawer for items that can be used as game pieces and print out paper money.

3. Write a winter poem
Put your creative thinking caps on and see where inspiration leads you. If the kids are old enough, let them each write their own verses. Even young children can help come up with rhymes. Write the poem in a notebook that the kids decorate, and continue the tradition for every season. You’ll end up with a best-selling family heirloom.

4. Read together
Visit your local library and pick out a book the whole family can enjoy. At home, make some hot chocolate and take turns reading out loud. This family bonding experience has the added bonus of giving young readers a chance to practice their reading skills.

5. Make homemade treats
Get out your favorite dessert cookbooks or look online for recipes to make yummy treats such as cookies, cupcakes or candy. Plenty of tempting confections you usually buy in the store can be made at home, such as toffee, rock candy, cotton candy and gummies. If you prefer salty snacks, homemade potato chips are always a hit.

6. Start an indoor garden from kitchen scraps
Growing houseplants from kitchen scraps is an enjoyable activity for the whole family. A surprising number of vegetable and fruit scraps transform into eye-catching plants, such as sweet potatoes, which create sprawling vines, avocados, which grow into small trees, and pineapples, which may even eventually grow fruit — even if planted indoors.

7. People watch
Go to the mall, get everyone a snack and make a game of watching shoppers. Once the passersby is out of ear shot, compare notes on what each of you think the person is buying at the mall, who he or she bought the items for and where he or she will go next. You’ll all most likely be wrong, but you’ll have a great time guessing.

8. Visit a national, state or local park
In addition to 365 federal parks, there are innumerable local and state destinations from which to choose. Pack a picnic lunch and head out to enjoy nature’s bounty. If it’s too cold to dine outdoors, eat your spread in the car as you make a game of trying to spot wildlife. Bring along binoculars. Don’t forget a camera to photograph the special moments sure to occur on your adventure.

item.title: Fitness goals can be achieved at home
item.dc:creator: Chie Davis
item.description: Are costly gym memberships standing between you and your Beyonce body? Don’t let tight financial times hold you back from accomplishing your 2014 fitness goals. Diversify your workout with home and outdoor solutions that will lead you to the promised land of sculpted gams! Before lacing up your running shoes, make a cohesive, goal-oriented schedule. […]
item.content:encoded:
Are costly gym memberships standing between you and your Beyonce body? Don’t let tight financial times hold you back from accomplishing your 2014 fitness goals. Diversify your workout with home and outdoor solutions that will lead you to the promised land of sculpted gams!

Before lacing up your running shoes, make a cohesive, goal-oriented schedule.

“Plan specific days to work each body part. Sit out your workout clothes on the nightstand,” advises Sia Cooper, creator of Diary of a Fit Mommy. The Florida-based exercise buff transformed her body — without a gym. Creative visualization also helped her.

“Set your (computer) background to someone … who’s fit level you would like to achieve. My background was fitness model Jamie Eason for the longest time!” she admits. Eason won the title of World’s Fittest Model and is a former NFL cheerleader.

Aside from falling prey to lurking temptation in the nearby kitchen, the biggest mistake people make with home workouts is the lack of preparation and “…not warming up,” says exercise physiologist Christi Hampton. The certified wellness program coordinator, who has worked in corporate fitness and private training in Washington D.C. and New York, stresses: “A dynamic warm up protects you from injury. Take 5-10 minutes to prepare the body for movement.”

Both agree that using household items is key. Say goodbye to the almighty Stairmaster, and jog up your staircase instead. Rely on sturdy kitchen chairs for tricep dips, one-legged lunges and step ups. They recommend filling up two empty one-gallon water jugs (weighing up to 9 pounds when full), to act as dumbbells. Low-cost accessories can also enhance your routine. Cooper’s favorites include a fitness ball ($11-Kmart), kettlebells ($40.99 Target) and
and a jump rope (Sears, $3.77).

For outdoor workouts, Hampton says medium-resistance tubing ($8.40 Wal-Mart) works wonders. Hampton suggests tying the band to a tree for 3 sets, 12 reps of standing row arm isolations.

Don’t discount short, consistent, high-intensity routines.

“Ten minutes of sprinting can burn more calories than 20 minutes of walking!” reveals the Fit Mommy. “Any movement strengthens your heart, skeletal system and builds muscle tone. If you only have 20 minutes, get cardiovascular exercise. (It) promotes blood flow and mobilizes fat stores,” adds the exercise physiologist.

Dynamic 30 minute-60 minute at-home routines:

  • Planks: “It works your abs, back, arms and chest. Lie face down on a mat, resting yourself up on your forearms. Push off the floor, raising up onto your toes, elbows resting on the floor. Keep your back flat in a straight line from head to heels. Hold for 30-60 seconds, (then) repeat,” Cooper says.

  • Squat-Stay: Add a twist to the classic squat by holding the seated air position for 30 seconds, once in proper form. Hampton suggests repeating 8 times.

  • Burpees: “Get into a squat..Kick your feet back into a push-up position while lowering your body to the floor. Return your feet back to the squat position. Jump! ” Cooper adds.

Outdoor circuit training can supplement cardio. “This is a set of any five exercises that you complete for 30 seconds-1 minute each before moving on to the next exercise. When you have completed each exercise once, that’s considered one circuit,” explains Cooper. Effective circuits, which should be completed at least twice up to five times, include walking lunges with knees ups, push-ups, crab walks and jumping jacks.

Both experts are active moms, making exercise a family affair. Cooper, who is eight months pregnant, blogs about her prenatal workouts. “Once my son is born, I plan on … using our jogging stroller at the local outdoor track.” She also plans on incorporating him into my exercises as a weight for (at home) squats.

If you haven’t been active lately, it is always smart to consult a doctor to cover any unanswered questions.

item.title: Budget-friendly makeup trends for 2014
item.dc:creator: Chie Davis
item.description: Step out looking fresh and renewed this year without spending a bundle. Expert artists have rounded up the latest makeup trends for 2014 — guaranteed to keep your pockets full, while making you feel unstoppable. The word this year? Focus. Professionals agree that maintaining a focal point on the face is key. Lips are taking […]
item.content:encoded:
Step out looking fresh and renewed this year without spending a bundle. Expert artists have rounded up the latest makeup trends for 2014 — guaranteed to keep your pockets full, while making you feel unstoppable.

The word this year? Focus. Professionals agree that maintaining a focal point on the face is key. Lips are taking center stage.

“A bold lip is always a great statement. It wakes the face up, dresses up a woman’s attire just with a swipe of a cool color. Whether it be deep red, bright orange (or) purple, a face will make a statement without going overboard,” says Joanna Rodriguez. The New York-based makeup artist, who has worked with industry giants ranging from Lady Gaga to Spike Lee, favors TOM FORD and Giorgio Armani Beauty for clients with limitless budgets. For price-savvy vixens, she recommends NYX Cosmetics, which offers lipsticks from $6-$20.

Pilar Freeman, another master artist, works with top couture fashion houses. This year, she predicts that bold lips will come with a twist.

“We’re looking at berry and bordeaux colors. It will be very similar to that of the ombre hairstyle, where it goes from darker to lighter. We’ll see a darker (tone) in the middle and lighter around the outer area.” To usher in your own ombre, she suggests gearing up with L’Oreal’s HIP (High Intensity Pigment). Sold for $3.99 online, the lip stains are also available at discount retailers.

Makeup tips by Pilar Freeman

Whether lips are bold in style or color, this season they will be applied wet. Liquid lipstick in bright tones is one of the top trends this year, says Amelia C. Her Las Vegas-based makeup company works with TV productions such as TLC’s “What Not to Wear”. 

To keep your lips hydrated and primed for this trend, Amelia goes classic.

“No beauty bag is complete without Aquaphor, for perfectly hydrated lips.”

The timeless trend of flawless, glowing skin will also dominate 2014. It’s all about “… wearing makeup to appear to have NO makeup on, creating a natural, groomed, healthy appearance,” Rodriguez explains. It “should start with prepping the skin by exfoliating and moisturizing. (Add) a tinted moisturizer and concealer to give the face an even, perfect canvas. (Have) groomed brows, mascara, liner applied to makeup lashes to appear fuller …(use) bronzer, peachy blush for a fresh glow. A neutral lip make(s) for a clean, fresh looking face,” she details.

To glow on a budget, Freeman spills the goods. “I would do the tinted moisturizer by Laura Mercier. It’s about $42 but will last 6-8 months; and her secret camouflage concealer. I’d a use the Maybelline Expertwear brow pencil ($5.59).” 

Both Freeman and Rodriguez choose L’Oreal’s Voluminous non-waterproof mascara as a bargain pick.  “It not only lengthens and thickens, but also gives you fuller lashes,” Freeman says.

Economical yet effective eyeliners include  Elf
and L’Oreal gel eyeliner. She suggests capping off the look with a Nars bronzer.

When shopping for stellar drugstore deals, experts suggest checking the ingredients, but also educating yourself.

“If you can grab and go, that’s fine. But if you’re on a budget and something’s $7.99, that’s still a pretty penny for some mascara that you’re not going to be happy with. (Read) beauty blogs to see what’s trending,” Freeman adds. Also, steer clear of animal-tested products, Amelia C. says.

“This old-fashioned and cruel practice is alive and well… . There’s too many amazing alternatives to participate in such a devastating act.”

item.title: White Sale secrets to getting your money’s worth
item.dc:creator: Naomi Mannino
item.description: Do you wait for the White Sales every January to stock up on bedding and bath items? In January 1878, department store pioneer John Wanamaker created the first ever White Sale when bed linens and towels were only white. Now, the January sale has grown to mean all things, “home.” But, when it comes to […]
item.content:encoded:
Do you wait for the White Sales every January to stock up on bedding and bath items? In January 1878, department store pioneer John Wanamaker created the first ever White Sale when bed linens and towels were only white. Now, the January sale has grown to mean all things, “home.” But, when it comes to bedding and bath items, watch out for deep discounts on cheap fabrics and construction and shop smart.

Because of the global economy, which affects textile prices and factory costs, a lot has changed in the bedding and bath departments, according to retail bed and bath buyers for today’s major department and discount stores.

Here’s what they say you need to know to shop smart at a White Sale this January:
Items in a set may have changed: In the past, a standard bedding set or “comforter set” included a fitted sheet, a flat sheet, a pillow sham (two for a king size set) and a bed skirt. Today’s comforter sets often lack the bed-skirt and sometimes even the sheets but cost the same as a full set. Check the items listed in the set on the back of the package to be sure you are buying what you need.

Microfiber is no substitute for real cotton: When cotton costs sky-rocketed a couple of years ago, many manufacturers switched to using a new fiber for sheets called pure spun microfiber. It’s a pretty name for a sheet made from 100 percent polyester and can be found on store shelves from Bed, Bath & Beyond to Wal-Mart. It is very soft to the touch and much cheaper than cotton, so when cotton prices stabilized, retailers kept their microfiber sheet assortments at the lower prices, while pure cotton sheets rose in price.

The problem with cheaper microfiber is two-fold. First, the soft fabric is very thin resulting in fraying and splitting easily where worn. Secondly, polyester is not a natural fiber and it retains heat and dirt, making for sweaty sleeping and easier staining.

If you want to avoid microfiber, check the fabric designation on the back of the package. You may also find microfiber and cotton blends, which can be useful for wrinkle-resistant sheets that are cheaper than 100 percent cotton. The only time a sheet is 100 percent cotton is when it says “100 percent cotton” and lists a thread count; thread counts don’t apply to microfiber.

The highest cotton thread counts don’t mean higher quality: Many look to the thread count of cotton bedding (how tightly woven it is) as an indicator of softness, quality and price. Cotton Percale sheets with a 180-250 thread count is the most basic high-quality weave and results in crisp, cool bed sheets. A cotton Sateen weave costs more, has a softer feel and sheen, but may wear down and pill faster. Bedding in 300 to 600 thread count cotton feels luxurious, sleeps cool, releases dirt and stains, washes well, lasts long and is priced comparatively. Thread counts beyond 600 have a tighter weave, which often results in a stiffer sheet that is not as soft to the touch as the 300 to 600 thread counts, yet has a much higher price.

Other, good-quality cotton choices for sheets, depending where you live and your personal sleep considerations, are soft, warm cotton jersey and cotton flannel.

As in a cashmere sweater, the longer cotton fibers denote a higher quality because it results in a tighter construction that feels softer and lasts longer than the shorter fibers, which release and pill easier. And, the more you wash them the softer they will get. Label designations of high quality “long-staple” cotton fibers include Pima, Supima and Egyptian cotton (check that it comes from Egypt).

If you’re looking for satin pillowcases, look for satin made from silk, not satin made from polyester, which will nick, pill and stain easier.

Beyond the bedroom

Towel sizes, loops may have shrunk: The standard “bath sheet” labeled towel size should be 35 inches by 60 inches, but bath sheets in stores today may be sized 30 inches by 54 inches and cost the same as the larger counterparts, while the true bath sheet may cost more.

Make sure towels are 100 percent combed cotton and heavier rather than lighter for the best absorbency. Inspect the loops because towels with less loops feel scratchier and absorb less, while towels with more loops feel thicker, plusher and absorb more water. If you can see the base of the towel through the loops, look for a denser weave instead.

Compare towels by size and feel first, then by price.

item.title: Cut heating costs with one small change
item.dc:creator: Naomi Mannino
item.description: The typical American family spends at least $2,000 a year on home utility bills, and heating accounts for the biggest portion of those utility bills at 45 percent, according to the latest figures from the Department of Energy. If you’ve ever conducted a home energy audit or read through the list of tips to reduce […]
item.content:encoded:
The typical American family spends at least $2,000 a year on home utility bills, and heating accounts for
the biggest portion of those utility bills at 45 percent, according to the latest figures from the Department of Energy.

If you’ve ever conducted a home energy audit or read through the list of tips to reduce your heating costs, you might be dismayed at the advice to replace windows or insulation in your home. While those ideas yield good returns on energy savings, they require a big outlay of money. If you’re looking for a simple, inexpensive way to quickly reduce your heating bills, consider replacing an old dial or simple digital thermostat with a new, programmable thermostat. If you have already updated your thermostat, make sure you are maximizing its use to cut your heating costs.

“Setting back your thermostat when you are not at home for long periods of time, such as while at work all day, is one of the biggest single savings opportunities for the smallest amount money or disruption,” says Brad Paine, director of energy management systems at Honeywell. “Every one degree you set it cooler for eight hours during the winter represents one percent in heating savings,” Paine advises.

During the winter, the Department of Energy recommends setting your thermostat to 68 degrees while you’re awake, and setting it several degrees lower during the hours you are sleeping or away from home. By turning your thermostat back 10 degrees to 15 degrees for eight hours, you can save 5 percent to 15 percent per year on just your heating bill, which could be a savings of up to $135 per year.

Programmable thermostats are available in a wide range of prices and are easy to install for do-it-yourself-ers, Professionals are not needed, although they can be used.

How to pick a programmable thermostat that suits your needs

  • Look for a 7 day programmable thermostat, or one with a 5 day/2 day option, called 5-2. This way you can program different temperature settings for the weekdays and the weekends.
  • Look for four program periods per day, so you can have the temperature change throughout the day and night, such as lowering it in the middle of the night and raising it up just before you wake up in the morning.
  • Look for one that is back-lit or well-lit, especially if you have vision concerns.
  • If you are away from home a lot, check in to the newest versions. Many options have a corresponding Apple or Android app so you can control the thermostat from any device or home computer.
  • If you’re away from home for extended periods or have a vacation home that may be empty for long periods of time, be sure you choose one with temperature swing alerts, so you can make temperature adjustments away from the home and be alerted to any possible system failures.

One example is the Honeywell Wi-Fi 7-Day Programmable Thermostat, which available at The Home Depot and Lowe’s and other home improvement stores and department stores for under $120. That’s mid-priced among the sea of available thermostat choices, which sell up to $349.

What makes this thermostat so smart is that it learns how your house reacts to weather and temperature, such as how long it takes a house to warm up and cool down, and adjusts itself accordingly. Other more expensive thermostats have touch screens, automatic weather displayed on-screen and can even send you maintenance alerts on your home’s heating and cooling system. If you have trouble with the small controls, consider a voice-activated thermostat so you can tell it exactly what you want it to do.

item.title: Reap rewards, pay off debt with credit cards
item.dc:creator: Julie Bawden-Davis
item.description: For those trying to save money and stay out of debt, the mantra is to steer clear of credit cards. Beverly Harzog disagrees. The credit card expert and author of Confessions of a Credit Junkie: Everything You Need to Know to Avoid the Mistakes I Made says that if they’re used responsibly, credit cards can […]
item.content:encoded:
For those trying to save money and stay out of debt, the mantra is to steer clear of credit cards. Beverly Harzog disagrees. The credit card expert and author of Confessions of a Credit Junkie: Everything You Need to Know to Avoid the Mistakes I Made says that if they’re used responsibly, credit cards can be a valuable financial tool.

“If you understand how credit cards work and you don’t carry a balance, you can use them to make a profit as well as to build an excellent credit history,” Harzog says. “I have an airline miles card, and I use my miles to travel for free or, at the very least, at a discounted price.”

Consider these secrets for using credit cards to pay off debts and get free merchandise and services and you’ll soon think of credit cards as your friends.

Change your credit attitude

Before you embark on your journey to reaping the benefits of credit cards, Harzog suggests shifting your views regarding credit.

“Most people aren’t aware that their credit score impacts so many areas of their lives,” she says. “An excellent credit score helps you save money on mortgage rates, health insurance, car insurance and more. So when people say they can live without credit, they’re missing a chance to use it as a tool to save money in many areas of their lives.”

Take advantage of rewards programs

Sign up for credit cards that offer rewards programs and then use the cards to pay for everyday expenses. Some cards issue free airline tickets after you spend a certain amount, while others provide points that allow you to get free merchandise and gift cards and earn cash back. Other cards give bonuses at the gas station and gift certificates for restaurants.

To your advantage, the credit card market is competitive. When you sign up for a new rewards card, for instance, you’ll often receive bonus points. A typical bonus for getting a new travel rewards credit card is at least 25,000 frequent flyer miles, which immediately gets you a free trip. Those cards that give points for gift cards and cash back often offer double the points for a specific period of time after you sign up.

Follow rewards program rules

To get the most out of a rewards program, make sure to read the fine print, Harzog says.

“I understand that the fine print is very boring, but if you read it you come to understand all of the benefits of your rewards program. Credit card rewards program research has shown that consumers end up wasting about one-third of their rewards, which is a shame. Be sure you track your rewards and use them, and make sure you understand the rules. Sometimes there are inactivity clauses where you lose your rewards if you don’t use the card for a specified amount of time. And if you make a late payment, you might forfeit your rewards.”

Use interest rates to your advantage

The best way to pay off existing credit card debt is to transfer your balance to a card that offers a zero percent introductory APR on balance transfers. If you do this, you’ll have a time period — generally from six to 12 months —in which to pay off the debt without paying any interest.

The break from paying interest can give you the extra leverage in interest savings that you need to get a bill paid off. For instance, if you’re currently paying $150 in interest every month on a credit card balance and switch it to a zero percent card for 12 months, you can throw an additional $1,800 at the debt over the next year.

It’s definitely important to spend carefully when it comes to credit, but if you make strategic moves, you can reap the benefits of hundreds and even thousands of dollars in free merchandise and services.

Champagne is at the top of everybody’s list for holiday parties, especially for New Year’s Eve. But few really […]
item.content:encoded:
If you’ve ever stood gape-eyed, baffled by the wine aisles at your local grocery or liquor store and asked yourself, “What’s difference between the $6 bottles, the $26 bottles and the $56 bottles?” here’s your answer.

Champagne is at the top of everybody’s list for holiday parties, especially for New Year’s Eve. But few really know what they are buying, according to Vinny D’Agostino, food and beverage director of The King and Prince Resort on St. Simons Island, Ga. “Champagne must originate in the specific method of production using only grapes from the Champagne region of France. You will see the exact area, such as Épernay, and vineyard noted (stamped) on the label and it may include a vintage date, too,” he explains. “All others from anyplace else in the world are actually not Champagne and are instead, sparkling wine.”

Why the price difference?

D’Agostino explains that those Champagnes with the area and vintage stamps on the bottle are the ones that fetch the highest prices, because the grapes are more concentrated to one vineyard and one year, and will taste the best, too.

One such Champagne is Moet & Chandon’s best-known Dom Perignon, which usually starts around $150 but often sells for more depending on the year it was bottled.

Some Champagne do not contain the vintage date and are blended from a mixture of grapes from different years, which sell for around $40-$60 and which are great beginner Champagnes, he says.

Any bottle of sparkling wine that doesn’t specify an area or vineyard means the grapes come from a mixture of places, resulting in the lower price.

“A recognizable brand name is not always an indication of quality. Big names have big marketing dollars. It’s more about where the grapes come from, so always read labels.”

Sweet versus dry

Here are some different types of champagne designations you may see on the labels and what they mean, according to the Champagne Bureau’s U.S. office of the French trade association that represents all the grape growers and houses of Champagne, France:

Brut: a very dry (not sweet) wine. If the letters “NV” (non-vintage) are next to it or you see no year designation, then it is usually a blend of wines from several years.

Rosé Champagne: A slightly pinkish color, usually due to the addition of locally produced red wine or macerated black grape skins to the champagne blend.

Special Cuvée: The word “Cuvée” means it is made from the finest, most complex wine. These can be vintage or non-vintage.

Demi-Sec Champagne: These wines will taste sweeter than a Brut because more sugar is added during the process.

Blanc de Blancs: This white Champagne is made exclusively from Chardonnay white grapes.

Blanc de Noirs: This white Champagne is made exclusively from Pinot Noir/Meunier black grapes.

When to splurge

D’Agostino stresses that a high-quality, expensive chapagne is also no indication of the quality and there are many times when a lower-priced sparkling wine will serve your purpose better.

“If you are serving or giving to a wine lover, expert or to people who will know the difference, buy the best you can afford. The Dom Perignon or any Moet & Chandon definitely makes a statement,” D’Agostino says.

For large, fun parties where quantity may be more important than quality, choose less expensive varieties of sparkling wines. Some examples are Korbel from California, Freixenet from Spain, Asti from the Piemonte region in Italy and Prosecco, which originated in the Italian village of Prosecco, but is now grown in a few other parts of Italy as well. All of these are great choices that won’t bust your party budget, at around $10 a bottle.

item.title: Be a better clearance shopper
item.dc:creator: Naomi Mannino
item.description: Retail sales are not as good as the stores hoped they’d be this holiday season. But that’s good news for all of us clearance shoppers because there are plenty of leftovers marked down after Christmas. U.S. retailers squeeked out a 2.3 percent sales gain on Thanksgiving and Black Friday, in line with ShopperTrak’s prediction for […]
item.content:encoded:
Retail sales are not as good as the stores hoped they’d be this holiday season. But that’s good news for all of us clearance shoppers because there are plenty of leftovers marked down after Christmas.

U.S. retailers squeeked out a 2.3 percent sales gain on Thanksgiving and Black Friday, in line with ShopperTrak’s prediction for the weakest holiday results since 2009. The newest data from ShopperTrak shows traffic for the week ending December 22 (the biggest shopping week of the holidays) decreased 21.2 percent compared to last year and in-store sales fell 3.1 percent from the same week in 2012.

So if you’re a smart clearance shopper, you’ll be on the lookout for discounts galore on these specific items right after Christmas:

Holiday decorations

If you noticed your holiday lights, wreaths, ornaments are wearing out (or not lighting up) or you are running low on ribbons and wrapping paper this year, the few days right after Christmas is the time to stock up on holiday necessities for next year.

Even if you are not in the spirit, do yourself a favor and head to the Walmart and Target holiday clearance aisles for holiday leftovers worth waiting in line for.

Dealnews.com, a website that tracks sales and discounts from the previous year, recently reported holiday decorations, both Home Depot and Lowe’s had particularly steep deals (up to 75 percent off) on everything holiday last year.

Fashion

All fall fashion footwear, accessories and apparel will be aggressively discounted as stores frantically mark down whatever’s left on the sales floor, stockrooms and warehouses to make room for new spring floor sets.

Watch for advertised clearance sales more than 50 percent off for the best deals. Dealnews.com reports that Saks Fifth Avenue and 6pm.com both offer the biggest percent-off sales of the entire year after Christmas along with no-minimum free shipping.

Wine and champagne

Wine, beer and champagne makers are all vying for your holiday party dollars so take advantage of these discounts up until New Year’s Day.

Look for wine and sparkling wine BOGO (buy-one-get-one free) or 2-fers (2 for a specified price) and pair it with manufacturer coupons whenever possible. Buy as many as the deal allows and stock up if it’s a brand you like and want to use.

Maximize savings on clearance prices

  • Always wait to pair up clearance shopping with an in-store or online coupon whenever possible.
  • Check the store’s Twitter or Facebook page and sign up for the email, text message or snail mail savings program for every retailer you shop regularly so you have lots of different types of discounts and coupons to stack on top of the clearance prices.
  • Check coupon and discount aggregator sites for on-the-spot coupon codes and even printable store coupons such as Dealnews.com, Retailmenot, Couponsherpa.com and Pushpenny.com.
  • Never go without free shipping when shopping online: Check www.freeshipping.org for a coupon code and check the store’s minimum spending to get it.
  • Always price-check bigger-ticket items on your smartphone or tablet using a scanner app such as Redlaser when in a store, and even when shopping online. Retailers want to attract mobile shoppers and now show different prices on different devices and often for different locations.

    • It takes a little planning and perseverance to shop this way. But why not save 50 percent or more whenever you possibly can?

item.title: Throw a cheap and fabulous New Year’s Eve party
item.dc:creator: Julie Bawden-Davis
item.description: Welcoming the New Year with friends, family members and good food and drinks is a time-honored tradition. If you’re planning on welcoming in 2014 with a bang but are worried about the cost of throwing your own can’t-miss shindig, consider these tips for an inexpensive New Year’s Eve party. Send personalized evite Save money and […]
item.content:encoded:
Welcoming the New Year with friends, family members and good food and drinks is a time-honored tradition. If you’re planning on welcoming in 2014 with a bang but are worried about the cost of throwing your own can’t-miss shindig, consider these tips for an inexpensive New Year’s Eve party.

Send personalized evite

Save money and time by sending your guests email invites, says Natasha Shahani, learning experiences manager at the Aurelian Marketing Group in Las Vegas. “I’m a fan of Paperless Post, because it offers a more personalized evite than some services,” she says. “They have free options to choose from, or you can purchase coins for a really low cost to send more elaborate evites.”

Be creative with entertainment

Unless you have a friend or relative who plays in a band or is a professional DJ, chances are live entertainment is out of your price range. “Check out playlists on Spotify, Pandora or 8tracks, or have your guests create their own playlists to share and rotate,” Shahani suggests.

The secret is to play music that everyone enjoys and to keep things lively.

Provide your guests with plenty of fun memories and something to talk about by getting a little zany. Hold a belly dancing contest, play charades or invite guests to participate in a New Year’s resolutions guessing game. Make the countdown fun by videotaping everyone as they welcome in the New Year and then show the video at next year’s party during the countdown.

Edit decorations

A few well-placed decorations are all you need at your New Year’s Eve celebration. “Tea light or regular candles inexpensively add a beautiful touch and create an intimate atmosphere, and string lights work well for an outside party,” Shahani says. Fresh flowers also bring a decorative touch to the occasion. She suggests finding eye-catching floral selections from a local flower market and making your own arrangements.

Offer tasty finger foods

Serving bite-sized, eclectic foods is a fun and affordable way to keep your guests satisfied, says Jayme O’Neil, sales and catering coordinator for California Fresh Catering & Events. “Stay away from platters of pre-made fresh appetizers, as they tend to be expensive,” she says. “Instead, opt for items like well-priced cheeses that you cut into cubes and accompany with crackers and baguettes. If you want pre-made items, opt for frozen appetizers in bulk that you can heat up. Veggie trays with a side of hummus or salsa are also affordable and popular.”

When it comes to the amount of food to prepare and serve, O’Neil suggests this rule of thumb: “Provide four to six bites per person per hour,” she says. “If you have 25 guests, serve five different appetizers — two meats, one seafood, one veggie and one sweet.”

Use your own tableware

No need to spend money on plastic dishes for your celebration when you can choose the eco-friendly option of using your own dishes and utensils. “Use your own dishware for the festivities; it’s okay if things don’t match,” says O’Neil, who suggests getting creative and honoring the holiday by serving up food in martini, margarita and shot glasses.

Watch alcohol costs

Alcoholic drinks are one of the most expensive considerations for your New Year’s Eve get together. Save money by buying a case of sparkling cider or champagne, suggests O’Neil, who also advises serving up a signature drink rather than providing a full bar. Do some experimenting before the big event and come up with your very own cocktail to mark the occasion. Wait until a few minutes before midnight to break out the bubbly to welcome in the New Year.

item.title: Step into the new year on the right foot
item.dc:creator: Chie Davis
item.description: An awe-inspiring outfit, sparkly tiara and attention grabbing shoes are essential components in every party girl’s New Year’s Eve toolkit. Whether you’re planning to greet 2014 in dramatic hiking boots, thigh-high platforms or strappy heels, dynamic footwear can transform your look from drab to fab! “They are to my outfit what icing is to cake!” […]
item.content:encoded:
An awe-inspiring outfit, sparkly tiara and attention grabbing shoes are essential components in every party girl’s New Year’s Eve toolkit. Whether you’re planning to greet 2014 in dramatic hiking boots, thigh-high platforms or strappy heels, dynamic footwear can transform your look from drab to fab!

“They are to my outfit what icing is to cake!” says the self-confessed pump worshipper Tamika Sims. “A good shoe is something that is cute, perhaps comfortable and can be worn with various outfits. A dynamic shoe is a shoe that has an instant ‘wow factor.’ It makes a woman feel polished, classy-attractive and it enhances the impression of her overall look. Not all shoes can do this,” warns the creator of FastInTogether.com. Her practical yet savvy site highlights “fashion ideas for the chic lady on the go.”

As a wife and mother of two, who juggles blogging with a career in the medical field, Sims is a pro when it comes to quickly scoping out footwear deals.

“I love web shopping! The best thing to do is pick a couple of key shoes sites and sign up for their newsletters. My key sites are 6pm.com, NineWest.com and ShopStyle.com,” she says.

When it comes time to shine during the holidays, bargain hunters should have no fear slipping into designer shoes. Whether you’re hitting the town or toasting close to home, treat your pedicured paws to stylish hot-steppers for $100 or less.

“Sparkly pumps, pointy-toe suede booties and embellished cap-toe pumps,” are trending says the Washington D.C.-based fashion expert. “I love the pumps J.Crew  has out this season. Jeffery Campbell and Vince Camuto also (have) some fab picks … . Great stores to visit to get bargains on name-brand shoes are Nordstrom Rack and T.J. Maxx.”

Animal prints are still in, roaring into 2014 imprinted on ankle strap pumps (Chinese Laundry, $69.99) and chunky heels (Luichiny, $85.50)

From bow and feather embellishments to patent leather, runway designs reveal a return to feminine and classic styles in the New Year. Ignite your inner ballerina by capturing Persia bow heels for $98 by BCBGeneration.

Black Swan inspired Alberto Moretti show-stoppers retail for about $900. A more economical version can be found on DSW.com for $99.95.

Fashionistas will also honor a schoolgirl staple — the patent leather Mary Jane. The sassy 2014 interpretation (Steve Madden, $39.98) can easily transition from work to play. “I often have to balance out my desire to put on my “pow/in-your-face” pumps with what is work appropriate … . A patent leather pump in a classic and versatile color like black, nude or red, can go a long way. They are a bit more fun and snazzy than regular leather pumps and they look great with almost any work look,” Sims adds.

If you favor grunge over girly, rubber soles are the ticket. Step forward by flashing back to the 90s. Multicolored Doc Martens (Macy’s $99) have returned to the marketplace. Cap toe boots are another red-hot option, pairing well with liquid leather leggings or jumpers. While Rihanna favors Balmain’s Spring 2014 quilted leather cappies ($1,840), budget-minded babes can treat themselves to a similar style for only $37. 

Stomp into the New Year stylish and debt free, with these value finds.

item.title: Give parties that have a purpose
item.dc:creator: Sandra Gordon
item.description: It’s party season, but instead of throwing a traditional holiday soiree, “Why not start the New Year with giving back and host a party that can change the world?” says Kim Boerman, the author of “With Love: The New Generation of Party People” and the corresponding party-planning site, WithLoveParty.com. Boerman came up with the idea […]
item.content:encoded:
It’s party season, but instead of throwing a traditional holiday soiree, “Why not start the New Year with giving back and host a party that can change the world?” says Kim Boerman, the author of “With Love: The New Generation of Party People” and the corresponding party-planning site, WithLoveParty.com.

Boerman came up with the idea of charitable party giving after her mother-in-law, brother-in-law, sister-in-law and her son’s best friend all died within six months of each other, all from different causes. “I had had a successful residential real estate business, but after that, I was shell shocked. I really hadn’t dealt with a lot of death until then,” she says. Grief stricken, Boerman retreated to her back porch in Charleston, S.C., stopped working and began soul searching. She started reading a lot, too, and a fact she came across stuck with her — 53 percent of the world’s population lives on less than $2 per day.

Financially, Boerman wasn’t exactly flush either. “When I stopped working, things went downhill quickly,” she says, to the point that one day, she had just $10 in the bank and nothing much in her kitchen cupboards. But Boerman didn’t panic. “When I looked at my empty pantry, I thought, ‘It’s okay because my family will give with love,’ ” she says. That was her ah ha moment. “Right then, I knew that was it, that love and that we take care of each other were the most important things,” she says.

She soon embarked on writing her charitable party-planning book and developing her WithLoveParty website, which gives party givers everything they need to host 10 themed parties that benefit 10 non-profits, including: Water Missions International, The Pajama Program, Coalition to Abolish Slavery and Trafficking (CAST), National Foundation for Facial Reconstruction, UCP Wheels for Humanity, Southeastern Guide Dogs, Operation Homefront, Give Kids the World, Alex’s Lemonade Stand and Convoy of Hope.

“Each charity is four-star graded through Charity Navigator and has a public service announcement that goes along with it,” Boerman says. As the hostess, you can go online to WithLoveParty.com, choose a party theme and complete the Evite which will send an electronic invitation to your guests. The site includes party activities, menu ideas and even name tags for you and your guests that can be printed on Avery labels.

“The site is designed so that every detail for all 10 parties are planned for you so you don’t have to plan anything,” Boerman says. It even include menus ideas and a shopping list you can print and take with you to the supermarket.

Party hearty

Here are two examples of the themed give-back parties Boerman suggests that might be appropriate for a New Year’s gathering:

Sweet Dreams: This pajama party benefits Children in Crisis, a program that provides pajamas for children in need in New York City. After watching a short, five-minute PSA about the organization on your TV, your pajama-wearing guests pledge at least $20 from their cell phones. “No cash is exchanged at the parties,” Boerman says. Then you make pizzas and play charades or Pictionary.

Let’s Roll: This Bunko party benefits Wheels for Humanity. After the guests watch the Wheels for Humanity PSA and contribute via a mobile pledging, you and your guests play Bunko, which is easy enough for kids to master. The host provides prizes for the winners.

Boerman’s goal is to raise $5 million dollars for 10 non-profits in a year through parties that create soulful connections and heal millions of lives throughout the world with the click of a button. To accomplish that goal, she needs 2,500 people giving parties, each with 10 attendees who donate $20, which will yield $500,000 per organization. “That’s all I need,” she says.

Are you game? If so, Boerman is offering her book for just $10 with the coupon code MORELOVE. The book offers discounts on party vendors across the country who she recommends to help you pull off each themed party with pizzazz.

“Party planning is time consuming and stressful, but it doesn’t need to be that way. With my book and website, everything is preplanned and done for you,” Boerman says.

item.title: Repurpose your leftovers
item.dc:creator: Chie Davis
item.description: With presents revealed and your belly filled with all of the sumptuous fixings, Christmas is officially over! Before you start tallying up receipts or stressing out about your waistline, why not maximize your resources? A recent Gallup poll estimated that Americans will spend nearly $800 on Christmas gifts this year. Founder of the LiveWell Movement, […]
item.content:encoded:
With presents revealed and your belly filled with all of the sumptuous fixings, Christmas is officially over! Before you start tallying up receipts or stressing out about your waistline, why not maximize your resources?

A recent Gallup poll estimated that Americans will spend nearly $800 on Christmas gifts this year. Founder of the LiveWell Movement, Nwenna Kai, has the scoop on post-present appetizers that will allow your food to stretch, while easing some of that overindulgence guilt.

The former Los Angeles restaurateur, who also created a line of tasty and healthy entrees for Whole Foods Market, suggests that these quick fix recipes are best served uncooked.

“Raw is better, simply because it’s nutrient dense … when you cook food you destroy (most of) the nutrients and vitamins,” Kai says. With Christmas being one of the prime family feasting times, there is often “… an obsession with food having to taste a certain way — being fried, overcooked and highly seasoned, because there’s a mental, emotional and spiritual attachment to food, that has to transform!” she explains.

Here are a few of Nwenna Kai’s simple solution recipes that can easily be repurposed from holiday leftovers:

Leftover vegetables

Cream Kale Salad
Uses leftover kale, red pepper, carrots and tomatoes

1 avocado 
1 T curry powder 
1 T lemon juice 
1 handful of kale 
Sea salt to taste 
1 T olive oil  
1 handful of cherry tomatoes 
1/2 red pepper (chopped finely) 
1 carrot (shredded)

Place the avocado, curry and lemon juice in a food processor until creamy. Massage your kale with the salt and olive oil until it is broken down. Toss your kale with the curry mixture and add in the other veggies.

Stuffed Cucumber Sandwich
Uses leftover kale, avocado and cucumbers

1 hot house or Asian cucumber
1 handful of kale 
8-10 black olives (pitted) 
1 avocado 
1 tablespoon flax oil  
1-2 teaspoons of dulse flakes 

Core out the meat of the cucumber. Chop up the kale and olives into fine pieces. Mash the avocado into your kale and olives. Douse with flax oil and dulse flakes. Add more dulse flakes to fit your liking. Stuff the mixture inside of the cucumber. Enjoy like a sandwich!

Leftover spices

Persimmon Nog
2 cups almonds (soaked for one hour)
5 large pitted dates
3 cups water
3 persimmons, (peeled and seeds removed)
1/4 teaspoon nutmeg
1/4 teaspoon cinnamon
1 teaspoon ground ginger
1 teaspoon ground cardamom
1 vanilla bean
1 banana (to add to the thickness)

Use a Vitamix (or any other strong/professional grade) blender to mix the almonds, dates, and water until creamy and smooth. Strain the liquid through a cheesecloth or strainer. Pour the almond milk back into the blender. Add in the persimmons, nutmeg, cinnamon, ginger, cardamom, vanilla bean and banana.

Leftover nuts

Amazing Mac & Sweet Cashew Cheese
For the Cashew Cheese:
3 cups cashews, (soaked for two hours and drained)
1/4 cup nutritional yeast
2 cloves garlic
2 cups water
Sea salt to taste

4 cups coconut meat (sliced as noodles) or kelp noodles
1/2 cup of ground walnuts (optional; to act as bread crumbs)

Place all of the cashew cheese ingredients, except for the water, in a Vitamix (or any other strong/professional grade) blender. Mix well. Lift the plastic cap of the blender and slowly pour in the water until the texture becomes creamy and whiter in color. Add the cashew cheese to the noodles of your choice. Sprinkle the ground walnuts on top.

item.title: Make money from your old electronic devices
item.dc:creator: Sandra Gordon
item.description: Christmas Day is finally here. If you’ve just unwrapped a shiny new electronic device from Santa, don’t toss your old model into a desk drawer or a closet. Instead, cash it in as soon as you can. “There’s a huge market for used electronic devices domestically and overseas,” says Nik Raman, co-founder and COO of […]
item.content:encoded:
Christmas Day is finally here. If you’ve just unwrapped a shiny new electronic device from Santa, don’t toss your old model into a desk drawer or a closet. Instead, cash it in as soon as you can.

“There’s a huge market for used electronic devices domestically and overseas,” says Nik Raman, co-founder and COO of uSell.com, the only online “recommerce” marketplace for used gadgets. If you’re like 51 percent of consumers, you have up to five old-model gadgets, just sitting around, according to a recent uSell.com survey. “We recommend that consumers trade in immediately,” Raman says. “Newer models are going to get the highest price.”

USell.com doesn’t buy your device from you and give you cash. Instead, it connects sellers who want to get instant quotes on the value of their electronic device, with a diversity of businesses that specialize in purchasing mobile devices, such as insurance companies that supply customers who break their phone with a refurbished phone as a replacement. Your old phone could end up in a brick and mortar store or on Amazon. “Old devices end up all over the world and all over the country,” Raman says. In any event, uSell.com makes it easy to sell your device and move on. “We monitor the logistics and the transactions so that consumers get paid quickly and accurately,” Raman says.

Talkin’ Money

IPhones garner 40 percent of uSell.com’s business volume. “As a rule, the value of an iPhone depreciates 5 percent per month,” Raman says. Whatever model you have will be worth 55 percent of what it was a year ago. Right now, an iPhone 5 or an iPad 3, for example, will net $210 each on the resale market. Don’t worry if your device is damaged. It’s still worth something. An iPhone 5 with a cracked screen, for example, will get you about $120.

You can get something for older models too. An iPhone 4S is going for about $115 on the resale market right now and you’ll get about $40 for iPhone 4. Still, that’s better than nothing.

When you buy a new device, “get in the habit of getting some cash for your old device as soon as you load your data onto your new device,” Raman says. Besides Apple products, including iPods, there’s a decent resale market for Samsung products, such as the Galaxy Note series and the Galaxy S series, on Usell.com. “We also have a decent amount of volume for handheld gaming consoles, such as Nintento DSis and Sony Playstation PSPs,” Raman says. Older model Blackberry phones are still in demand, too.

When selling your used device, make sure you’re turning in the correct model. For example, “don’t send in an iPhone 4 and call it a 4S,” which is a mistake some consumers make, Raman says. The buyer will have to send you a revised offer. If you change your mind about selling before the deal is done or reject the offer you receive, “you always have the chance to get your device back,” Raman says.

To start the process, do your research on uSell.com to see how much your device is worth. Then, uSell.com sends sellers a kit. You’ll just drop your device in the kit and put it in the mailbox. After you send off your gadget and it’s inspected, uSell.com’s third-party vetted buyers will pay you within five business days, either by check or PayPal. uSell.com handles all communication between sellers and buyers. A buyer rating system on the site with online reviews can help you know who you’re dealing with.

“The benefit of working through us is that we can monitor the transaction, make sure it goes smoothly, and if you have any issues, you can reach out to our customer service department,” Raman says. “It’s a lot safer and less work and hassle than trying to sell your device yourself.”

item.title: Meaningful gifts offer more than just the present
item.dc:creator: Naomi Mannino
item.description: You can buy great fashion and great gifts and still have it “mean something.” There’s a new marketing term for this called Guilt-Free Consumption, dreamt up by the folks at TrendWatching.com who coined the phrase for marketers. Guilt-Free Consumption refers to consumers who want to shop, live and eat without worrying about negative impacts on […]
item.content:encoded:
You can buy great fashion and great gifts and still have it “mean something.” There’s a new marketing term for this called Guilt-Free Consumption, dreamt up by the folks at TrendWatching.com who coined the phrase for marketers. Guilt-Free Consumption refers to consumers who want to shop, live and eat without worrying about negative impacts on the world, such as poor working and humanitarian conditions, eating or wearing animal-based products, doing things that are unhealthy for our bodies, the sick, disabled and disadvantaged, environmental and waste concerns along with carbon footprint and just the overall vast commercialization of the holidays.

Here is a short list of some of the web’s most meaningful gift ideas from companies that pledge to make a difference:

For outdoorsmen 

If your main mantra is reduce, reuse, recycle, join Patagonia’s Common Threads Partnership. When you buy and give Patagonia, you’re getting high-quality gear made purposely to last a long time. If your gift needs repair, they will repair it. Patagonia will help find used Patagonia gear a new home and they will even take back worn out gear and recycle it to keep it out of landfills.

For indoorsman 

If the cause near and dear to your heart is children or cancer, consider that Dell purchases support Dell’s Children’s Cancer Care. The Texas-based company has committed millions of dollars and its tech skills to help children fight cancer. In addition, Dell’s zero-waste initiative reports that its global manufacturing and fulfillment facilities maintain a high recycle and reuse rate of about 98 percent of nonhazardous solid waste.

For the woman who has everything

With 24 ways and counting to style and wear The METAmorph Dress ($84-$100), it is the perfect fit for many body types and is created using a sustainable closed loop production process with a ultra soft, luxurious bamboo fabric. Besides funding production and supporting local and sustainable design, a portion of funds from the sale of each dress color corresponds with an organization that helps fund a more sustainable future:

  • Black: Free the children
  • Beige: Kiva
  • Grey: CharityWater
  • Raspberry: GiveDirectly
  • Teal: David Suzuki foundation

The Tory Burch Foundation sunglasses, bracelet or agenda are thoughtful ideas for super-stylish women ($95-$149). All proceeds from the purchase of these classic Tory Burch sunglasses, a double wrap studded bracelet or the leather-bound agenda go to support the economic empowerment of women and families through the Tory Burch Foundation.

Meaningful stocking stuffers under $25 

Want to feel better about buying kids a gift card to Mcdonald’s or Burger King (because they will love you for it)? Burger King recently launched Satisfries — French fries with 40 percent less fat and 30 percent fewer calories than the McDonald’s equivalent. And McDonald’s announced a global partnership with the Alliance for a Healthier Generation to make specific commitments, including always offering a choice of a side-salad, fruit or vegetables as a substitute for fries in a value meal.

All of the profits of Laura Mercier Shop for a Cause Lip Glacé in kiss of hope (peach) or rose hope (pink) limited-edition lip gloss ($24) will be donated to the Laura Mercier Ovarian Cancer Fund.

Vegan and made with fair trade and organic cocoa butter, ylang ylang and geranium, LUSH donates 100 percent of the price of the sale of each LUSH Charity Pot body lotion ($22.95) to support worthy causes: In five years, Charity Pot has funded donations to more than 350 worldwide animal welfare, humanitarian and environmental charities.

Through proceeds of the sale of each Philosophy Graceful Journey gift set which includes pure grace shampoo, bath and shower gel and seven inspirational cards ($25), Philosophy has partnered with Look Good Feel Better, which helps cancer patients deal with the appearance-related side effects of cancer treatment through in-person group workshops.

Online shops where everything you buy gives back

Given Goods is an online marketplace for home decor, kitchen, bath, handbags and accessories where products make a tangible social impact every time an item is purchased. Each product has a story and the website shows how the product gives back. Free shipping is available on orders that total more than $100.

Shop For Social partners with and curates products exclusively from local social enterprises and nonprofits, and includes handicrafts made by physically handicapped or disadvantaged individuals. Items start at $1.

You probably know that when you buy a pair of TOMS shoes, the company donates a pair of shoes. The same holds true for the new eyewear line, too, except instead of shoes it gives a pair of prescription glasses, a sight-saving surgery or a medical treatment via the Seva Foundation. This year, TOMS launched The Marketplace, which curates products from sustainable and socially conscious companies and you can shop by cause.

If you still have not completed your holiday shopping, you’ll have no choice but to go out to a local store. Whether you need something cute, crafty, kitschy, cutting edge or if you don’t know what you need, the best place to find it is at a large, multi-department off-price retailer such as Ross, T.J. Maxx and Marshalls. These brick-and-mortar shops contain a treasure trove of high-quality, brand-name (but also a lot of low-quality and cheap) gift ideas for any member of the family.

Every type of gift possible

These are mini department stores that have every type of gift, which is especially helpful when you don’t know what to get. Just wander among the departments to find presents for everyone on your list: tech accessories, gift sets, toys, designer apparel and footwear, designer fragrances, watches, sunglasses, jewelry, designer handbags, slippers, pajamas, bathrobes, wall art, books, crafts, furniture, luggage, workout gear, underwear, skincare, personal care products and appliances, cookware, food, kitchenware, kitchen appliances, gadgets and more. The one-stop shopping options also sell gift wrap, ribbon and cards, which you may need if you’re that late on your holiday shopping.

Lots of brand names

Vicky Oliver, author of “The Millionaire’s Handbook,” says that in order to score finds at these stores you need to know your brands and you should also know the difference between high-quality and a low-quality items in apparel, footwear and fashion accessories.

“Sometimes, manufacturers create specific lines for sale for the off-price retailers and they are not true close-outs, meaning they are not random designer leftovers of high-quality items from department stores such as Neiman Marcus, Lord & Taylor, Bloomingdale’s and Nordstrom,” Oliver explains. “It may not be the same fabric, fit, finish or styling you might have found in the upscale department stores for two or three times the price, so you have to check out the item carefully.”

But if you do know your brands and what to expect from them, whether skincare, toys, shoes, athletic footwear, activewear or women’s or men’s apparel, you can scoop up some great brand-name and designer deals. Here are some of the lines you can find at the off-price retailer shops:

Apparel & Footwear

  • Coach
  • Ugg
  • Michael Kors
  • L.A.M.B.
  • Tahari
  • Jones New York

Accessories

  • Fossil
  • Micheal Kors
  • Calvin Klein
  • Betsey Johnson
  • Ralph Lauren

Athletics

  • Nike
  • Adidas
  • Asics
  • Under Armour
  • Columbia Sportswear
  • Patagonia
  • Merrell
  • Minnetonka

Skin and hair

  • Chi
  • Philosophy
  • Bliss

Toys

  • Melissa & Doug
  • Fisher Price
  • KidKraft
  • Madame Alexander dolls
  • Wonderworld

Kitchen

  • Cuisinart
  • KitchenAid
  • Keurig
  • Wusthof

Off-beat unique choices

If you like to give unique gifts that are not straight off the shelf from Macy’s, these off-price retailers are the stores to find items for grandma who loves metal chickens, an aunt who collects mirrored elephant figurines and a niece who can use an interesting jewelry box. Ross says on its website that it does not buy the same merchandise for all stores, so you can shop two Ross stores in the same town for a different selection. Also, between T.J. Maxx and Marshalls, their merchandise also differs regionally and they receive shipments many times per week.

Lower prices

Prices may often be lower for similar items compared to what is currently in Macy’s and Nordstrom. But when it comes to low prices, Oliver says watch out especially for no-name, private label outlet and off-price handbags, apparel and footwear, and to stick with the name brands if possible.

“Skip the cheap chic bargain basement finds because they are probably no bargain at all and will fray and fall apart faster than you can say ‘happy holidays.’” She says to read labels for fabrications, examine stitching and workmanship and double check sizes and items in a set to get the most for your money.

One problem with shopping at these stores: Don’t stray from your list, or you’ll find yourself overspending on items for yourself!

item.title: Turn back the clock with these vintage looks
item.dc:creator: Chie Davis
item.description: Whether you’re punching up your style for a holiday office party or a New Year’s night on the town, close this year out properly! Arrive looking like a lady of luxury on a dime. Vintage styling is the key to making your caviar dreams come true. Retro fashion is in vogue: skirts that flutter, shiney […]
item.content:encoded:
Whether you’re punching up your style for a holiday office party or a New Year’s night on the town, close this year out properly! Arrive looking like a lady of luxury on a dime. Vintage styling is the key to making your caviar dreams come true.

Retro fashion is in vogue: skirts that flutter, shiney pearls, elegant gloves, cocktail rings, bold prints and decadent hats. Before you rewind a few decades, make sure that it’s real. “… A close look at the fabric content and brand label, the construction, will ensure you are purchasing an authentic vintage item and not a more recent item that is simply vintage-inspired,” says Mary Kincaid. The founder of Zuburbia.com, an eco-conscious purveyor of period wear, suggests newbies should do their homework. “There are unscrupulous sellers who will sometimes switch tags or cut tags out entirely and claim that an item is vintage.” Confirm that you’re buying from a reputable distributor by sourcing VintageFashionGuild.org.

Once you’ve identified a viable shop to purchase your threads, stay true to the mission. Don’t fall victim to investing in designer vintage, which is often more expensive than modern name brands. Kincaid, who curates and posts “eBay Vintage Roundups,” an online tag sale of vintage finds, encourages shopping smart. How do you run with the affluent set without investing like one?

Tip 1: Don’t be a label snob

If you plan to splurge on one item, go for a timeless coat or Hermes scarf. But if you’re interested in a complete look, “… bypass the pricey and in-demand designer labels and seek out the often very well-made clothes by lesser-known designers and manufacturers,” Kincaid says.

Tip 2: Do NOT shop around

Making quick decisions when buying vintage is crucial. Most pieces are one of a kind — back stock is rare. “If you try to shop around, there’s a good chance the first piece will be gone when you return to purchase it. If you are shopping for a special day or big event, start early. Shopping for vintage isn’t going to be as easy as walking into a large department store and finding something at the last minute,” the personal shopper advises.

Tip 3: Widen your scope

Venture beyond your neighborhood boutique. Kincaid favors estate sales, local auctions, charity sales, Craigslist ads, websites, as well as eBay. “Don’t overlook your local Goodwill store,” she says. “Some of my all-time favorite vintage pieces came from there.”

Tip 4: Mix and match

Retro-themed TV shows such as Mad Men and Boardwalk Empire have boosted interest in vintage fashion. “Flapper styles of the 1920s and early 1930s have been very popular. With fashion today, though, pieces from all decades can be combined and styled with modern pieces to look current,” notes the expert. Vintage hair clips, opulent costume rings or jeweled brooches can add spunky accents to modern dresses and blazers. But beware of fully embracing your inner Jean Harlow. “Avoid wearing vintage from head-to-toe. The look is too costume …. If you’re wearing a modern cocktail dress, add unique flair with vintage jewelry, a vintage handbag or a knock-out pair of vintage heels. If you’re wearing a vintage suit or dress, then pair it with contemporary or trendy shoes, jewelry or other accessories,” she advises.

With all of the potential pairing, budget-friendly options are endless. Start with retro essentials that can carry you from an office soiree to the after-party. Beaded sweaters, satin camisoles, sleek cigarette pants, capes and pencil skirts can be found for under $150.

item.title: Exchange unwanted gift cards for cash
item.dc:creator: Sandra Gordon
item.description: For the 7th year in a row, gift cards are the most requested holiday gift, according to the National Retail Federation. Because gift cards allow you to choose your own present, it’s hard to go wrong. Still, what if you get a gift card for a merchant you rarely frequent? Or, what if you’d really […]
item.content:encoded:
For the 7th year in a row, gift cards are the most requested holiday gift, according to the National Retail Federation. Because gift cards allow you to choose your own present, it’s hard to go wrong. Still, what if you get a gift card for a merchant you rarely frequent? Or, what if you’d really rather have the cash to help pay down your Christmas debt?

There’s no time like the present to turn your plastic into cash through the secondary gift card market.

“Right after Christmas is a good time to sell your gift cards because reseller inventory is at an all-time low,” says Kendal Perez, a spokeswoman for www.giftcardgranny.com, an online exchange that lists bids from the top gift card companies to easily identify the best price.

GiftCardGranny represents gift card sellers with an inventory of about 50,000 discount gift cards. “At least we did three months ago,” Perez says. “Now, we’re down to half that because people have been buying gift cards like mad.”
The average return on a gift card is 75 percent of its value. But if you sell a gift card soon after Christmas, you’re likely to do even better than that, Perez says. After the holidays, resellers need to rebuild their inventory.

One website, GiftCardExchangeDay.com, is promoting Dec. 26 as a one-day event to provide instant bids on unwanted or unused gift cards from resellers.

By selling a gift card sooner rather than later, you’re also less likely to lose track of it. As a result of the Credit Card Accountability, Responsibility, and Disclosure Act, which was signed into law in May 2009, consumers can hold onto gift cards for 5 years before fees kick in that slowly erode a gift card’s value. But not using a gift card immediately increases the chances you’ll lose or misplace it. “Each year $1.8 billion in gift cards go unused,” Perez says. If you don’t plan on using a gift card, resell it as soon as possible so you can pocket the cash. Here’s how:

Check the balance: Once you decide to sell your card, verify the balance on the gift card first. You can sell both unused and partially used gift cards for cash, but companies need to know the true balance of the card to pay you for it. You can usually check the balance on the company’s website or by calling the customer service department listed on the back of the card.

Get the best offer. There are a dozen or so reputable gift card companies that will buy your card for cash. However, each will offer you a different amount for your card, so shop around to make sure you’re getting the best deal. “At GiftCardGranny.com, we don’t buy your card and give you cash,” Perez says. The portal allows you to easily comparison shop and vets gift card resellers so you know you’re dealing with reputable dealers.

Decide on payment. Most gift card companies offer you payment in the form of a check, but receiving funds via PayPal or an Amazon gift card may also be an option. If you trade your gift card for an Amazon gift card, you typically get 4.5 percent to 5 percent more than if you opt for cash, Perez says. Some cards are worth more in the resale market because they’re more in demand. Target and Wal-Mart gift cards will often net 90 percent of their value because consumers can buy basically anything at these retailers.

You may only get 50 percent to 60 percent of a gift card’s value if it’s for a regional restaurant or retailers that isn’t as popular. Still, it’s better than nothing, especially if the gift card is for a restaurant or retailer you don’t really like.

Don’t forget: Besides selling your gift cards, you can also buy discount gift cards through GiftCardGranny.com, too. “About 90 percent of the resellers we work with have a cash-back guarantee,” Perez says. That means that if you’re buying a gift card and it doesn’t have the balance that was advertised, you get your money back in full.

item.title: Holiday gift guide: For the guy in your life
item.dc:creator: Chie Davis
item.description: Scratching your head over what to buy your guy for the holidays? We’ve compiled a stress-free gift guide with the hottest items for the man of the house. Before you grab your Santa hat, here are a few tips from Brigitte Segura, creator and editor of Fashion Daily Mag-Boys Club: Stick to the basic categories: […]
item.content:encoded:
Scratching your head over what to buy your guy for the holidays? We’ve compiled a stress-free gift guide with the hottest items for the man of the house. Before you grab your Santa hat, here are a few tips from Brigitte Segura, creator and editor of Fashion Daily Mag-Boys Club:

  1. Stick to the basic categories: clothing, fragrances, grooming or gadgets. “Men are simple beings — no matter how picky they are.”
  2. Don’t entertain pieces that may be too fashion forward. “… Don’t try to give them a makeover, they won’t wear it,” Segura says. “Guys need to ease into a new category or color.”
  3. Take time to do some research. “Don’t buy gadgets without doing your homework. Guys like to ‘own’ that domain,” Segura suggests. Don’t invest in pants or shoes if you’re not privy to the brand’s fit.

With a fail-proof guideline in tow, we conducted a diverse sampling of men, ages 23-43 for the top items on their wish list, priced for $100 or less:

Technology

SONY has stepped up its game by creating the 4GB Walkman Sports Underwater MP3 Player ($79.99). “This would be great when I swim at the gym,” says Jose Tankersly, a welder from Philadelphia. The lightweight wireless gadget will allow your Michael Phelps to listen to his favorite tunes while diving down to 6 feet. He can download 900 songs onto the device, which can run for up to 8 hours.

Zensah Running Gloves ($29.99) are another tech-savvy treat.
