If you’ve ever had to put off sending a text or an email because it was too cold outside to use your smartphone, this gift is ideal. “It sucks to take off your gloves when you walk to school in order to make a call,” says student Geoffrey Spencer. These gloves are not only warm, but have built in traction, allowing your man to easily use his smartphone. They’re also stamped with reflectors for nighttime runners.

Clothes

Saying yes to a cozy cardigan and no to that reindeer knitted Christmas sweater is key. But “the most practical things remain: underwear, ties and socks….(they) can never get enough,” Segura explains. University of Louisville dental student Ira Hill agrees. He hopes that Santa delivers thermal underwear (Hanes, $6-$32) and basketball warm-up pants (Nike, $64.99). Since he is a man on the go, these items are basic necessities and are “a beautiful merger between form meeting function.” Silk boxers and wool socks (hopefully not paired together) are also top requests. Bonobos is a great resource for stylish, economical accessories.

Watches

“Every man should own a few nice watches. Jewelry is not necessary, but nice timepieces add a touch of class and sophistication,” says Ricardo Sears, a New Jersey-based ambulance technician. If you’re unable to shell out $300 for Galaxy’s Note 3 + Gear, one of the most sought after items trending for guys, hunt for sales on dependable brands such as Invicta. With pieces ranging from $52-100, designs range from classic to vintage to surf.

Grooming

Know your guy’s regimen when it comes to grooming. “If the guy uses shaving foam, he’s not going to use a fancy shave kit,” Segura says. The Andis T-Outliner Trimmer ($47.89) is popular in the barbering world. It is “… not too over the top … (and it) enhances sharpness,” explains Lewis Jones, a travel agent in Maryland. Jetsetters will appreciate The Art Of Shaving: The 4 Elements of the Perfect Shave ($25). The starter kit takes up little room in the luggage, allowing Mr. Wonderful to “prep, lather, shave, (and) moisturize, all in one complete bundle,” Segura adds.

item.title: Volunteering can be mentally, financially beneficial
item.dc:creator: Julie Bawden-Davis
item.description: In addition to making you and those you help feel good, volunteering to assist the less fortunate produces some unexpected benefits, including boosting your finances. Consider how donating your time and talents has a way of giving back to you. Tax breaks Many of the unreimbursed expenses you incur while volunteering can be written off […]
item.content:encoded:
In addition to making you and those you help feel good, volunteering to assist the less fortunate produces some unexpected benefits, including boosting your finances. Consider how donating your time and talents has a way of giving back to you.

Tax breaks

Many of the unreimbursed expenses you incur while volunteering can be written off on your taxes. Such expenses include travel costs that allow you to get to and from volunteer locations. Write off train, bus and plane fees, gas, tolls and parking. You can even deduct travel expenses to an out-of-town location, such as a convention, providing you attend for charitable, not personal, reasons. And if your charitable work requires a uniform, you can write off the cost of the outfit. For more tax tips, read Start preparing for tax season now

Learning/training opportunities

The skills you develop while volunteering may help you advance in your day job or give you necessary experience to climb the corporate ladder. Volunteering can provide a variety of marketable job skills, including fundraising, marketing, planning and leading. You’ll earn educational experience and valuable on-the-job training.

Career guidance

If you haven’t yet found the ideal job, volunteering can offer you the chance to try various roles within an organization. Experiencing different facets of a company will help you choose the ideal career path that leads to a job you love — and a good salary.

Networking

The contacts you gather when volunteering can lead to an impressive roster of individuals who are happy to help when you call seeking employment or business opportunities. If you would like to work in a particular field, volunteer at an organization that specializes in that industry so you gain access to the key players in that realm. Those relationships you develop during service can prove to be long-lasting and mutually beneficial.

Improved productivity

There is a direct link between the emotional well-being you experience helping others and your desire to tackle your own projects. “Our research shows that not only does giving to others lead to happiness for people all over the world — from Canada to Uganda to South Africa – but giving time has another unusual benefit: it actually makes you feel less stressed about your own time,” says Michael I. Norton, an associate professor of Business Administration at Harvard Business School and co-author of Happy Money: The Science of Smarter Spending. “In several studies, we have shown that when people volunteer and help others, the feelings of accomplishment that they experience (‘I really helped someone!’) make them feel that they are better able to get their own tasks done (‘I’m on a roll!’),” Norton says.

Help you stand out and get a job

Volunteer work on your resume helps you stand above the crowd and get noticed. Hiring managers tend to be impressed with a person’s dedication to help others and often consider this a sign that you’re a self-starter who will go the extra mile. Because many potential employers highly value non-profit experience, your commitment and generosity is likely to make you a strong contender for any job for which you apply.

Improves your health and well-being

Studies show that volunteering can lead to better health, which means that you will likely have fewer medical expenses. The physical and mental rewards associated with volunteering are many, including reduced stress, improved moods and emotions and strengthening of the immune system.

Opens you to receiving

Giving isn’t done in a vacuum. Once you reach out to help, you initiate a natural give-and-take process between you and the world that allows you to receive the many good things likely to come your way, including financial fitness.

item.title: Trending: Twitter another tool to save you money
item.dc:creator: Sandra Gordon
item.description: If you’ve ever “liked” a company on Facebook to get exclusive coupons and deals, you know that social media is a marketing frontier. Online deals represented $35 billion in the U.S. in the last quarter of 2013, says Bernard Perrine, CEO and co-founder of HipLogiq, a marketing software company based in Dallas that helps retailers […]
item.content:encoded:
If you’ve ever “liked” a company on Facebook to get exclusive coupons and deals, you know that social media is a marketing frontier. Online deals represented $35 billion in the U.S. in the last quarter of 2013, says Bernard Perrine, CEO and co-founder of HipLogiq, a marketing software company based in Dallas that helps retailers find customers on Twitter. In fact, Twitter is now getting in on the action by vying for your consumer dollars.

“Half of all Twitter users have already purchased a product or service because of Twitter,” Perrine says. “There are lots of coupons and deals on Twitter waiting to be snatched up.”

Twitter is a more public forum than Facebook, which makes it a marketer’s dream. It allows retailers the potential of reaching a much larger audience. “The community is more willing to participate in conversations that can spark offers and discounts, such as “Looking for a good place for dinner on Saturday night,” Perrine says.

Working through a software marketing firm such as HipLogiq, which uses a patented algorithm to target key words and filter conversations, retailers can maximize their efforts and start listening in real time to what potential customers are looking for and then tweet back directly with discounts or offers.

Tweeting tips

Although Perrine is in the business of coaching retailers on how to find customers on Twitter by mining their public profiles, he offers this advise for consumers on how to use Twitter to get in on deals and coupons.

Share your life events. Having a baby? Planning your next vacation? Getting your haircut? Heading to lunch? Put it out there on Twitter. You’re more likely to get offers from companies if you share your daily activities, especially if they’re related to travel and leisure (airlines, resorts, golf and tennis), health and beauty (spas, hair stylists, mani/pedis), restaurants or health and wellness, which are the industries generating the most deal “traffic.”

Ask your followers “Where to go for spring break?” as part of your 140 character message and you’re likely to get discounts on hotels and flights to Mexico. “The department of tourism in Mexico is one of our clients and they’re trying to incentivize people to come to Mexico,” Perrine says.

Include your geographic area in your tweets. If you’re visiting Dallas and you’re looking for a great coffee bar, mention your location so local retailers can find you. For example, you might tweet something like: “Anyone know where to great coffee in Plano?” You’ll probably get suggestions from your social media followers who are familiar with Plano. You’re also bound to get coupons from local coffee shops. “Retailers who are anticipating that sort of tweet will find you and respond with a personalized @reply Tweet,” Perrine says.

Spread the word. If you get a deal on Twitter, you might be asked to pass the offer onto your pals. By all means, do it. If you send three of your friends a coupon offer through Twitter for $1 off a cup of Dunkin’ Donuts coffee, for example, and they redeem it, you might get another perk as well, such as a free cup of coffee. Companies such as Hiplogiq are in the business of helping companies make their offers and deals viral.

Be specific. If you’re interested in getting a deal on a product that isn’t geographically bound, for example, hone your tweet to include the brands you’re looking for to narrow the focus of the responses you receive. Try this tweet if you are hunting for electronics for a Christmas present: “Deciding between an iPad and the Surface for my teenage son. Help!” Besides buying advice from your followers, you might also get a discount code for a tablet computer from a major retailer, such as Best Buy. “Retailers aren’t necessarily reserving some deals for Twitter users, but they are giving more targeted deals so you don’t have to hunt through a forest of offers on the Internet,” Perrine says.

item.title: How to spot low-quality cashmere
item.dc:creator: Naomi Mannino
item.description: Fast-fashion doesn’t apply to cashmere sweaters. “A high-quality cashmere sweater is meant to last a lifetime. It should get softer and more form-fitting with age and wear,” says Karl Spilhouse, president of the Cashmere and Camel Hair Manufacturer’s Institute. He says there are no bargains in cashmere because it a very expensive raw material. “There’s […]
item.content:encoded:
Fast-fashion doesn’t apply to cashmere sweaters. “A high-quality cashmere sweater is meant to last a lifetime. It should get softer and more form-fitting with age and wear,” says Karl Spilhouse, president of the Cashmere and Camel Hair Manufacturer’s Institute.

He says there are no bargains in cashmere because it a very expensive raw material.

“There’s only a finite amount in the world. It takes the hair of approximately four goats to make one sweater.” He explains that a majority of Cashmere goats are raised in China, specifically inner Mongolia in Northwest China. The climate is rough, cold and demanding. The fibers are combed individually to separate the fine fiber from coarse fiber and a lot of care is taken in the procedure.

If you have cashmere on your gift (or wish) list, you’ll want to avoid low-quality cashmere, which simply is not worth the money, Spilhouse says.

If you see sale prices or promotions on cashmere products, look for these tip-offs that the quality might not be as high as you’d like:

1. The fabric is very thin. A 1-ply yarn used in a sweater will yield a very light sweater that may not hold its shape, may release yarns easily and tear and pill as well as not be warm. Turn the sweater inside out and look for 2-ply yarn which means you’ll see two yarns wound around each other and then knitted. It’s twice as much material so it will stand up better over time (and be warmer).

2. It’s not 100 percent cashmere. According to the Wool Products Labeling Act and enforced by the Federal Trade Commission, there must be a statement of material percentages in the inner clothing label. Look for the 100 percent cashmere designation because low-priced or promotion-priced cashmere may have an ad or hang tag that says “cashmere,” but the inner label may actually read 95 percent cotton and 5 percent cashmere. Some common fabrics blended with cashmere are silk and cotton, both of which are less expensive than pure cashmere. Silk is a “harder” fiber, so silk-and-cashmere-blended garments do not feel quite as soft as 100 percent cashmere. When cashmere is blended with cotton, a lower-priced, cooler garment will provide some of the luxury and softness of cashmere, but not the longevity.

3. It “pills” easily. Gently rub the palm of your hand on the surface of the garment in the store to see if fibers start rolling into little balls, which is called pilling. If it does, cashmere may be made using shorter, lower-quality fibers and will result in unattractive pilling under arms (the hallmark of a cheap sweater).

4. It’s scratchy and dull. Good, quality cashmere fibers when knit tightly together create a subtle sheen and a luxurious feel you can only get from a high-quality cashmere product. Look for this sheen and feel whenever purchasing cashmere.

5. The fit is bulky and awkward. A hallmark of high-quality cashmere is when it conforms naturally to the body. If the sweater is too tight, sticks out in all the wrong places or the wrap does not drape beautifully, then it is not good, quality cashmere.

6.Loses its shape. Good cashmere is springy. Another quick in-store test is to stretch the garment body side to side and see if it snaps back into shape. If it does not, low-quality fibers or very loose tension when knitted may be the reason. Loosely knit, limp fabric are tip-offs to a cheaply made sweater.

7. A no-name retailer or manufacturer. Fashion brands and retailers who have a reputation for high-quality apparel and who are known for reliability and integrity in their business, offer the best cashmere at good prices. Always be wary of “bargains” with cashmere, especially from unknown brands or retailers.

How to care for high quality cashmere

Spilhouse says knit cashmere products are meant to be machine-washable and, over time, get softer and better-fitting when cleaned this way.

  • Machine-wash in cold water on a gentle cycle with gentle detergent.
  • Never wring or twist. Lay flat on a towel and press another towel over to remove excess moisture.
  • Dry lying flat.
  • Woven cashmere products, such as a jacket, need to be dry-cleaned. Always check the care label.
  • Never hang knit cashmere products by hanger. Instead, store flat. When not in use, fold flat and protect from moths in a sealed garment bag.
  • Never leave cashmere dirty because that will attract moths.

item.title: Holiday gift guide: Stocking stuffers
item.dc:creator: Chie Davis
item.description: While the legend of Christmas includes Santa placing presents under a dazzling tree, those that believe are also known to receive pocket-sized pleasures in their stockings. Some view stocking stuffing as a light appetizer, but most have no problem filling theirs to capacity. What is the proper protocol when it comes to budgeting? “It really […]
item.content:encoded:
While the legend of Christmas includes Santa placing presents under a dazzling tree, those that believe are also known to receive pocket-sized pleasures in their stockings. Some view stocking stuffing as a light appetizer, but most have no problem filling theirs to capacity.

What is the proper protocol when it comes to budgeting? “It really irks me when I see $50 or $100 items advertised as ‘stocking stuffers.’ Perhaps put one or two higher priced items in, but that’s it. Even then I would say $25 should be the limit,” advises Liz Mills, owner of TheStockingStufferStore.com.

The holiday trinket connoisseur says that the key to purchasing stellar stuffers lies in bending the rules. “Essentials are great, but it’s also nice to have a few items where the recipient goes ‘cool’ because they haven’t seen it before,” she says. Step away from the drugstore and hunt for specialty boutiques or online hubs that specialize in the odd and unusual. Mills adds, “…that’s what makes a stocking so much fun, as I can go buy my own toothpaste and shampoo … . My husband is a sport motorcycle rider and enthusiast, and I found a magazine imported from the UK where that sport is huge. It’s more expensive than standard magazines, but it’s very niche — so well worth it. Specialty magazines make a great stocking stuffer because there are magazines on virtually everything and most people have a passion for something.”

If your loved one’s passion includes bubbly, allow him or her to sip fearlessly by gifting them with the all popular Wine Wipes ($8.99). It advertises that it will remove red wine stains from your teeth without interfering with the taste of your wine.

The adult fun doesn’t stop there. Another best-seller for Mills is the Pop-Up Wine Glass ($12.99). The verbiage describing the portable stemware explains, “… no more drinking wine from cheap paper cups, the Pop Up Wine Glass means you can always drink in style.” The company is based out of England, so it might be easiest to purchase this item off of Amazon.com.

In addition to catering to the gift recipient’s passions, identifying a theme helps consumers remain focused on a budget. Mills reveals that this year, shoppers are gravitating toward TV trivia from the 1970s, 80s and 90s ($9.99). Another popular gift this year is moustaches. The store’s Emergency Mustache Kit ($8.99) “contains 6 moustaches to instantly ‘become a man!’ Traditional Gent, Cowboy, Rusty Brush, Italian Plumber, Oil Baron and Abra-Kadabra!”

Another theme that often follows the season of indulgence is health and wellness. Lais Pontes, of The Pontes Group, says that her stocking stuffer of choice helps friends get over the post-holiday slump. If you’re pumping up for a work out, Energems ($2.99 per box) is a dietary supplement that resembles an M&M. Energems is promoting its product as the first energy drink to be made with real milk chocolate: “They are portable, let you control how much or little energy you need, taste decadent, cost $2.99 and are only 15 calories each!”

Those who prefer to bundle up, as opposed to working out, can stay classic without breaking the bank. Scoop up this trio of exquisite scarves from Closet Deep for the three little bears in your life. “It is an online destination created by sisters Kristine and Stephanie Navas. The site features an eclectic mix of both classic and edgy styles,” with clothes, accessories and home goods starting at just $6.99, Pontes says.

item.title: Don’t let holiday parties bruise your budget
item.dc:creator: Sandra Gordon
item.description: With all the presents to buy during the holiday season, it easy to forget about how costly meals and cocktail parties can be. Entertaining expenses can pile up faster than guests’ coats in a back bedroom. To keep your feasts and fetes budget-friendly, Dian Farmer, a grocery-shopping expert for Favado, a new, free app that […]
item.content:encoded:
With all the presents to buy during the holiday season, it easy to forget about how costly meals and cocktail parties can be. Entertaining expenses can pile up faster than guests’ coats in a back bedroom.

To keep your feasts and fetes budget-friendly, Dian Farmer, a grocery-shopping expert for Favado, a new, free app that can help you slash grocery costs, offers these tips for saving at the supermarket, especially during the holidays when you’ve only got so much in your wallet, but a lot on your plate.

1. Focus on the front page of the supermarket circular.
The front page features items with the deepest discounts that are only on sale for that week. These deals are designed to get you in the door, so pay attention. Don’t worry so much about flipping through the circular. “Some of the items in the middle, if you look closely, may be normal price,” Farmer says.

2. Wait for the right sale.
When something goes on sale, stock up on it. That’s common food-shopping advice. But Farmer has another take. “The best way to stock up is to know your rock-bottom sale price for items, wait for that sale, then use coupons on sale items and buy as much as you need of that item until the next sale,” Farmer says. Sales run in cycles. Many products go on sale every six to 12 weeks. PushPenny.com recently reported that retailers start advertising sales and deals during the holiday season for baking goods, so now is a good time to stock up on those items.

3. Keep a price book.

To spot a great sale versus a so-so one, and predict when the next great sale will be, keep a price book with a list of best prices for your favorite products, such as peanut butter, chicken, milk, bread and cereal. “Take a notebook with you when you’re shopping and jot down the prices of the items you like to buy each time you go to the store,” Farmer says. Within a span of 12 weeks, you’ll see that there will be a rock-bottom price for the products you’re tracking. “A price book is work in the beginning, but it pays off,” Farmer says. From her price book, Farmer created a price-tracking spreadsheet. Using this method, she spends less than $200 per month on groceries, for herself, her husband and one teenage son. Her goal is to never pay more than the rock-bottom price for an item.

“Wait for the rock-bottom price and keep your coupons until then,” Farmer says. Sometimes that can mean holding your coupons until just before they expire, to time them with the rock-bottom-price sale. Then, stock up. “Be picky. Try not to use coupons during so-so sales,” she says.

In lieu of or in conjunction with a price book, an app such as Favado can help you track coupons and sale items at stores in your area. All you have to do is select items you buy regularly from the app’s grocery list and the app will notify will notify you when they’re on sale.

4. Cash in at Wal-Mart.
Spending less than $200 per month on groceries is quite a feat. But Farmer has done even better than that. “I’ve saved over 100 percent on my grocery shopping trips,” she says. In other words, Farmer has actually pocketed money on some grocery expeditions. How? By shopping at Wal-Mart, which gives shoppers money back if the coupons they use exceed the price of a product.

Let’s say Wal-Mart has Tropicana orange juice on sale for $1.88, and you have a coupon for $2 off any Tropicana product. Unlike most supermarkets, Wal-Mart will give you the $.12 you’re due instead of just honoring the coupon to the price of the product, in this case $1.88).

There’s more. Wal-Mart doesn’t double or triple coupons, but it does have a generous ad-matching policy. If an item is on sale at your local supermarket for less than what it’s selling for at Wal-Mart, Wal-Mart will give you the local supermarket’s sale price. “You don’t even have to carry your supermarket circular with you to prove it,” Farmer says. In her neck of the woods, for example, local Hispanic markets will often sell 15 oranges for $1.
“At the register at Wal-Mart, I just tell the cashier before she scans my oranges that I can get 15 oranges for $1 and she gives me that price,” Farmer says. However, all Wal-Marts might not operate the same way, so it is better to be safe than sorry.

item.title: Creative ways to teach your kids to give back
item.dc:creator: Sandra Gordon
item.description: This time of year, with all the TV ads your kids are probably seeing for toys and electronics, it’s easy to get a big case of the gimmes. But with all the focus on stuff and gift lists, it’s also easy to turn the conversation around, from “What do you want for Christmas?” to “How […]
item.content:encoded:
This time of year, with all the TV ads your kids are probably seeing for toys and electronics, it’s easy to get a big case of the gimmes. But with all the focus on stuff and gift lists, it’s also easy to turn the conversation around, from “What do you want for Christmas?” to “How can we help others who are less fortunate?”

“The holidays offers a great opportunity to help children practice kindness and start developing the skills and abilities that help them show compassion for others,” says Rachel Robertson, the director of educational development at Bright Horizons Children’s Centers, which is headquartered in Watertown, Mass. Philanthropy may seem like a complex concept for some kids, but even preschoolers can grasp the idea because children are naturally empathetic. “Even as infants, they’ll cry sympathetically when they hear another baby who is upset,” Robertson says.

Teaching children to give back now can set the tone for their charitable future. Adult giving and volunteering are part of an ongoing pattern of behavior that starts early in life, according to the study Women Give 2013 by the United Nations Foundation and researchers at the Lilly Family School of Philanthropy at Indiana University in Indianapolis. The study, which followed the same 903 children over two time periods, 2002-2003 and 2007-2008, asked them each time whether they ever gave some of their money — if only a few pennies — to a church, synagogue or charity. It also asked the child’s primary caregiver, usually the child’s mom, whether he or she ever talked to the child about giving money to charity. The study found caregivers who talked to the children about giving significantly increased the likelihood the child would give to charity later, whether the parents actually did so themselves. The findings were consistent across all income levels and genders.

Having your child donate a portion of his or her allowance to a cause of his or her choice is one way kids can give back. But there other creative and unique ways you can teach your child how to help others with little or any cost. Here’s a sampling of family-friendly service project ideas fitting for this time of year — and beyond.

Send homemade get-well cards. With blank cards and envelopes and whatever decorating supplies you have on hand, such as markers, crayons, stamp pads and stickers, have your kids create personalized greeting cards and send “happy mail” to a child diagnosed with a life-threatening illness or suffering from serious injury through organizations such as Send Kids the World or Hugs and Hope. Be sure to include an uplifting message, such as “Thinking about you!” While your kids are busy decorating, talk to them about the meaning of the activity. Ask questions, such as: “Would you like to receive mail if you were sick?” “How would it make you feel?”

Volunteer in your community. “Find organizations in your area that work with people who don’t have a place to go for the holidays,” Robertson suggests. At her local Armed Services YMCA, for example, Robertson and her family of four girls ages 10 to 19, can sign up to sponsor a U.S. Marine to come over for Christmas dinner. Other organizations to approach include a local assisted living facility or Meals on Wheels. There’s nothing like a child to brighten the day of someone who can’t get out of the house or who doesn’t have much contact with the outside world. “Call these facilities and ask them what you and your kids might do for them,” says Robertson, who is also the co-author of Healthy Children, Healthy Lives.

Sponsor a micro loan. Through crowd-funding organizations, such as Kiva, which provide loans to small, family-owned businesses in developing countries that don’t have access to traditional banking systems, your child can lend as little as $25 to entrepreneurs in need of cash. The donation could allow a farmer add a cow to his small herd or help a home cook start a food-delivery business. Kiva helps drive home the concept that we’re all in this together. If 100 people contribute $25 to one person’s goal, that person in need can make some headway; 99.9 percent of Kiva loans are repaid on time. Have your kids read through the bios and decide for themselves which idea appeals to them. When the loan is repaid, they can choose to loan the money to someone else.

These are just a few ways you can help your child get in the spirit of giving. You can also use the dinner table to drive home the concept daily. In addition to the basic round of questions, such as: “How was your day?” add: “How did you make someone’s day today?” Robertson says.

item.title: Holiday gift guide: Gifts with a purpose
item.dc:creator: Chie Davis
item.description: Let’s face it. Two weeks after the holidays, that designer sweater that you spent way too much money on has already been stuffed in the back of his closet. Think smarter this holiday season by purchasing gifts with purpose. These hot-ticket cause-based items are not only economical, but also stylish. (All items can be found […]
item.content:encoded:
Let’s face it. Two weeks after the holidays, that designer sweater that you spent way too much money on has already been stuffed in the back of his closet. Think smarter this holiday season by purchasing gifts with purpose. These hot-ticket cause-based items are not only economical, but also stylish.

(All items can be found online by clicking the name of the product)

Headbands of Hope

Two years ago, then 19-year-old Jessica Ekstrom was inspired by her work at the Make-a-Wish Foundation to make a difference.

“I was pulling my hair back in a ponytail and thought about the hundreds of girls I encountered that lose their hair to cancer. Being a young girl presents many struggles with self-esteem already, and losing their hair as a result of a life-threatening illness is traumatic,” she says.

She took action by creating Headbands of Hope. “For every headband purchased, one is given to a girl with cancer. $1 is donated to the St. Baldrick’s Foundation to fund life-saving childhood cancer research.” From shimmery beaded pieces to knockout headwraps, each band retails for less than $20. “Over 10,000 headbands have been donated to girls across the country and that same amount has been donated to St. Baldrick’s,” she adds.

Denik

Denik also helps children in need. It teams up with fine artists across the globe to design journals and sketchbooks that fund school construction.

“Currently the artwork is submitted through our website and reviewed by our art team. … We’re building a middle school in Mali, Africa. Mali is in desperate need of schools and increased education,” says CEO and founder of Denik Tyler Tolson.

Popping with color and bold themes, the journals are $12. $1 from each purchase is donated to building schools and 5 percent is paid to the designer. “As the user shares their own story on the pages of the notebook, they become part of something bigger. It stores memories, ideas, and passions,” he shares.

Buy Native

Kristen Dorsey Designs

Like Denik, the Buy Native Campaign launched in 2011, during the recession.

“I was thinking about ways that we, regular people, can help our current economic situation, says Jessica Metcalfe, who organized a consortium of Native American jewelers, crafters, home decor and clothing designers.

Kristen Dorsey Designs

“Individuals spend hundreds of dollars on gifts each holiday season, and if we put even a fraction of that money back into our local economies then we have the potential to see immediate positive impacts … our Native American artists, designers, and businesspeople are some of the most vastly underrepresented in the retail industry.”

Chickasaw jeweler Kristen Dorsey adds, “Native-owned businesses are a way for this unique knowledge and artistic traditions to be passed onto the next generation. The culture is preserved and allows for (small) business owners to make a viable living doing what they are passionate about.” Her designs are featured on the Beyond Buckskin website.

Changing the Present & Oxfam America

If you’re anti-gift wrapping, you can still be pro-cause by linking with hubs such as Oxfam America and Changing the Present. Both sites allow users to select gifts that directly impact change within a chosen region or field of interest.

Starting at $5 on ChangingThePresent.org, you can select from thousands of charities and non-profits to “… preserve an acre of the rain forest, fund an hour of cancer research, or provide shoes for girls in Africa so they can attend school,” says representative Robert Tolmach.

Oxfam America’s mission is to create long-lasting solutions to end global poverty, hunger and injustice. Its “Most Wanted” list of charitable gifts includes a goat (‘The Kid‘) and building tools (‘The Fixer‘),” all of which promote self-sustainability. Gifts start at $12.

item.title: Fact: Showrooming saves you money
item.dc:creator: Naomi Mannino
item.description: “Consumers today do not believe the price they see is the best price they can get,” says James Dion, president of retail consultant DionCo. We go into stores to see and feel products, try them out or try them on, speak to sales associates for information and then we go online, sometimes while still standing […]
item.content:encoded:
“Consumers today do not believe the price they see is the best price they can get,” says James Dion, president of retail consultant DionCo. We go into stores to see and feel products, try them out or try them on, speak to sales associates for information and then we go online, sometimes while still standing in the store, to buy the product at a cheaper price. Retailers call it showrooming – treating stores like showrooms. Consumers call it “getting the best possible price.”

According to the 2013 Holiday Retail Spending Survey from CFI Group, a retail analytics company, shoppers who plan to spend more than half their holiday gift budgets online, three quarters are confirmed “showroomers.” The survey found that men are the biggest showroomers of all. Nearly one-third of men say they showroom all or most of the time and 60 percent of men said they showroom electronics. Only 22 percent of women indicate they showroom all or most of the time.

The biggest reason for showrooming is the amount of money consumers can save. More than two-thirds of respondents said they expect to save between 25 percent and 50 percent going to the store first and then purchasing online. That’s a big chunk of change.

How retailers curb consumer showrooming

Retailers have tried to fight it. Earlier this year Vera Wang‘s bridal boutique in Shanghai was charging customers nearly $500 for a fitting fee (since repealed due to consumer outcry in the media). A health-food store in Brisbane, Australia, charges a $5 “just-looking” fee. Both fees were deducted from actual purchases.

Michael Paulsen, former vice president of Decide.com, a price-tracking tool recently purchased by eBay, says retailers purposely create store brands, product bundles, specific products, model numbers and SKU numbers and QR codes that are exclusive to the store so the codes cannot be scanned or price-checked. Consider Insignia and Dynex “house” brand electronics only sold at Best Buy. INC brand apparel is only available at Macy’s. Exclusive item bundles and gifts sets where products are not sold separately such as brand name fragrance gift sets containing odd product sizes or food and kitchen utensil item gift sets at Ross or T.J. Maxx or even a barbecue grill and utensil set or toy set created specifically for Costco. None of these can be price-checked.

Showroom to your advantage

Stores have recently found that trying to stop consumers from showrooming only hurts sales and are now embracing the practice. Best Buy is hoping to attract users with “Your Ultimate Holiday Showroom” holiday advertising campaign showcasing its online and in-store experiences. Store associates from Nordstrom to Coach and even JC Penney will be carrying iPads to help you find information, availability and even price-check their products. And most retailers will match the advertised price of a competitor.

A remarkable example of this happened at Nordstrom in November. Bloomingdale’s ran a 20 percent off Friends and Family sale. Nordstrom’s, not wanting to be out-showroomed by smartphone price-checking customers, matched prices on the same SKU numbers from the Bloomingdale’s sale and further advertised the discounts online and with in-store signage and special price tags.

At the urging of retail consultants, stores such as Bed, Bath & Beyond regularly price-check branded items against Amazon, Target and other nearby competitors to price items within a few dollars or even lower so customers won’t have a reason to leave the store and order online. The moral of the story: Just ask those iPad-wielding sales associates if they will price match for you, or give you a coupon or code to purchase the item in the store.

Focus on features

Don’t just rely on Amazon for the best prices, which isn’t always the cheapest depending on the day and product category. Instead, first try scanning the UPC bar code using a smartphone price-checking app such as RedLaser or PriceGrabber. If that fails a match, try searching within the app search bar and also in a general internet search engine for the exact model name and number. Another consideration is the desired features in anything you are shopping for, says Andrea Woroch, consumer savings expert for Kinoli Inc. Whether it is specific items in a bedding set or specific controls on an HDTV, you can search for similar products with the same features when faced with products that cannot be exactly matched and price-checked. Paulsen also suggests bringing along a list of other brands you would consider.

Just be careful when searching for cheaper prices online. “If you haven’t heard of the retailer, check for negative reviews and beware of counterfeitters for branded products such as UGG footwear, Coach handbags, Michael Kors watches and other designer brands, because scammers are out in droves during the holidays,” Woroch warns.

item.title: Google: Under-handed or helpful this holiday?
item.dc:creator: Naomi Mannino
item.description: In case you hadn’t noticed, Google has gotten a lot more personal on your smartphone this year. Not only does it barrage you with products you searched for and didn’t buy, but it also tells you about the weather and your transit time to someplace you recently searched, even if you aren’t headed there. Some […]
item.content:encoded:
In case you hadn’t noticed, Google has gotten a lot more personal on your smartphone this year. Not only does it barrage you with products you searched for and didn’t buy, but it also tells you about the weather and your transit time to someplace you recently searched, even if you aren’t headed there. Some people think this is an under-handed use of the search function on Google’s part and would rather it not track our every search and move.

But now, in a slightly more helpful twist, Google can search your email, calendar and transactions to keep track of your online purchases, plans, travels, holiday parties, events and dates. It can find what you ordered, when it shipped and when it will be delivered. It can tell you whether you will hit traffic in transit, find your flights and reservations and if your flight will arrive on time. You have this information at the tip of your fingers without having to dig or search for the information, which might go a long way to smoothing your holiday shopping and travels.

“Since Google already has access to this information, I see no new privacy concerns,” says George Hobica, founder of AirfareWatchdog.com. “It’s just a more convenient way of accessing information without having to type on those tiny smartphone keyboards.

You can also use these same techniques on your home computer or any mobile device, all without having to dig around for the information, which just might go a long way to smoothing your holiday shopping and travels.

It’s very personal

What you need to remember about this “personal” Google Search service is that it is actually searching your personal, private Google profile for the information: Gmail, Google Calendar and your Google+ account. If you don’t have order confirmations and travel plans confirmed via Gmail or you don’t use Google Calendar for your daily plans, Google won’t be able to find them for you.

If you want to be able to use Google to answer personal questions about your plans, purchases and daily life made offline, then send yourself a Gmail with the appropriate subject line or put it in your Google Calendar so Google can find it for you very quickly and easily. For example, if you went to the post office to mail a package and want to keep the tracking number handy, put it in your Google Calendar and it will become a searchable item you can retrieve with a click of the search button. Additionally, Google can help you find your personal photos, but only if they are uploaded to Google+ and tagged correctly. If your photos are saved to Dropbox or Facebook, Google won’t be able to retrieve them.

Can’t remember when you ordered that Furby for your niece? Don’t know off-hand what time you arrive in New York? If you want Google to find your personal information for you, just type or speak your request by tapping the Google search bar on your phone, and more often then not, Google will politely speak the response. Here’s how:

Today’s schedule

Ask Google “What are my plans for tomorrow?” to see and hear a summary of upcoming flights, hotels, restaurant reservations and events. This can be a very useful tool when you’re traveling. Also, you can ask for “My calendar today” to hear what you need to do or prepare for next as well as to see the rest of the day’s plans without having to open your whole calendar and every event separately.

Your purchases

Ask Google for “My purchases” and you’ll get the status of your current orders. It will list what you bought, when your items shipped and the delivery time. It will list all your purchases, which is especially helpful if you want to keep track of everything you ordered online for everyone on your holiday list.

Upcoming flights

You can tell Google “Show my flights,” or you can ask specifics such as, “Is my flight on time?” or, “What is my flight number?” or, “What time do I arrive in New York?” Google can’t, however, give you information about past flights.

Ask about hotel or dining reservations

Just ask Google to show, “My reservation” or, “My hotel” to see dates and times. If you need driving directions you can tap once more on the link to directions that appears next to each place on your list.

Remember: If you want Google to butt out of your life entirely, don’t use any of Google’s services, app or products.

item.title: Holidays can be a teaching moment for teens
item.dc:creator: Chie Davis
item.description: With the season of consumerism upon us, it’s the opportune time to teach your teens about money. Maryland-based investment firm, T. Rowe Price, believes in starting conversations early. “Although parents don’t have to reveal everything, openly discussing family finances will make it more likely that kids will learn and share financial lessons – and help […]
item.content:encoded:
With the season of consumerism upon us, it’s the opportune time to teach your teens about money.

Maryland-based investment firm, T. Rowe Price, believes in starting conversations early.

“Although parents don’t have to reveal everything, openly discussing family finances will make it more likely that kids will learn and share financial lessons – and help them understand that the topic of money is not taboo. Kids are already drawing conclusions – right or wrong – from what they observe. As a parent, you have the opportunity to help them put that all in context, to help them develop the skills of managing through difficult times,” says Stuart Ritter, a senior financial planner with T. Rowe Price.

It is important to start teaching them early, before your children start making poor financial decision. “As soon as your kids begin to notice that buying things is part of life,” Ritter explains. “They will catch on very quickly that paper bills and metal coins can be exchanged for things.”

Building their financial vocabulary is the first step to help youngsters understand transactions.

“When you are pushing them in the cart at the grocery store, tell them how much the bananas (cost) … . Explain to them that you have a $1 coupon off of two containers of the favorite oatmeal,” says Sorina Fant, a mother, former elementary school teacher and author of “Hailey Fantrugal, Chief Couponing Officer.”

Fant’s book was inspired by her upbringing. “My mother was the person that couponed in the family, but around the third grade my math grades began to decline. My mom passed the coupon torch to me. I was able to apply the concepts that I was having trouble with in class (fractions, percentages) to our weekly shopping trips. I hunted for the deals with the best value for my family,” she remembers. Her parents rewarded their “Chief Couponing Officer” with a percentage of the household cash she saved.

Another teaching moment is transforming budgeting tasks, such as couponing and comparison shopping, into positive experiences. As teens they’ll process details better. “… Parents need to explain the importance of setting long-term goals like saving for a car, college or even retirement,” Ritter urges. By the age of 15, teens should be ready to invest, he says. They should also understand the concept of inflation, credit, interest and balancing a checkbook.

“Begin a concrete 50-40-10 system,” advises Fant. If you save 50 percent, spend 40 percent and give 10 percent away, it teaches balance, moderation and security. Before your teens become adults, “encourage them to save at least 50 percent of their earnings in a college/’rainy day’ savings account.

When spending their 40 percent, parents should step back. “Give them restrictions that compliment how you are raising them, but do not tell them what they can or cannot buy. They need to have confidence in themselves to make sound decisions. If you don’t want them spending their money on a ton of candy, tell them that. But do not tell them that they cannot buy a racecar magazine because you want them to purchase a different type of magazine.”

Giving 10 percent to charitable organizations reinforces that “…philanthropy is a learned behavior,” she stresses. “They need to understand that the flow of money is circular. Put money out there, to help someone else, and positive things will come back to you.”

Being a financial role model during tight times isn’t about being perfect. Honesty prepares your mini me for the future. “Thousands of teens are … maintaining blogs with high traffic and selling items that they are making from their bedrooms. The future belongs to the person with the entrepreneurial mind,” Fant adds.

item.title: Stylish, celebrity-inspired maternity looks for less
item.dc:creator: Chie Davis
item.description: From singer Gwen Stefani to actresses Drew Barrymore and Kerry Washington, ‘baby bumps’ are the newest accessory in Hollywood. Just because you haven’t been knighted with a personal stylist doesn’t mean that you have to go bargain bin hunting when your belly expands. According to Abby Vorobeychik, founder of 9Bliss.com, which offers a daily guide […]
item.content:encoded:
From singer Gwen Stefani to actresses Drew Barrymore and Kerry Washington, ‘baby bumps’ are the newest accessory in Hollywood.

Just because you haven’t been knighted with a personal stylist doesn’t mean that you have to go bargain bin hunting when your belly expands. According to Abby Vorobeychik, founder of 9Bliss.com, which offers a daily guide ‘to nine months of bliss,’ there are two major complaints of budget conscious mommy’s to be. “1. I feel guilty buying nice things that I’ll never wear again and 2. Maternity clothes never fit me right,” she says. To tackle those dilemmas, women should invest in multifunctional brands, such as Keungzai or Hatch, which can be worn during and after pregnancy. Vorobeychik also suggests hunting “for dresses and shirts with ruching, which will allow the clothes to grow and shrink with you.”

Maternity trends often mirror contemporary fashion, which translates into more bang for your buck. Hold tight to closet staples like blazers. “Try wearing an open blazer or coat from your pre-pregnancy days. It will instantly dress-up an inexpensive, casual maternity piece underneath it,” says the former Conde Nast corporate director. You can also stretch the love by stepping into the Ingrid & Isabel BellaBand ($19.99). It “lets you wear non-maternity pants as your belly grows, allowing you to get more use out of what’s already in your closet.”

After accessing your carry over items, elevate your look to superstar status, with daring add-ons. Leather and lace embellishments will transform you from frump to electric. “There’s something about putting on lace that makes you instantly feel pretty. It’s a great style to wear to the seasons’ parties, and it dresses up your work wear,” she explains. One of her favorites this season is a long sleeve scoop neck lace back shirt from BCBG.

Guilt will dissipate when splurging on multifunctional looks that have a sense of purpose.

“A lot of women will splurge on one or two things they need for specific occasions and then have little left to stock their every day wardrobe, resulting in a love-fest with their sweats,” Vorobeychik says. If your figure has done a 180 and you’re left with few carry over items, stay calm. After stocking up on basics, such as comfortable underwear and tanks, splurge on 2 key items — jeans and comfortable shoes.

“Your feet will grow during pregnancy, so having a pair of shoes that fit well may be the key to true happiness. If they look great, too, you’ll instantly feel put together when you throw them on.” With a great pair of jeans “… you’ll wear them so much that your CPW (cost per wear) will be close to $0!” she adds.

While celebrities have go-to designers, some of them have created lines that mirror their personal styles for less. Jessica Simpson celebrated her body during her latest pregnancy with maxi dresses — a great everyday look that can be paired with leggings in the winter. Purchase similar designs from her Destination Maternity collection, starting at $59.

Kerry Washington favors tailored A-line dresses that gently conceal her bump.
Duplicate the same construction for $29.99 by shopping Liz Lange for Target. For funky striped tops and chunky sweaters that speak to Drew Barrymore and Gwen Stefani’s casual vibe, try Asos, Top Shop and Loft Maternity. Have knockout pieces delivered to your doorstep for under $100.

item.title: Healthy foods can cost you less in the long run
item.dc:creator: Sandra Gordon
item.description: Would you eat healthier if you were paid? Your employer may soon be banking on it by offering NutriSavings, an employee benefit program dedicated to promoting healthy eating and employee wellness. “NutriSavings incentivizes employees with money and education to eat healthier,” says Jacques Stern, the CEO of Edenred, a world leader in employee benefits based […]
item.content:encoded:
Would you eat healthier if you were paid?

Your employer may soon be banking on it by offering NutriSavings, an employee benefit program dedicated to promoting healthy eating and employee wellness.

“NutriSavings incentivizes employees with money and education to eat healthier,” says Jacques Stern, the CEO of Edenred, a world leader in employee benefits based in Malakoff, France, that developed the NutriSavings program.

Administered through a company’s human resources department, NutriSavings is a portal program that promotes eating a healthier diet by giving employees cash back every time they buy healthy food at one of the 25,000 participating retailers in the U.S., including farmer’s markets. NutriSavings scores items from 1 to 100, with one being the worst and 100 the best.

The scoring system’s algorithm, which was developed by nutritionists and registered dietitians, combines data from the nutrition facts panel and ingredients lists on food packages, dietary reference intakes, which are defined by the National Academy of Sciences Institute of Medicine, Food and Nutrition Board, and guidelines from the United States Department of Agriculture. Every item purchased is tracked and scored when you scan the product’s bar code or the item is scanned at a register. When you’re done shopping, you can consult your score online or by using NutriSavings’ smartphone app, which is customized per company. You’ll also receive detailed information about the nutritional quality of your purchases.

Employers that offer NutriSavings, which is a free benefit to employees, can decide how much money its employees get back per healthy item purchased. The value is estimated to be 20 percent cash back or up to $15 per month, for a total savings of $400 per year per participating employee. For further savings, NutriSavings participants will also be encouraged to save money through coupons and price reductions on high-scoring NutriSavings items offered at the point of sale.

NutriSavings launched in the U.S. in October when Harvard Pilgrim HealthCare in Boston became one of its first customers. The health plan will begin offering NutriSavings as a benefit to its 1.7 million employees beginning in January.

Jeremy Nobel, adjunct lecturer in the department of Health Policy and Management at the Harvard School of Public Health, will be conducting a research study with Harvard Pilgrim HealthCare to determine if NutriSavings can change the eating behavior of its employees. He says consumers can still overeat, so it isn’t a given that if consumers buy healthier food, they will be healthier.

Today, obesity is a bigger risk factor for chronic disease than smoking. “We overeat and we eat the wrong things,” Nobel says. Excess body fat burdens the cardiovascular system and can lead to everything from back pain to heart disease. Yet Nobel is hopeful.

“NutriSavings goes to the heart of how you change behavior. As a consumer, you have to have a sense of awareness, a vision of being healthier, and information at the point of decision making,” he says.

In 3 to 5 years, Jacques Stern estimates that 5 million U.S. workers will participate in NutriSavings. Companies invest in the program, which has an estimated cost to companies of $850 per employee per month, in hopes that it will save money in the long run. “It’s a big investment,” Stern says. The overall goal of NutriSavings is to reduce chronic disease and health care costs. When employees are healthier and reduce their health care costs, companies reduce their health care costs by paying less for health insurance. NutriSavings may help companies manage their payroll costs through reduced absenteeism too.

Research shows that the idea of paying employees to change behavior could be good for business. A study in Preventing Chronic Disease involving 1,282 transit workers in Austin, Texas, for example, found that health care costs diminished and worker absenteeism decreased by 25 percent after the company, Capital Metro, began offering cash incentives to employees who joined weight-loss programs, used the on-site gym, lost weight, purchased healthy food in the cafeteria or met other criteria for participating in its employee wellness program.

item.title: Free shopping apps can save you time, money
item.dc:creator: Naomi Mannino
item.description: If you’ve been using free shopping apps on your smartphone to help you save money while shopping, then you already know they can help you price check items and search and receive additional coupons and discounts that can be deducted at the register. “If you haven’t been using smartphone apps then you have been paying […]
item.content:encoded:
If you’ve been using free shopping apps on your smartphone to help you save money while shopping, then you already know they can help you price check items and search and receive additional coupons and discounts that can be deducted at the register.

“If you haven’t been using smartphone apps then you have been paying retailers more than you have to,” says shopping expert Andrea Woroch. She says many existing shopping apps have upgraded their services to save you even more money than before.

Stephanie Nelson, founder of CouponMom.com, says she looks for new apps that allow you to pile even more savings on top of coupons and sales you have already used in store.

Here’s the list of this year’s must-have mobile shopping apps:

Ibotta: Gives cash back

You can earn cash by using this new iPhone and Android app, even if you are using a manufacturer coupon, a store coupon and the item is on sale. The app will ask you to read a quick fact and then answer a question about how you shop and/or watch a video about a product. Once you buy the product, scan the receipt and the product bar codes to earn cash. When you reach $5, money can be directed into your Paypal account.

Ibotta works best for grocery items. It has partnered with large national grocery chains, and is even working with stores such as 7-Eleven and Whole Foods Market. The offers are similar from store to store, so it’s really a matter of where you want to shop to redeem them.

Tip: Ibotta gives first-time users a nice cash bonus and is surprisingly easy and quick to use.

DealNews: Black Friday help

The Black Friday app from Dealnews.com for iPhones and Androids allows you to browse leaked and published advertisements from 60 major retailers. If you search for a particular item, it will reveal comparable deals online and offline, so you’ll always know if you’re getting the best deal on Black Friday.

Tip: Use the app to save specific deals to your list for future reference and search store ads quickly and easily instead of carrying around an armload of circulars from the newspaper on Black Friday.

Retailmenot: Additional store discounts

The new app for iPhone and Android allows you to simply show your coupon on your phone to a store clerk to redeem savings. If you’re about to go shopping at a specific store, you’ll want to quickly search for additional savings you can get while you are there; if you’re going to the mall, the app can also show you deals nearby.

Tip: Never check out without checking for an additional discounts from this app first.

RedLaser: Location-based price-checking

This one is a must for location-based shopping as both a price checker and a deal finder. Scan bar codes and QR codes to discover if a better price on a specific item is nearby or online. The app allows you to also purchase through the app. The latest update to the app includes in-store deals, store maps and store circulars.

Tip: Always scan the in-store price, especially for a large brand name or big-ticket purchase, to make sure you are getting the best price.

Hukkster, for best price alerts

Download Hukkster to your iPhone or iPad and start browsing. When you see an item you like, press the “Hukk button,” which saves the product to an alert list. Hukkster will alert you when the item goes on sale, which is great for gift-list shopping and big-ticket item purchases.

Tip: Saying “Hukk it” is fun. Getting stuff cheaper is really fun.

item.title: Appreciating family, friends, food on Thanksgiving
item.dc:creator: Naomi Mannino
item.description: “Appreciation is a wonderful thing: It makes what is excellent in others belong to us as well.” — Voltaire You probably have your own precious Thanksgiving Day traditions, but we wanted to share some stories that touched our hearts. Never forget the green Jell-O salad “Every year, about 20 of us would gather around my […]
item.content:encoded:
“Appreciation is a wonderful thing: It makes what is excellent in others belong to us as well.”
— Voltaire

You probably have your own precious Thanksgiving Day traditions, but we wanted to share some stories that touched our hearts.

Never forget the green Jell-O salad

“Every year, about 20 of us would gather around my grandparents’ kitchen table for Thanksgiving dinner. The table would be covered with food: turkey, stuffing, multiple bowls of mashed potatoes, corn, green bean casserole, sweet potato casserole, rolls, shrimp cocktail and more. Usually about half way through the meal with plates already loaded up, my grandmother — one of the most important women in my life — would realize she forgot about the green Jell-O salad in the fridge. Several people would have to get up from the table and move their chairs to open the fridge to get it out. She would insist we all eat some, even though we were already stuffed and didn’t really like Jell-O salad.

“My grandmother died five years ago. And you better believe, whether we like it or not, we always make sure there’s green Jell-O at Thanksgiving!”

—Tiffany Saunders, Ashland, Ohio

Black Friday shopping ninjas

“Even though my two sisters and I have moved away from our hometown in North Carolina, every single year the three of us travel home for Thanksgiving Day with mom and our yearly Black Friday shopping contest. We’ve been doing it all our lives and look forward to spending our time together after the meal with the Black Friday newspaper ads spread all over the place plotting our shopping strategy. We all always sleep at mom’s so no one will be late. The most fun is that once the shopping is done, we have a contest: Whomever saved the most money and got the best deal gets her big, after-shopping meal paid for by the rest of us!”

—Pat Stone Smith, Ponte Vedra Beach, Fla.

Turkey with a side of molé

“My grandmother is from Oxaca, Mexico, and she makes the best homemade molé I’ve ever had, and even serves it with holiday turkey. As a professional chef now, I’m sad to say I was so young when she died that she didn’t have a chance to pass on the recipe. She would serve it on Christmas Day turkey with tomato rice, fresh tortillas, cumin-spiked black beans and extra molé salsa, as it was so good and spicy. But the most important ingredient of this meal that brings me back to grandma and turkey is family and a large helping of love. (I think the real secret ingredient to my grandma’s molé might be lots of chicken fat, but I am still experimenting … and mine is still never as good as hers!)”

—David A. Cruz, executive chef/operator Simon Mansion & Supper Club|Hard Rock Hotel & Casino, Punta Cana, Dominican Republic

Appreciating friends, family out loud

Christine Carter, a sociologist and happiness expert at University of California Berkeley’s Greater Good Science Center, shared her own fantastic traditions on her Raising Happiness blog:

Friends: “Every year my friends travel to a small town in Northern California the weekend before Thanksgiving to celebrate together. The core members of this group have been gathering like this for more than 20 years! The highlight of the weekend comes during our Thanksgiving dinner when everyone gives a toast to the past year, and of course what they feel grateful for.

“My friends are a particularly appreciative bunch, and the go-around the table can often last an hour or more. The main focus, year after year, is on the others at the table. Husbands give tearful tributes to their wives; friends detail all the ways that people at the table supported them through surgeries, kid mishaps and job changes. Most people only hear toasts like these at their weddings — or they never hear them at all, as often we only celebrate people so publicly in memoriam, when the person being honored is no longer alive to revel in the love of their friends.

Family: “My young kids fold pieces of construction paper in half, and make them into humongous place cards, gluing leaves to the front and doing their best to spell everyone’s names inside. Then, when the turkey is still in the oven, each family member finds time to sneak away from football and silently saddle up to the dining room table. There they write on the inside of the place cards, noting what they are thankful for about each person named on the front of the card.

“At Thanksgiving dinner, we go around the table and read out loud one or two things that someone else has written about us. What I love about this is that there is both a private and a public component to our gratitude.”

item.title: Distractions can cost you money while shopping
item.dc:creator: Naomi Mannino
item.description: Cell phones, alcohol and footwear can have a significant influence on your pocketbook. What do they all have in common? “If you are distracted while shopping, it can have a serious negative impact on your shopping dollars,” says savings expert, Andrea Woroch. “Whether brought on by your own actions or influenced by the retailers, your […]
item.content:encoded:
Cell phones, alcohol and footwear can have a significant influence on your pocketbook. What do they all have in common?

“If you are distracted while shopping, it can have a serious negative impact on your shopping dollars,” says savings expert, Andrea Woroch. “Whether brought on by your own actions or influenced by the retailers, your mobile device and your shopping habits may be leading you to spend more,” she says.

There is research to prove that theory. Woroch says, “In order to save money and shop smart, you have to focus on the shopping at hand, and nothing else.”

Steer clear of store parties

A recent study in the Journal of Marketing Research confirmed that relaxed shoppers were willing to pay up to 15 percent more than less-relaxed shoppers. Researchers helped relax subjects by using video and music in six different experiments. The study reports shoppers focused less on price or specific features and more on the benefits of owning the item. And that’s exactly the purpose of holiday store parties. With a glass of wine or champagne, a much stronger relaxant then the nature videos or the music the researchers used in the study, retailers hope you are more willing to spend more money than what you expected when you walked through the door.

Don’t shop, talk and text

With recent state laws prohibiting texting and/or talking on a cell phone while driving, you might wonder what other activities are affected by cell phone use. Another recent study from the School of Health Technology and Management at Stony Brook University in New York found that texting and talking on a cell phone while walking results in walking errors and could interfere with memory recall.

Woroch says shoppers can easily be distracted by text messages, emails and phone calls. “These can cause you to overlook sale signs, forget to use or comply properly with coupons and simply pick up things not on your list, which all leads to overspending. Sticking to a shopping budget with a planned coupon list takes attention to detail,” she says.

Keep your eye on the prize

While tapping into your smartphone to access mobile coupons or compare prices, you could be tempted to make an unplanned purchase, Woroch says. Another study published by the American Marketing Association has proven the theory: The more time you spend in a store walking around outside the path of your shopping list, the more you spend, especially when tempted by promotions that pop up on your phone.

The researchers knew what shoppers planned to purchase before walking into the store and used radio frequency identification tracking to conduct the field experiment. They tested the effect of consumers’ walking path through a store when smartphones, with location-based mobile promotion apps such as FourSquare, display users deals and savings in the store. Then researchers compared their receipts with the original shopping lists.

The experiment found that consumers, on average, overspent $13.83 when a coupon popped up on their phone that required them to walk near their planned shopping list path, but a mobile coupon requiring shoppers to walk through the store and away from their planned path increased overspending to $21.29. Every 55 feet outside the unplanned path added $1 to unplanned spending.

Wear high heels

A new study by two Brigham Young University marketing professors reveals that shoppers who wear high heels while shopping are more likely to make sensible decisions and not overspend. That’s because wearing heels gives you a heightened sense of balance so you’re less likely to stand in uncomfortable shoes or walk around the store beyond than what’s necessary.

item.title: Black Friday shopping tips
item.dc:creator: Naomi Mannino
item.description: Whether you agree with it or not, Thanksgiving Day is now an official shopping day. More than 20 major retailers will be open on Thursday and Black Friday. Last year, when only a handful of stores were open on Thanksgiving Day, more than 35 million were roaming the aisles, according to the National Retail Federation […]
item.content:encoded:
Whether you agree with it or not, Thanksgiving Day is now an official shopping day. More than 20 major retailers will be open on Thursday and Black Friday. Last year, when only a handful of stores were open on Thanksgiving Day, more than 35 million were roaming the aisles, according to the National Retail Federation 2012 survey. Twenty-eight percent of those who shopped during Black Friday weekend were at stores by midnight on Thanksgiving, up 24 percent in 2011 and 10 percent in 2010.

If you’re planning to shop on Thanksgiving Day, here are store hours for 10 top Black Friday destinations:

  • Wal-Mart: 6 p.m. Thursday-Black Friday
  • Target: 8 p.m. Thursday-Black Friday
  • Best Buy: 6 p.m. Thursday-Black Friday
  • Sports Authority: 6 p.m.-midnight Thursday; 6 a.m. through Black Friday
  • Macy’s: 8 p.m. Thursday-Black Friday hours depend on location
  • Kohl’s: 8 p.m. Thursday-Black Friday
  • JC Penney: 8 p.m. Thursday-Black Friday
  • Sears: 8 p.m. Thursday-Black Friday
  • Staples: 8 p.m.-midnight; opens 6 a.m. Black Friday
  • Toys ‘R’ Us: 5 p.m.- Black Friday hours depend on location

Bonus: Two stores open early on Thanksgiving Day

  • Kmart: 6 a.m. Thursday-Black Friday
  • Old Navy: 9 a.m.- 4 p.m. Thursday; opens again at 7 p.m.-Black Friday

Take it

  • Guaranteed door busters: Be at the store during the hours advertised for door busters. Wal-Mart has increased its list of guaranteed door busters for customers who follow the rules and will give you a voucher for any sold-out item.
  • Discounted Apple products: It’s widely known that Apple is stingy on discounts, but authorized sellers are undercutting it. Wal-Mart, for example, is offering a $100 gift card for the purchase of a regularly-priced Apple iPad mini Wi-Fi 16GB (in two colors) for $299 and a $75 gift card for the purchase of an Apple iPhone 5C 16GB smartphone for $45.
  • Bundled gaming systems: You may not be able to score (due to very limited supplies, already sold out) or afford an Xbox One or a PlayStation 4, but you can find fantastic bundled deals for last year’s gaming systems. A PlayStation 3 game console with the “Move” bundle including a controller and a game costs $249 at BestBuy, while the PS4 system alone costs $399 and bundles cost over $500, even at Wal-Mart.
  • Deals on large appliances: Websites such as Sears, Lowe’s and The Home Depot will offer some of their best deals of the year on dishwashers, ovens and washers and dryers, reports Dealnews.com, who tracked sale prices throughout the holidays last year. It pays to check regular prices now and look for deals if your significant other has his or her heart set on a new dishwasher, washer and dryer, vacuum cleaner (Hoover took 30 percent off site-wide last year) or any small kitchen appliances (under $10 even).
  • Tools also on sale: Dealnews.com also predicts that Black Friday will be the best time to buy drills, wrenches, socket sets, tool storage units and more from stores such as The Home Depot, Lowe’s, Sears and Kmart.

Leave it

  • No-name gift baskets and sets: These are called “fillers” in the retail industry. That’s because retailers rely on these high-margin, unbranded item purchases to fund the door-buster discounts on electronics, says James Dion, president of Dionco, a retail-consulting firm in Chicago. These items could be no-name food, toiletry, bath and skincare gift sets or baskets. Other options include private label or exclusive store brand bundles such as cookware, kitchen utensil or even bedding sets that may be of poorer quality. Keep in mind you can’t price check these because they are typically unbranded and exclusive only to that store. Even though the gift baskets are packaged nicely, it may be cheaper to create your own.
  • Luxury items: Dion says designer brand names don’t usually participate in Black Friday discounts, so it’s wise to look carefully at any exclusions for any coupon you might want to use on Black Friday. However, the exception at is the designer brand outlet stores, which typically offer deeper storewide discounts on Black Friday than any other time of the year.
  • Toys: Even though you’ll see lots of Black Friday deals for toys, its usually better to wait until the first two weeks of December to purchase toys when discounts were steeper last year, reports Dealnews.com.

Most Black Friday deals are also available online and most retailers will be offering site-wide savings discount in addition to free shipping.

The most important thing, says Dion, is to check the retail and sale prices of the items on your gift list now to know whether you are getting a deal on Black Friday. Also, before heading out, be sure and double-check the Black Friday deal requirements. Some stores are offering specific deals on Thanksgiving Day and different sales on Black Friday. Lastly, know the model numbers, sizes, styles and prices so you’ll be able to easily spot the best Black Friday deals.

item.title: Holiday gift guide: Smartphones for kids
item.dc:creator: Naomi Mannino
item.description: If a tablet or a smartphone is at the top of your kids’ holiday wish list this year, you aren’t alone. According to a recent report from the NPD Group titled “Kids and Apps: A New Era of Play,” 79 percent of 2,248 parents with children ages 2 to 14 report that they or their […]
item.content:encoded:
If a tablet or a smartphone is at the top of your kids’ holiday wish list this year, you aren’t alone. According to a recent report from the NPD Group titled “Kids and Apps: A New Era of Play,” 79 percent of 2,248 parents with children ages 2 to 14 report that they or their children own a mobile device, such as a smartphone or tablet, for the child to use. That’s up from 63 percent last year and that figure is only expected to grow. This year’s survey update revealed that 51 percent of children are now using smart devices and nearly 40 percent of the kids represented in the survey are considered a primary user of the device.

The report also found that children don’t use these devices to replace other activities but they multi-task with them, such as browsing the tablet while watching TV. The number of activities children do on smart devices was also found to be increasing. Games were the favorite activity for 87 percent of children.

If you have reservations about buying a device for your child, it’s not a choice to be made lightly, according to Sophia Pierroutsakos, a screen-time expert, speaker on family wellness and child development and professor of psychology at St. Louis Community College.

Think gift choices through

The amount of screen time with gadgets such as smartphones, game consoles and tablets should be regulated, especially the younger they are.

“As a developmental psychologist and as a parent of a 4-year-old and an 11-year-old, I recommend thinking hard about why you are spending your money on it, how your family will use it and how you will regulate it before buying anything,” Pierroutsakos says.

Toys versus screens

“If ‘screen’ toys don’t fit with your family goals or your budget, then simply choose not to give it,” Pierroutsakos says. “You can take it off the list and ask kids what else they want.” She says giving something you can’t afford (or puts you in credit card debt into next year) or aren’t prepared to handle isn’t the best idea. “I advise parents spend money on things that will bring you together instead of apart. If you think a tablet or a smartphone will help you come together as a family and you are prepared to regulate their use – then buy it,” she advises.

Save money on toys: According to the deal-tracking website Dealnews.com, skip Black Friday and Cyber Monday discounts in favor of the deeper toy discounts, especially on toys from the Toys ‘R’ Us “Fabulous 15″ list, you will find during first two weeks of December. Prices dropped 37 percent on other basic toys such as LEGOs and other classic toys in December last year. The one exception is LeapFrog, whose prices actually rose during the same time period.

Save money on iPhones and iPads and other electronics: Dealnews.com reports that the iPad 4 price may fall to around $399 (the same price as the new iPad mini with Retina display and the iPad 2). Apple usually discounts 5 percent to 10 percent on Black Friday, but other authorized sellers such as Amazon, MacMall and MacConnection may offer discounts up to 20 percent. Get to know the regular, retail prices now for any electronics you might want so you can spot Black Friday deals.

Save money on gaming consoles: Opt for a bundled console deal that includes extras such as controllers and game titles you want, which were discounted last year 30 percent to 40 percent off their retail prices, according Dealnews.com. Don’t expect any discounts on the new Xbox One or PlayStation 4, which will be in short supply.

Give experiences instead of stuff

“Part of the holidays is giving your kids joy … and they don’t always know themselves what that is. Most of all, kids still want your time and attention. Money spent on experiences, even if they don’t go as planned, are always learning opportunities and memories for your child’s heart and mind,” Pierroutsakos advises.

Save money on experiences: Groupon or Living Social is a great way to buy experiences for activities you can do together on the cheap. You can find deals for all sorts of fun activities such as high tea, trampoline gyms, kid’s cooking classes, exercise classes, nail spas, horseback riding and even museums, sporting events and tourist attractions.

item.title: Quick holiday decor fixes for under $50
item.dc:creator: Chie Davis
item.description: While you are preparing for visitors this holiday season, make sure your home reads ready — not wreck! Don’t abandon your hosting duties if you don’t have time or resources to renovate. Robin Callan of Room Fu, sports a “black belt in bad-ass design.” The former creative director turned interior guru now helps people “navigate […]
item.content:encoded:
