While you are preparing for visitors this holiday season, make sure your home reads ready — not wreck! Don’t abandon your hosting duties if you don’t have time or resources to renovate. Robin Callan of Room Fu, sports a “black belt in bad-ass design.” The former creative director turned interior guru now helps people “navigate the challenging issues of remodeling” within a budget. Before the in-laws come knocking, here are Callan’s quick fix décor solutions to spruce up your abode for $50 or less.

Tip 1: Tackle

Tackle the area that your visitors will inhabit first. Set an alarm to organize the space for an hour and reward yourself once the task is complete. “Have comfortable linens, a reading lamp and a water pitcher on the night stand, Callan says. RemoveAndReplace.com offers some DIY options for lamps for under $50.

“Good black out curtains are always helpful for guests who may have trouble sleeping.” Stock the bathroom with lotion, bath salts, an extra toothbrush and robe, she says. “Give them that hotel or spa retreat experience. You can get trial-sized things for little money. Put a tree branch in a vase in the bathroom. Just having that natural element takes you a long way.”

Tip 2: Tweak

Minor tweaks can transform a room from drab to fab. Callan emphasizes, “I’m a big fan of alternative color palettes for the holidays.” Add an accent color to your living room space by pulling from the colors of your Christmas ornaments. “Maybe that’s just 2 pillows,” she adds. World Market offers a chic selection of pillows for under $30.

Flip off the overhead switch and use low ambient light when entertaining. “A really fun statement lamp makes a big difference. I go for big, chunky, colorful vases in simplified forms. When you get that shot of color in an unexpected place, it feels like a huge upgrade. Home Goods always has distinctive lamps for a fraction of what you’d pay elsewhere.”

Tip 3: Paint

Want to attract prosperity in the New Year? Slap on a coat of courage. “There’s a lot that goes into the psychology of color and how it affects you,” says Callan. “I had a client who was a painter.” She neglected her craft for many years. After Room Fu re-painted her home, “her space felt much more personalized. It inspired her to start pursing creative outlets again. For $50 you could paint a whole room. If you’re scared of color, bump up your shade 2 notches on the color strip. It will be a shock for the first 2 weeks, but if you can just sit tight with it, you’ll be surprised.”

Tip 4: Flow

Establish a harmonious flow. The decorator explains, “In a bedroom, the first place I want to try putting the bed is opposite the door. So that when you’re laying in bed you have a clear view of the door. That’s good for both the inhabitant and the visitor. When you enter the bedroom, you see the bed in all it’s splendor.”

Tip 5: Utilize

Instead of dreaming of a walk-in closet, utilize hidden space. “A typical closet has 1 rod and 1 shelf above it. Even if you have a bunch of things hanging, (there‘s) all of this space from hip level down that doesn’t get used. With metro shelves from Target you can add bins and take advantage of vertical storage in your closet. I created a butler’s pantry in my laundry room, (in) an alcove under the stairs. I found used bookshelves on Craigslist for $10, for my cookbooks, small appliances and table linens. Everything has a place.”

item.title: Start preparing for tax season now
item.dc:creator: Julie Bawden-Davis
item.description: The end of the year is looming and before you know it, Uncle Sam will expect you to file your taxes. Now is the best time to take stock of your tax situation. “Once January hits — with limited exceptions — it’s too late to take advantage of tax deductions for this year,” says tax […]
item.content:encoded:
The end of the year is looming and before you know it, Uncle Sam will expect you to file your taxes. Now is the best time to take stock of your tax situation.

“Once January hits — with limited exceptions — it’s too late to take advantage of tax deductions for this year,” says tax attorney and former IRS special agent Julian Block, who has written several books on income tax. “Now is the perfect time to make strategic moves in order to save as much money as possible on this year’s tax return.”

Help ensure that April 15th comes and goes without a hitch by keeping the following tips in mind.

Decide on year-end charitable donations

The standard advice is to make donations to charities in December to take advantage of the tax break on next year’s tax return. But Block advises to determine what type of return you’ll be filing before pulling out your checkbook.

In general there are two types of tax filings: itemizing every tax deduction or choosing a standard deduction, which is determined by the federal government. The Internal Revenue Service can help you decide whether you should itemize deductions.

“If you’ll be itemizing for 2013, then make as many donations as possible by the end of the year. But if you’re going to take standard deductions and not itemize, then don’t make those donations before the close of 2013, because you can’t write them off and they’ll be wasted,” he says. “Hold off making donations until 2014 when you can get a tax break if you itemize.”

Include charitable contribution expenses

Besides the checks you write to charities, the expenses you incur volunteering are also tax deductible when you itemize, Block says. Allowable write-offs for your good deeds include out-of-pocket unreimbursed expenses, such as travel costs (train, bus and plane), gas, tolls and parking.

Consider end-of-year medical expenses

If you’ll be itemizing this year’s tax return, now is the time to make an appointment for the dentist, doctor or ophthalmologist you’ve been putting off. However, add up your medical expenses so far this year to make sure you’ll reach the necessary threshold.

If you are going to itemize, tax guidelines currently state that you can write off any medical expenses that exceed 10 percent of your adjusted gross income, and 7.5 percent if you are older than 65, Block says. “If your planned medical expenses won’t push you over the 7.5 or 10 percent mark, there isn’t any good tax reason to do them. You’d be better off waiting until January and claiming them on the following year’s taxes.”

If you do end up making that appointment, you’ll also have to pay the bill by the end of the year for these expenses to qualify for this year’s tax return.

Check state tax totals

Now is a good time to determine if you’ve paid sufficient state tax for the year in order to avoid penalties. To do so, consult your most recent paystub. Take your current gross income for the year and subtract from it any deductions you’ve paid so far (medical expenses, charitable contributions, real estate taxes, mortgage interest, state income taxes and state sales taxes). This gives you your taxable income. Multiply this figure by your applicable state tax rate, which you can find by searching on your state’s tax board page. The resulting amount will be what you owe in state taxes.*

If you haven’t paid sufficient state tax and you’re employed by a company, adjust your tax deductions on your W-4 so more taxes are taken out through the rest of the year. If you’re self-employed, pay more estimated tax before the end of the year to make up the difference. In order to avoid penalties, which vary by state, you must pay at least 90 percent of this year’s calculated state tax liability or the same amount you paid last year.

*If you prefer not to do any calculations and your pay and deductions are similar to last year, simply make sure that you’re paying the same amount in state taxes this year. You can do this by comparing your most recent paystub to one during the same time period last year.

Get organized

Take time now to look for and record all of your deductions. “Tend to this organization task by the end of the year while the year’s expenditures are still fresh in your mind,” Block says. “It will be easier to remember what you spent, and you’ll be less likely to overlook any deductions.”

If you compile all of your documentation now, you won’t have to wait until April 15th to submit your tax return. And the earlier you submit in the new year, the faster you’ll receive your much welcome refund.

item.title: Seize savings on organic food

item.description: Eating right is no picnic. It’s not cheap either, especially if you want to buy organic food. item.content:encoded:
Eating right is no picnic. It’s not cheap either, especially if you want to buy organic food. In fact, while there’s a tremendous momentum for organic sales, which spiked 10 percent in 2012 from the previous year, the overwhelming reason consumers say they don’t purchase organic is that it’s too expensive, according to Laura Batcha, a spokesperson for the Organic Trade Association (OTA), in Brattleboro, Vermont.

Buying organic can cost more than conventional foods. OTA surveyed 639 U.S. households and 600 members of KIWI magazine’s Parents’ Advisory Board and released its results in the U.S. Families’ Organic Attitude & Beliefs 2013 study. It shows parents who buy organic food spend more a week on groceries (an average of $119) than parents who don’t buy organic ($104). Yet, “there are many ways families can enjoy all organic meals every day for about the same cost as conventionally produced food,” Batcha says. We’re talking all organic, not just a few items here and there. Here’s how:

Watch for in-store specials. To maximize savings, pick up the in-store flyer at your local organic foods store, such Whole Foods Market, before you shop. Come equipped with a shopping list and stock up on savings by buying enough sale items for several meals. Price-check several local grocery stores for often-purchased organic items to find the lowest prices. A site such as www.Mysupermarket.com is an easy way to comparison grocery shop.

Buy in bulk or by the case. Buy flour, legumes, oats, nuts and spices from the bin (you save
by doing your own packaging). PushPenny reported last week that November is a good time to stock up on baking staples because stores advertise sales and deals for the holidays.

Plan meals for a month out. In general, the OTA says consumers should have keep a well-
stocked pantry and plan meals for the month, not just a week at a time. When you’ve got lots of staples around, such as organic spices, oils, nuts, dried beans, flour/grain and frozen produce that you’ve purchased on sale, it’s easier to round out your recipes with perishable ingredients, such as fresh vegetables, meat and milk. And when organic meat and fish goes on sale, stock your freezer.

Take home the house or generic brand. Similar to conventional supermarkets, many organic foods stores such as Whole Foods Market carry their own line of products — everything from pasta sauce and cereal to olive oil. Because the federal government regulates the organic certification, private label organic products must be held to the same standard as organic branded products. And, in general, the quality of private label products now rival branded products. Private label products can cost as much as 30 percent less.

Shop in season. This general savings rule of thumb applies to organic produce, too. Organic apples, for example, can be much less expensive when you buy them at peak season (fall) than at any other time of the year. Lock in the savings by freezing seasonal produce for use later. In June, which is berry season, buy as many fresh blueberries as your freezer space can hold.

Clip or download coupons. On average, two in 10 families report they “always buy” organic, with fruits, vegetables and dairy leading the way, according to OTA. That means there are still a lot of families who aren’t buying organic, always or ever. To lure more consumers, organic manufacturers frequently offer high-value coupons. Try calling the company or posting on its Facebook page to request the coupon, says OTA’s Batcha. By “high-value,” we’re talking free, as in one free Stonyfield YoKids Organic Smoothie Pack or one free Horizon product up to $4.99, which are two coupons available now that expire on Dec. 31. To take advantage of these offers, you have to register with each company to receive more offers via email.

item.title: Meatless meals can stretch your dollars
item.dc:creator: Sandra Gordon
item.description: Whether you’re bringing a casserole to a holiday potluck or inviting everyone to your house for a festive feast, serving meatless options can help you save on your food bill — and stretch your holiday dollar. “When you’re not including meat, you automatically save money because meat tends to be the most expensive ingredient,” says […]
item.content:encoded:
Whether you’re bringing a casserole to a holiday potluck or inviting everyone to your house for a festive feast, serving meatless options can help you save on your food bill — and stretch your holiday dollar.

“When you’re not including meat, you automatically save money because meat tends to be the most expensive ingredient,” says Jill Skeem, the author of “Comfort Food Gets a Makeover.”

How much can you save by going meatless? Skeem recently did a cost comparison between traditional meat lasagna and the spinach, mushroom, onion option she features in her cookbook, which doesn’t even include cheese (though you can add it to the recipe if you want to). To serve 15 people, Skeem calculated that a lasagna made with ground beef, ricotta and mozzarella costs around $34; her veggie lasagna costs just $17. This is a savings of 50 percent. “The trick is to make your veggie dishes so delicious that no one will miss the meat — or realize that you cut corners,” Skeem says.

Smart, money-saving substitutes start with appetizers. Instead of serving pigs in a blanket, make your own hummus with chickpeas, olive oil, tahini, salt and pepper and other spices, such as cumin. At just pennies per serving, beans are a basic cost cutter. Serve it with crudité. Plan to use the leftover carrots and celery in a stir fry. In fact, why not plan to serve your guests leftovers? If you’ve got leftover rice around, for example, serve fried rice. Plan your menu around what you have on hand and “repurpose everything,” Skeem says.

Think seasonally too. Butternut squash is plentiful this time of year. A five pound squash can cost as little as $2.50. As a first course, think butternut squash soup, not pricey shrimp bisque. Want more holiday meal ideas? Here are two of Skeem’s vegetarian party-friendly recipes that can get you started. You can feel good about serving vegetarian fare not just because it is budget friendly. “When beans, tofu and grains substitute for meat, your guests eat healthier too,” Skeem says.

Jill Skeem’s Lasagna with Spinach, Mushroom & Onion

Ingredients
12 sheets lasagna noodles
2 10 oz. boxes frozen chopped spinach, defrosted
1 16 oz. block tofu, extra-firm
1/4 cup sun-dried tomatoes, oil packed
1/2 cup kalamata olives, pitted
3/4 cup, fresh basil
5 cups mushrooms, sliced
4 cups onions, finely sliced half moons
Sea salt
Black pepper
Olive oil
4 cups marinara sauce

Directions
Place uncooked lasagna noodle sheets in a large baking dish, cover with boiling water for 20 minutes. Meanwhile, place a cotton kitchen towel in a bowl; empty spinach into towel, wrap tightly and squeeze out excess liquid. Then, in a food processor, blend tofu, sun-dried tomatoes, olives, 3/4 cup basil, 1 tsp. sea salt and 1/2 tsp. black pepper. Add 1 tsp. olive oil. Pulse until well blended and has paste-like consistency. Set aside.

Heat oil in large skillet and sauté onions, mushrooms and spinach separately with large pinches of salt and pepper. When spinach is almost done, add cooked onions and mushrooms and sauté together 1 to 2 minutes to combine. Place mixture in bowl and let cool before building lasagna.

To compile the lasagna, pre-heat oven to 350 degrees. Spread 1 cup marinara sauce on bottom of a 9×13 baking dish. Place 3 pasta sheets on top of sauce. Spread one third tofu mixture on pasta, then spread one-third spinach mixture on top of tofu. Spread 1 cup marinara sauce on top of spinach mixture. Repeat the sequence two more times. Top with last 3 pasta sheets and 1 cup marinara sauce. Cover with foil and bake 45 to 50 minutes. Garnish with fresh basil and let stand 15 minutes before serving.

Party Vegetable Fried Rice

Serves 4; if you have more guests coming, double or triple the recipe
Instructions
1 Tbsp. light sesame or olive oil
1/2 cup onions, diced
Sea salt
1/2 cup carrots, diced
1/2 cup diced celery, peas, mushrooms or any combo vegetables
2 cups, leftover brown or white rice
1/4-1/2 C water
Soy sauce
1 Tbsp. ginger juice, freshly grated
1/4 cup scallions, finely sliced as a garnish

Directions
Heat olive oil in a medium skillet. Add onions with pinch of sea salt and sauté 1 to 2 minutes. Add additional vegetables separately; sauté 1 to 2 minutes before adding each veggie.

Place rice on top of sautéed vegetables; add water, cover and simmer 5 to 7 minutes. Check to see if rice is getting soft. If it is, add 1/2 tsp. soy sauce, stir well. Cover, sauté another 5 minutes until rice is sticky. Then add ginger juice, stir and garnish with scallions.

item.content:encoded:
Do you use oil, salt, sugar, extracts, baking powder, spices, cornstarch, yeast, pie crusts, chocolate morsels, canned and frozen vegetables, butter, cream cheese, cake mix, parchment paper and tinfoil throughout the year? Well, now’s the time to stock up.

“Every year, at the beginning of November, retailers start advertising sales and deals on these holiday feast ingredients, and manufacturers distribute their coupons for these items,” says Stephanie Nelson, founder of CouponMom.com. “You put the two together and you can stock up on these ingredients until well into next year for the cheapest prices of the year.”

How to coupon

  1. Start with the Sunday newspaper and clip at least two coupons (preferably more) from the inserts for items you use. Find more coupons online at Smartsource.com, Redplum.com and CouponMom.com as well as in advertisements distributed by the stores.
  2. Look for sale prices, special promotions and deals, BOGOs (buy-one-get-one-free), two-for-one items and 10 items for $10.
  3. Then match up the coupons with the sales and deals. While it is tempting to take advantage of all of the potential savings, you only want to purchase items you know you will use.

Digital downloads

Did you know that many grocery stores offer digital coupons? Take advantage, Nelson says. “The beauty of these digital coupons is that it’s an extra free coupon.”

You will likely have to create an account on each grocer’s website, which will then be linked to your discount card. Once you are logged into the  website, you can add digital coupons to your account. When you present your discount card in the checkout aisle, the coupons will automatically be applied when the item is scanned.

If you are having a hard time remembering which coupons you digitally stored, you aren’t alone. Nelson suggests printing a list of coupons when planning your shopping trip and placing the list in the front of your coupon binder for easy access.

For more tips on where to find coupons, watch this video from The Lemonade Connection.


Pick up produce

Be on the lookout for BOGO or two-for-one sales on bagged apples and cranberries and even single pumpkins. You can use them throughout the month of December for baking or make them a part of your holiday home decor. Here’s how to choose and store these items, thanks to the Utah State University Cooperative Extension:

  • Apples: The apple season begins at the end of August, so they are freshly picked in October and November, unlike apples bought during the summer, which are likely last year’s stock. Apples keep for several weeks in the crisper drawer of your refrigerator in an unsealed bag. At room temperature, they will shrivel, lose flavor and juicy crispness sooner. Store other fresh produce separately because apples release ethylene gas that can damage other fruits. For baking and cooking in pies or to make fresh applesauce, use Braeburn, Golden Delicious, Granny Smith, Jonathan or Honeycrisp varieties.
  • Cranberries: Cranberry harvesting season is October through December. Once purchased, cranberries can be stored in the refrigerator for up to four weeks and used as needed. They can also be frozen: Place in an air-tight freezer bag for up to a year. No thawing is necessary when you want to add them to a recipe.
  • Pumpkins: With a fall harvest, pumpkins are rarely on sale before Halloween. But they are almost always cheaper at a grocery store versus a private farm or church pumpkin patch. Choose a pumpkin that is firm and heavy for its size. Round pumpkins tend to be lighter and less meaty than oblong pumpkins. And always roast the seeds!

Get a free turkey

Check all your local grocery circulars every week for special deals and compare per-pound prices for the type of turkey you want. Look for free turkey deals when spending a certain amount at the store or for buying participating products.

Nelson says your Thanksgiving feast can be your least expensive meal of the year if you shop smart. Using coupons stacked on top of store sales and deals, you’ll get everything for just a fraction of the regular price.

item.content:encoded:
The top appliances trending this holiday season are smaller gadgets that reap big rewards. Save a bundle by complimenting your kitchen staples with these compact appliances. They’re guaranteed to woo your guests without exceeding your budget.

(All items can be found online by clicking the name of the product)

Cuisinart Smart Stick Hand Blender: $34.99

After decorating, shopping and preparing for visitors all day, who has the energy to stir in ingredients the old fashioned way? Avoid tracking down the multiple components of your high speed mixer by gifting yourself with simplicity. Cuisinart’s stainless steel, Smart Stick Hand Blender allows you to reach into pots and bowls effortlessly to mix up soups or milkshakes without leaving chunks of fruits or vegetables. Working like a magic wand, this one-touch, two-speed appliance has never made blending seem this smooth. The immersion-styled mixer comes in red, white or blue, which makes it an ideal present for the patriotic cook in your life. Designed with a removable shaft for easy storage, this 15.75″H x 4.8″W x 4.8″D product is dishwasher safe. It retails for $39.99, but is currently on sale at Kohl’s for $34.99.

NESCO 5 Piece Non-Stick Buffet: $31.01

Once your main spread is ready for consumption, allow NESCO’s 5 Piece Non-Stick Buffet to serve it up. Doubling as a roaster and mini buffet, guests can nosh on warm food all night. Complete with non-stick heating pans, this 3.8 pound, 18 quart delight is sleek and small enough to fit on your dining room table. A cinch to clean because it is dishwasher safe, it’s only available online.

Hamilton Beach Mini Breakfast Sandwich Maker: $29.99

If your rockstar celebration goes from dusk ‘til dawn, treat your guests to a delicious morning meal without leaving your home. Simply choose your ingredients and pile them into Hamilton Beach’s Mini Breakfast Sandwich Maker. Select your favorite bread, pre-cooked meat and cheese and place them onto the contraption’s layered slots. There’s even a built in hot plate that allows you to cook eggs, before pairing them with the rest of your sandwich. Operating similar to a panini press, once all of the elements of the sandwich are added, it takes only 5 minutes to produce a savory sandwich. All parts of the product are dishwasher friendly. A handy recipe book with these recipes comes inside the packaging.

Keurig K10 Mini Plus Brewing System: $99.99

Nothing sets off a holiday party better than a frothy beverage. If you’ve already invested in a frozen Margarita Machine ($199), invite guests to cozy up with warm java, tea, hot cocoa or even an iced beverage. The Keurig K10 Mini Plus Brewing System allows you to cater to your taste buds, one cup at a time. This single-serving machine comes with a 12-count “K-Cup” variety pack of gourmet coffee, tea and hot cocoa flavors. Add fresh water to this one-cup wonder, pop in your favorite K-Cup flavor, and sip, all within 2 minutes. Keurig offers more than 200 flavors such as French Vanilla and Italian Roast, which are sold separately.

Bella Cake Pop Maker: $17.99

Don’t have time to bake your mom’s popular seven-layer torte? Fear not! The Bella Cake Pop Maker will prepare your holiday dessert in a quarter of the time. Blend your cake batter, add the mix to the tiny baking cup tray and close the lid. Twelve fresh cake pops or donuts are made within 5 minutes. Dip your treats in chocolate frosting and then decorate with sprinkles. Plastic sticks are included to showcase your dessert once complete.

item.title: Gluten-free Thanksgiving can be savory
item.dc:creator: Chie Davis
item.description: It’s almost time to shine the silver in preparation for the biggest family feasting day of the year! item.content:encoded:
It’s almost time to shine the silver in preparation for the biggest family feasting day of the year! But, with a recent Mayo Clinic study estimating that nearly 2 million Americans suffer from celiac disease, traditional Thanksgiving meals could be a thing of the past.

“Celiac disease is an auto immune problem,” says nutritionist Sandra Meyerowitz. “The body rejects gluten as a foreign substance. It’s a protein found in particular grains, wheat, barley, rye and (some) oats. It sees gluten as a trigger and starts fighting it off.”

If you’ve recently boarded the gluten-free train, the thought of sacrificing holiday staples such as pumpkin pie and stuffing may cause your heart to ache more than your stomach. No need to suffer in silence! The rise of celiac has inspired tasty alternatives. Here’s how to prepare a savory, cost-effective, gluten-free Thanksgiving meal.

Gluten-Free Fun Apple Crisp 
from the site Gluten-Free Fun
Serves 8

Fruit Filling
10 apples, cored, peeled, and sliced thin
7 tablespoons of apple cider
2 tablespoons of raw agave nectar
1 1/2 teaspoons of cinnamon

Crisp Topping
1 1/4 cups of light brown sugar
1 1/4 cups of Gluten-Free Bisquick
2 teaspoons of cinnamon
6 tablespoons of Best Life Buttery Spread or Earth Balance Natural Buttery Spread

Directions
1. Preheat oven to 350° F.
2. Grease a 9X12 inch glass baking dish with some of the Buttery Spread.
3. Mix together the apples, apple cider, agave, and 1 1/2 tsps of cinnamon.
4. In a separate mixing bowl, mix together the light brown sugar, gluten-free Bisquick, and 2 tsps of cinnamon.
5. Add the 6 tablespoons of the Best Life Buttery Spread on tablespoon at a time.
6. Stir together with a whisk and then use hands if necessary.
7. Layer the glass baking dish with crisp topping, fruit filling, and top off with the rest of the crisp topping.
8. Bake 40 minutes, until topping is crispy and filling is near boiling. Apples should be soft when pierced with a fork.


Celebrate!

No adult wants to feel like they’ve been banished to the kids table because of digestion issues. Blogger Shauna Ahern of Gluten-Free Girl suggests organizing a potluck to get everyone involved.

“A lot of women have a hard time expressing why they have to be gluten-free,” Ahern says. “Turn it in into a joyful celebration. Most of the traditional dishes are gluten free: turkey (minus the gravy), mashed potatoes and cranberries.”

If you’re a guest, bring sharable dishes “that no one would notice that gluten is missing. Gluten-free cornbread stuffing is always a big hit. Bring a delicious dessert,” says gluten-free advocate Erin Smith. Her favorite indulgence is Apple Crisp.

Prepare

Elana Amsterdam, author of “The Gluten-Free Almond Flour Cookbook”, thinks in advance when planning meals for her family. “I make my menu a week ahead of time and shop the weekend before.”

If you’re a guest, speak to the host at least a few weeks before the big meal.

“Make sure they understand that your food cannot come in contact with anything that has gluten… . Ask your host if you can make your plate first to avoid any possible cross-contamination,” Smith suggests.

Don’t forget to taste test your new creation. “If you are worried about the flavor of your gluten-free dish, trying making it a few weeks before the holiday feast.” she says.


Budget

Some gluten-free products are expensive, so planning ahead can also save you some pennies.

“In the weeks leading up to Thanksgiving, you can save the heels of your gluten-free bread to use to make stuffing. Preserve the bread by freezing it before preparing your stuffing,” encourages Smith. Once the bread is ready, follow Gluten-Free Girl’s quick recipe called The Gluten-Free Stuffing the Chef and I Will Be Making for Thanksgiving.

Save a few more pennies by opting for pre-made dessert mixes. “These tend to be cheaper than buying individual gluten-free flours and making your own blend. They are also easier to prepare when putting together your gluten-free meal,” Smith says.

Sweet rice flour and almond flour are good options for making gravy. “Try to include other grains like buckwheat, millet and gluten-free oats. It’s nice to have other things to fall back on so that you’re not taking out that whole food group,” Meyerowitz adds.

Here is a video of Whole Foods Executive Chef Brad DeFurio on how to prepare gluten-free gravy

Experiment

Gluten-free experts find joy in recipes that put a twist on tradition.

“People forget that Thanksgiving is a celebration of the harvest. Play with sweet potatoes, squashes and seeds. I love sweet potato gratin. Slice up the sweet potato thick, add in coconut milk and put walnuts and seeds on top. Put it into the oven and bake it,” Ahern suggests.

For a killer dessert, she raves about her gluten-free pumpkin pie. “Use roasted pumpkin. Turn it into a puree. Add spices, coconut milk and Chinese 5 spice powder. It keeps people on their toes!”

item.title: 7 ways to stash cash for an emergency fund
item.dc:creator: Julie Bawden-Davis
item.description: Emergencies happen. Whether it’s a sudden loss of income, unforeseen medical costs, hefty house repairs or a broken down car, life is full of unexpected budget-busters. And they always come along at the most inconvenient time. Without an emergency fund, additional expenses can put a huge strain on your finances, says financial adviser and endowment […]
item.content:encoded:
Emergencies happen. Whether it’s a sudden loss of income, unforeseen medical costs, hefty house repairs or a broken down car, life is full of unexpected budget-busters. And they always come along at the most inconvenient time.

Without an emergency fund, additional expenses can put a huge strain on your finances, says financial adviser and endowment strategist Scott Cramer, president of Cramer & Rauchegger. “A study conducted by the FINRA Investor Education Foundation showed that households with no emergency funds are almost twice as likely to be involved in a foreclosure,” Cramer says.

When disaster strikes, the last thing you want to do is make matters worse by paying for your emergency with credit or loans, says Shawn Gilfedder, president and CEO of McGraw-Hill Federal Credit Union. “Being prepared for the unexpected will minimize stress and maintain financial health during a difficult time.”

Try these tips to stash cash for an emergency fund.

1. Earmark your tax refund

“For most of us, the one good thing about tax season is the refund; so why not use all or a portion of the extra cash to grow your emergency fund?” suggests Cramer. Gilfedder advises taking action now. “Increase your deductions on your W-4 to give yourself more cash up front, instead of waiting for your tax refund,” he says.

2. Seek out the highest interest rates

Though it’s common practice to keep your emergency fund in a liquid savings account, savings interest rates are at an all-time low, so it makes more sense to open up certificates of deposit, or a CD.

“Consider using some of your savings to set-up a CD ladder – a series of certificates that mature in sequences of 3 or 6 months out,” Cramer says. “As one set of CDs mature, you can roll that money into a new ladder. Or if you need access to your funds, you could withdraw and not renew the CD.”

3.  Automate savings

If you wait until the end of the month to transfer money to your savings account, you might not have any left. Instead, have funds automatically removed from your checking account and deposited into your savings account on a weekly or bi-weekly basis. Saving $40 once a week may be easier than saving $170 at the end of the month. Either way, you’ll save more than $2,000 in a year.

4. Invest surprises

When you receive an unexpected cash infusion, such as a bonus, monetary gift or rebate, after you’re done jumping up and down, put at least 50 percent into your emergency fund.

5. Cut back on incidentals

For one week, write down how much money you spend eating out for lunch, buying gourmet coffee and soda at the vending machine. Cut that amount by 50 to 75 percent and put the money you would have spent on non-essential items into your emergency savings. Saving just $10 a week adds up to $520 in a year.

6. Accumulate spare change

You’d be amazed at how much money you have jingling around the bottom of your purse or stashed in your car. Each time you pay for something in cash, put the change in a glass jar. Roll the coins every one to two months and deposit the money in your emergency savings account.

7. Opt to use cash

Whenever possible, use cash, which will help you stick to your budget. If you only have $60 in cash for groceries, you won’t spend that extra $10 that you often do, which adds up to a lot of savings for your emergency account.

Yes, saving for an emergency fund does take some sacrifice, but it’s well-worth knowing you can pay unforeseen bills.

item.title: Herbal remedies could brighten your winter blues
item.dc:creator: Chie Davis
item.description: Has the end of daylight savings put a chokehold on your cheery mood? If you’re increasingly sluggish, irritable and have resorted to hibernating — it’s time to get your happy back! Fend off the winter blues with low-cost natural remedies. They can easily be found in your kitchen or at a local health food store. […]
item.content:encoded:
Has the end of daylight savings put a chokehold on your cheery mood? If you’re increasingly sluggish, irritable and have resorted to hibernating — it’s time to get your happy back! Fend off the winter blues with low-cost natural remedies. They can easily be found in your kitchen or at a local health food store.

According to the Mayo Clinic, ‘winter blues,’ medically referred to as Seasonal Affective Disorder, is “a type of depression that occurs at the same time every year… . (Symptoms) start in the fall and continue into the winter … sapping your energy.”

Karen Rose is a mother of three, certified herbalist and the owner of Sacred Vibes Herbal Apothecary in Brooklyn, New York. Before raiding your medicine cabinets for a remedy, she suggests looking within the kitchen cabinets.

As the temperature drops, your meal selections should heat up. “Don’t consume cold foods,” Rose warns. “Incorporate spices — like cayenne — into your diet, which warm the body. Bring in broths and soups while concentrating on root vegetables… . Oftentimes we reach for sweets when a cup of tea can be very helpful,” she says. Try brews with vanilla, cinnamon and even chocolate. “Just a cup makes a big difference. It’s about educating people, that they have medicine in their cabinets already. With lots of teas, you can add shaved ginger and cinnamon. A lot of meds are found in spices, like cloves, nutmeg, lemon and honey.”

Nutrient-rich, fermented vegetables should not be ignored, the herbalist says. Meal additions such as kimchi, sauerkraut and miso soup can act as super foods — pumping up your energy while warding off disease. A 2003 study done by the Journal of the National Cancer Institute links the consumption of miso soup with a reduced risk in breast cancer. 

Incorporating herbs into your daily regime can also have transformative effects.

“Our DNA is very similar to that of plants. Pharmaceuticals are symptom based. A plant medicine stops the headache and finds out where we need to make up for it. It tries to go to the source of the problem not just the symptom,” Rose says.

If you’re an herbal newbie hoping to kick your blues to the curb, go slow.

“Choose a few and spend time with them,” Rose suggests. “They’re like friends. Plants have individual energies like we do. Start with 5 plants: garlic, turmeric, cinnamon, ginger and clove.” The herbalists says to try and incorporate them on a daily basis.

If you’re ready for specialty herbs, explore unique tea combinations. Rose blends herbs with precision in her store.

“A lot of our clients, their moods change when the sunlight changes, so we have (a product called) Here Comes the Sun,” she smiles. The ingredients of the tea, which she sells online for $15, include oat straw, borage leaves, tulsi, lemon verbena and lemongrass. The potent mix helps to “tonify the nervous system, which allows you to feel more in balance. It’s designed for bringing sunshine in when there’s not a lot. It’s really delicious, really lemony. It’s known to break through melancholy (feelings) and lift the spirit.”

Herbal elixirs require a longer seeping time than caffeine-based teas. First, boil the water, pour it over the plant leaves and let it seep for 25 minutes. Rose advises drinking herbal teas 2-3 times daily to brighten your mood.

“It’s so important to talk to people about what a body in balance feels like. If you know the signals when you feel like you’re slipping, you can easily come back.”
