item.content:encoded:
This is a screenshot from a YouTube video that explains how to create photo coasters using images from your Instagram feed.

With weeks still left before holiday gifting ensues, why not use your time wisely? Save your money and sanity by getting a jumpstart on personalized, homemade holiday gifts now!

Marci Siegel, owner of Co-Op 28, a Los Angeles-based gift shop, sources handmade goods from crafters from around the world. With a collection of unisex finds, she understands why DIY is trending.
​
​“You can’t find what we have anywhere, except from the artist. It’s far from the same old thing,” Siegel says. Her best-sellers, some of which are handmade subway signs and wooden magnets, suggest that crafters and consumers are thinking outside of the box this year when it comes to gifting.

Create personalized presents for the art lover or fashionista on your list by allowing creativity be your guide. Trade in go-to holiday cookies for dynamic DIYs that also push the boundaries on tradition. Here are ideas guaranteed to wow your family for seasons to come.

For the fashionista

Faceted gems are a perfect gift for the family stylista. DIY-maker Meg Allan Cole has a stress free, easy bake recipe that turns clay into coveted gems.

Gather colored Sculpey clay, knives and a cutting board. “Take a chunk of clay …. Work it until it’s soft and malleable,” Cole says. Separate them into circles. “Use the knife to trim it’s edges until it resembles a faceted look.” Bake the clay pieces in your oven on a non-stick pan for 15 minutes at 275 degrees. Once cooled, use glue to affix earring backs to the artistic gems.

For the bookworm

If they’ve already downloaded “The Hunger Games” trilogy and devoured all of J.K. Rowling’s novels (even that not-so-secret “The Cuckoo’s Calling”), why not create your own series for the bookworm on your list? Whether you conceptualize a fantasy or drama, make it come to life by creating a book online. Sites such as Blurb.com and Lulu.com allow you to customize layouts, scan images and publish, all in less than 2 hours. With an option to print a hard copy or publish an eBook, you can make wedding albums, baby books, cook books or travel journals, starting at $13.

For the art lover

Who says you have to liquidate your savings for an enviable body of artwork? Channel your inner Annie Leibovitz by gifting your family  originals from your Instagram feed. Print out and frame candid close-ups on glossy photo paper. You can also affix and glaze the images to wooden coasters, producing a set of unique libation holders.

Surprise mom by giving her a ceramic photo tile to add to her kitchen backsplash or a magnet for her fridge. For $4, upload a Instagram image to Imagesnap and for a 2X2 tile. For the holiday traveler, send Instagram-inspired postcards or calendars for less than $30. They can be made within minutes and mounted on wood through Artifact Uprising. If your shot belongs in a gallery — blow it up! Use Canvas Pop to transform your bite-sized photo into a canvas sized masterpiece for $40.

For the techie

If you’re one of the cool kids you probably already own a 3-D printer, even though the process is still new and pricey to purchase a 3-D printer.

Using design software that is compatible with your 3-D printer, such as Google Sketchup, which is free, you can sketch a design and select the type of material (plastic, glass, metal) that you’d like to have produce your final product. Press print and watch as your printer makes your DIY gift right before your eyes. Printing time ranges from a few hours to a couple of minutes depending on the materials and dimension of your product.

Nylon chess sets, lamp shades and dream catchers can  be designed on a budget through Shapeways, an online DIY marketplace. For those craving a more literal 3-D project, purchase a glass shadow box from Goodwill. Gather standout trinkets (pressed leaves, coins) from that mementos box you’ve been hiding in your closet. Collage and glue them to patterned paper. Mount the paper inside of the shadow box to create a striking 3-D image.

item.title: Celebrate the season without emptying your savings
item.dc:creator: Julie Bawden-Davis
item.description: The holidays offer a chance to enjoy the company of friends and family members and soak up the wonders of the season. Failing to keep a handle on spending, though, and holiday entertainment costs can quickly add up. Avoid running out of money before you’ve even tackled your gift list by approaching holiday celebrations with […]
item.content:encoded:
The holidays offer a chance to enjoy the company of friends and family members and soak up the wonders of the season. Failing to keep a handle on spending, though, and holiday entertainment costs can quickly add up. Avoid running out of money before you’ve even tackled your gift list by approaching holiday celebrations with a savings mindset.

Gift yourself with savings this holiday season by trying these fun and inexpensive holiday celebration ideas.

Get crafty

Handmade decorations are in, and making your own can save a lot of money, says interior designer RoxAnn Johnson, owner of Spatial Expressions in Orange, Calif. She crotchets holiday decorations from free patterns she picks up at her local yarn store, and she enjoys creating inexpensive ornaments with repurposed items like old jewelry.

“I get Styrofoam balls from the craft store and take apart jewelry that I’m no longer wearing and attach it to the balls,” she says. “I also use old earrings to create garland. The ornaments and garland are fun projects to do with kids, and you end up creating family heirlooms.”

If you need more ideas, Pinterest can provide you with thousands of craft projects.

Volunteer

Celebrate the reason for the season and reach out to help those in need. Check with charitable organizations in your area to see about preparing and serving meals for the less fortunate. You could also visit and read to those in nursing homes or the hospital. Volunteering will get you and your family in the Christmas spirit, and such actions promise to teach your children compassion and important life lessons. To find volunteer opportunities, call your local newspaper to find out when it prints volunteer opportunities and organizations. Also, there are a lot of websites to connect you to the organization of your choice, such as VolunteerMatch.org and Volunteers of America.

Throw a baking party

Get ready for the holiday feasts ahead and spend time with friends and family members by hosting a baking party. Banding together to cook up Thanksgiving and Christmas Day homemade side dishes and freezing them for future use saves money, because you share the cost. Being prepared will also prevent you from making costly last-minute food purchases when it’s time to gather for holiday meals.

Also fun for children and adults is a cookie decorating party. Have everyone bring dough, cookie cutters and toppings, and let the festivities begin. For a small investment, you’ll create happy memories and yummy holiday treats.

Go caroling

Bring out the performer in yourself and your family by spreading holiday cheer and singing carols. Provide everyone with printed Christmas carol favorites and impress your neighbors with some snappy holiday tunes. When you’re done, gather by the fire to share hot apple cider and cast your votes for the best decorated yards in town.

Limit alcoholic drinks

Alcohol can be an enormous expense, and over-serving causes liability issues. Set an alcohol budget and stick to it. For instance, figure on two or three drinks per person and only buy that much wine or beer. Or cut expenses by just serving one holiday drink, such as eggnog. If you think that guests will want more than you’ll be providing, let them know what they can expect and suggest they bring their own to supplement, if they choose.

Hold a holiday classic movie marathon

Get family members and friends involved in creating your own list of top holiday classic movies. If you need inspiration, start with AMC’s movie guide. Once the list has been culled down, invite everyone to come over whenever they can during a weekend day to enjoy a movie or two. For admission, ask that they bring tasty snacks, such as popcorn or candy. And if the holiday season is making you feel especially generous, offer to let adults leave their children with you while they do a little shopping. This could save you even more money by serving as your “present” to them for the holidays.

Sure the holidays bring out the urge to splurge in all of us, and it’s easy to overspend. But with a little ingenuity and by focusing on building relationships, you can save a great deal of money this season and have some fun at the same time.

item.title: Winterizing your skin care routine
item.dc:creator: Naomi Mannino
item.description: Do you change your skin care routine when the seasons change? “If you’re like most women, you don’t,” says Jodi LoGerfo, dermatological nurse-practitioner for Orentreich Medical Group in New York City. “But you should switch up your skin care routine to adapt for (your) skin’s reaction to the colder temperature, wind and drying indoor heat,” […]
item.content:encoded:
Do you change your skin care routine when the seasons change?

“If you’re like most women, you don’t,” says Jodi LoGerfo, dermatological nurse-practitioner for Orentreich Medical Group in New York City. “But you should switch up your skin care routine to adapt for (your) skin’s reaction to the colder temperature, wind and drying indoor heat,” she advises.

This is especially true if you live in the North and face more extreme cold, windy or wet weather or a combination of all three. Also, if you are on an anti-aging or an anti-acne prescription regimen and are using a Retin-A (tretinoin) product or an alpha hydroxy acid (AHA) lotion or a combination of the two, you may need to make some changes because these products have side effects of dryness and irritation that will only be exacerbated by any cold or extreme winter weather.

Re-evaluate your skincare routine for winter

Reduce use of Retin-A products. LoGerfo says you can cut your usage frequency of your prescription and it will continue to regenerate skin cell turn-over and form new collagen but without the drastic side effects of dryness, irritation and cracking that can increase in response to winter weather. Maximum Retin-A use is twice per day (morning and night), but if skin looks or feels irritated, try applying the product just once per day, every other day or even two or three times a week. You can experiment with how often and when to use it (such as morning versus night time if only once per day) so it doesn’t cause the irritating effects. The same goes for over-the-counter anti-aging products containing Retinol, which is also a vitamin A derivative just like Retin-A, but at a much lower concentration. Retinol products have a much less aggressive positive or negative effect on the skin, but you can adjust your usage the same way if necessary, LoGerfo advises.

Switch alpha hydroxy acid lotion for a protective, emollient lotion. “Many times we prescribe an anti-aging regimen combining the use of a Retin-A product and an alpha hydroxy acid product for the best effect. But, during the winter, you can stop using your alpha hydroxyl acid product if skin seems irritated,” LoGerfo suggests. Instead, she recommends using a thick cream facial moisturizer over any Retin-A to protect against cracking, peeling and chapping.

No more long, hot showers. Hot water is very irritating and drying to your skin’s top-most layer, especially if it is already irritated by other products, indoor dry heat, winter wind and cold temperatures. The hot water strips skin it of its natural oils leaving it unprotected and open to cracking and peeling. LoGerfo advises taking quicker, lukewarm showers, for less than 10 minutes at a time, and to pat skin dry gently (no harsh rubbing on skin or hair). While your skin is still damp, apply a super-rich cream moisturizer for hands, feet and anywhere else you see drying or cracked skin. Even better, try adding virgin coconut oil to your skin care routine to help it retain moisture and resist cracking and irritation.

Use a humidifier. Indoor heat can be very drying to your skin. “You’ll know if this is the case in your home if your nasal passages also feel dry,” LoGerfo says. Try a room humidifier all night and even all day to help skin and nasal passages remain moist, the way they should be.

And the one thing you should never change…

Don’t ever go without your sunscreen. Just because it’s winter doesn’t mean the sun is not strong. “I’ve seen some of the most severe sunburns on people doing winter sports such as skiing or ice skating outdoors because snow and ice reflects sunlight in combination with wind burn,” LoGerfo says. “Because your exposed skin (face, neck and hands) is always vulnerable to continuing damage from the sun’s UV rays whether winter or summer, I always recommend using a daily SPF of at least 30 whenever going outside. And don’t forget your lips.”

How will you tune-up your skincare routine for the winter?

item.title: Clamoring for costume jewelry
item.dc:creator: Chie Davis
item.description: From avant-garde statement pieces to delicate classics, celebrities, runway mavens and fashionistas alike are clamoring for costume jewelry. Mega moguls such Oprah Winfrey and Sienna Miller praise designer Lia Sophia, while singers like Beyonce are adorned in the latest Melody Ehsani pieces. With these jewels ranging from $16-$125, it’s only natural that celeb sitings would […]
item.content:encoded:
On the left is a piece from Vanessa Arizaga, the bracelet is designed by Amber Mims, and the two necklaces on the right were created by Bari Ziperstein.

From avant-garde statement pieces to delicate classics, celebrities, runway mavens and fashionistas alike are clamoring for costume jewelry. Mega moguls such Oprah Winfrey and Sienna Miller praise designer Lia Sophia, while singers like Beyonce are adorned in the latest Melody Ehsani pieces. With these jewels ranging from $16-$125, it’s only natural that celeb sitings would sound a fashion alarm. Hooray for a trend that is finally accessible to the masses!

For more examples of Arizaga’s work, see her blog.

Emerging leaders of the pack understand why working women, both on-screen and off, are flocking to this trend. Designer Amber Mims of the Washington D.C. line ‘2322,’ explains, “The phrase ‘costume jewelry’ implies dressing up, playing a character or taking a risk. I believe it’s meant for us to use as tool to learn something new about ourselves.”

Whether outfitting your alter ego or spicing up a corporate look, today’s hottest styles won’t be found in your mother’s jewelry box. Void of glue-gunned rhinestones, this new crop of eclectic jewelers, find inspiration in nature.

“The materials are recyclables; from bottle caps & wine corks to scrap fabric and door stoppers.” says Mims. Artist Bari Ziperstein creates rings and breastplate necklaces out of clay by “reusing extra bits of my sculptures.” All elements of her line, B. Zippy & Co, are handcrafted. “Nothing is store bought. They’re sculptural statements. It’s a constant balance of that interpretation … the bits and parts make up a larger narrative,” she says.

Made “for women with strong characters … who aren’t afraid to make a statement,” the Venessa Arizaga collection was inspired by the designer’s 2007 trip to Puerto Rico. She reveals, “(I) was inspired by the beauty of the beaches and the relaxed island culture, so I spontaneously started making jewelry from seashells and stones that I picked up. I started using mixed media to create my pieces. I wanted each one to have a different story.”

Working as a design director for Zac Posen at the time, she conceptualized humorous themes to bring her witty yet elegant line to life. “Accessories should be fun and should make the wearer feel happy. I believe our pieces do exactly that. We did a Junk Food collection, a Vices collection, and just recently we were inspired by tropical beaches all over the world.” Arizaga’s bracelets, starting at $55, are now sold by Nordstrom and favored by actresses Leighton Meester and Selena Gomez.

With costume becoming the new norm, what’s the secret to maintaining flawless baubles? Ritch Bich, a Los Angeles boutique carrying wallet friendly, pretty little things, has the answer. Its best-sellers include hot-to-trot earrings that fly off of the shelves at $14 and toprings (which sit between your knuckle and fingernail) for less than $20.

“People who haven’t bought costume or fashion jewelry in awhile might be surprised by the quality,” says co-owner Amorette Brooms. “This not Claire’s. We carry costume jewels for grown-ups. This is affordable merchandise, however, there are certain rules.”

To get the most wear out of your playful pieces, Brooms suggests steering clear of water, removing jewelry before applying lotion and perfume, and tucking away your goods once the party’s over. “The most important rule is to store your jewels in Ziploc bags. Air is what causes the oxidation or “turning” of metals,” she says.

item.title: 5 must-do-nows to avoid identity theft
item.dc:creator: Naomi Mannino
item.description: Three men distracted a Nordstrom cashier in Aventura, Fla., to case the cash register, according to news reports. Later, three different men again distracted cashiers, tampered with and installed “skimming” devices to six cash registers to intercept credit and debit card data. The devices were discovered by Nordstrom surveillance footage and removed before the thieves […]
item.content:encoded:
Three men distracted a Nordstrom cashier in Aventura, Fla., to case the cash register, according to news reports. Later, three different men again distracted cashiers, tampered with and installed “skimming” devices to six cash registers to intercept credit and debit card data. The devices were discovered by Nordstrom surveillance footage and removed before the thieves could recover the devices and use the stolen data to fraudulently clone credit cards.

That’s just one kind of identity fraud you could encounter while shopping this holiday season, says Miranda Perry of Scambook.com, a free scam complaint and resolution company.

The definition of identity fraud is any unauthorized use of personal information for financial gain such as making fraudulent purchases on a stolen credit card, taking control of existing accounts or opening new accounts, including mobile phone or utility services.

In honor of International Fraud Awareness Week, Nov. 3-9, we want help you be extra-vigilant this holiday season.

Identity fraud incidents in 2012 increased by more than 1 million victims and the dollar amount stolen increased to $21 billion, according to The Javelin Strategy & Research 2013 Identity Fraud Report. The report counts 12.6 million victims of identity fraud in the United States last year. That’s one victim every 3 seconds.

One bright spot: Because more than 50 percent of victims were actively detecting fraud using financial alerts, credit monitoring or identity protection services and by monitoring their own accounts, the amount of time financial information is being misused is growing shorter. In 2012, crooks had an average of 48 days to raid your accounts, down from 55 days in 2011.

While you have no control over what the scammers are doing to get at your personal information, you do have the steps you take to protect yourself from identity theft.

Sign up for credit monitoring

Many services you may already pay for  provide credit monitoring. Call your credit card companies and bank to find out what type of fraud detection they provide. If you are a member of AAA in Southern California, Texas, Hawaii, and New Mexico, make sure you sign up to receive free daily monitoring of your Experian credit report.

There are also companies you can pay to monitor your information, such as LifeLock, which pledges to spend up to $1 million to recover your stolen funds if you become a victim of identity theft. Plans range from $110-$275 a year.

Protect your passwords; shop securely

According to a 2012 CreditDonkey.com survey, more than three in 10 people share passwords with a friend and 68 percent of consumers use the same password for multiple websites. Don’t be a target; online burglars can do a lot of damage with one password. The Federal Trade Commission (FTC) advises never sharing your passwords with anyone and never using the same passwords for multiple websites, especially for email and bank accounts.

Be sure you are shopping securely before entering any payment, passwords or personal information, whether on a PC or on a mobile device such as a tablet or smartphone, especially when using typically unsecure public Wi-Fi at the airport or a coffee shop. According to Javelin, a secure connection is usually denoted by “https” (not just “http”) at the start of the merchant’s web address or a bright green box and padlock in the browser address bar.

“These can be faked and scammers are lurking on unsecure networks, so we advise limiting shopping and financial transactions to a secure network, such as your home network,” Perry says. In addition, she recommends turning off the automatic Wi-Fi connection setting on your smart phone so you are never unknowingly connected to an unsecure network.

Use credit instead of debit

Credit cards companies actively track fraudulent behavior on consumer accounts and limit liability for fraudulent purchases, while debit cards (which are dangerously connected directly to your bank account) typically do not, explains Perry. Alternatively, she says, you can purchase prepaid gift or credit card for each shopping trip and prevent thieves from accessing your financial information. Practicing this safe and secure payment option will also help you stay on budget.

Watch out for gift card scams

The holiday season is a huge time for gift card purchases, and gift card scammers, Perry says.

Never purchase gift cards from sellers on websites such as craigslist or Ebay. Buy them from authorized retailers or large, reputable websites that are well-known, Perry says. “In-store, be sure to inspect packaging, and if the bar code or any part of the packaging or card is bent it could have been tampered with by scammers.”

Create a smart phone password

A lot of identity theft still happens the old fashioned way: Theft of personal items such as backpacks, purses and wallets containing your account numbers, credit cards and smart phone.

The Federal Communications Commission (FCC) reports that mobile security threats have increased more than 350 percent since 2010. Perry stresses that everyone should password-protect his or her cell phone in case of theft to avoid illicit access to any of your stored personal information including passwords, birth date, addresses, social security number, account numbers and card numbers thieves use to commit identity fraud. If you have a smart phone, there is a setting that will allow you to create a password to access your phone.

Save yourself from identity theft and install a password on your phone right now. According to a 2013 Consumer Reports survey, 61 percent of adult smartphone users have not!

Bonus tip: Make Xerox copies of your debit and credit cards — front and back. That way if your wallet is stolen, you still have the account numbers and customer service phone numbers to call tucked away in a safe place.

item.title: Take the cheap-eats challenge
item.dc:creator: Sandra Gordon
item.description: Could you prepare dinner for a family of four for $10 or less? Chef Alicia McCabe, director of Share Our Strength’s Cooking Matters Massachusetts, teaches shoppers how to do just that with a field trip to a grocery store. The goal of Share Our Strength is to end childhood hunger by helping low-income families across […]
item.content:encoded:
Could you prepare dinner for a family of four for $10 or less? Chef Alicia McCabe, director of Share Our Strength’s Cooking Matters Massachusetts, teaches shoppers how to do just that with a field trip to a grocery store.

The goal of Share Our Strength is to end childhood hunger by helping low-income families across the country learn how to buy and prepare healthy and delicious low-cost meals. The benchmark of each dinner is to provide food for a family of four for $10 or less, using ingredients from at least three food groups. To accomplish its goal, it offers a program to adults and children called Cooking Matters that includes a grocery shopping tour.

During a recent trip to the store, McCabe shared some money-saving and food-shopping tips, which can help anyone spend less at the grocery store and pick up more nutritious items. If you’re already a pro at cutting back the grocery bill, these tips serve as good reminders.

  • Cheaper isn’t always better: In the produce aisle, a one-pound bag of organic carrots was cheaper than the same-size bag of regular carrots based on the unit prices; that’s not usually the case. Organic is typically more expensive than non-organic items. To get the best deal, zero in on the unit price. Baby carrots, which are regular carrots that have been milled and cut, cost the most, according to the unit pricing. Still, baby carrots are a nutritious snack. “They’re not a bad deal if that’s what your kids will eat,” McCabe says. “Buy what works for your family.”
  • Color matters: For the most nutrition per your produce dollars, get the deepest colored vegetables you can find. Choose romaine lettuce or red leaf lettuce over iceberg. That’s a general rule. There’s still a place for iceberg, on BLT’s, for example. Just don’t make it your go-to lettuce.
  • Fresh isn’t always better. Frozen green beans, for example, can be cheaper than the fresh varieties. But it depends on the season, so watch the unit prices to know when to buy fresh versus frozen and vice versa.
  • A frozen food bonus: If you’ve got picky eaters, it’s easy to personalize a meal with frozen food. You could serve green beans to one child and corn to another by scooping up one serving from the freezer.
  • Load up on produce: According to ChooseMyPlate.gov, half of your plate should be made up of fruits and veggies and are cheaper than meat. Produce is packed with vitamins, minerals, fiber, disease-fighting antioxidants and phytochemicals. Consider it an investment in everyone’s health future.
  • Buy products in larger-sized packages. While strolling down the dairy section, McCabe says to not be limited by products. Instead of buying blueberry yogurt, for example, cut costs by purchasing a large container of plain yogurt and mixing in fresh or frozen blueberries. Use the rest of the yogurt in smoothies, as a topper for baked potatoes and in baked goods in place of sour cream, she says.
  • Learn more about the products: McCabe points out that because of the popularity of Greek yogurt these days, it tends to be more expensive then plain yogurt. Greek yogurt is just regular yogurt that has been strained. This process concentrates the protein, which is why Greek yogurt typically offers more protein than regular yogurt, McCabe says. But some of the calcium and vitamin A escapes in the process. To save money, and for a protein punch with the calcium and vitamin A of regular yogurt, she suggests buying regular yogurt (at the lowest unit price) and adding your own nuts, such as pistachios, almonds, walnuts or cashews.
  • Experiment with store brands. McCabe says to give store brands a try. In general, a supermarket’s store brand product is cheaper than a name-brand product even when paired with a coupon. Still, be picky. If the store-brand cereal, mayonnaise or ketchup (three products that garner the most name-brand loyalty) don’t measure up to the name brand, splurge on the name brand, preferably when it is on sale and with a coupon.
  • Don’t buy the “lite” version. In the juice aisle, “lite” is code for “water.” Why pay a premium for a watery product when you can add water to the product yourself and pay less for it?

Don’t forget to plan a weekly menu. A game plan for food budgeting doesn’t have to be elaborate. For ideas on cheap eats you can whip up in your own kitchen, check out CookingMatters.org. Cooking Matters also has a free recipe app that has all of its chef-developed, healthy and affordable recipes. The app is available on iTunes and Google Play.

item.title: 6 secrets to eating healthy on a budget
item.dc:creator: Julie Bawden-Davis
item.description: You know the importance of feeding yourself and your family good-for-you foods, but noshing on meals and snacks made from ingredients such as free-range chicken, organic produce and whole grains can be a budget-buster. With a little planning and creativity, though, you can serve healthy meals without straining your budget. 1. Get organized “It’s entirely […]
item.content:encoded:
You know the importance of feeding yourself and your family good-for-you foods, but noshing on meals and snacks made from ingredients such as free-range chicken, organic produce and whole grains can be a budget-buster. With a little planning and creativity, though, you can serve healthy meals without straining your budget.

1. Get organized

“It’s entirely possible to eat healthy on a budget, if you stay organized and map out your meals,” says Susan G. Weiner, a registered dietitian-nutritionist in private practice in Long Island, NY, and author of “The Complete Diabetes Organizer.”

“Keep a running inventory of items in your refrigerator, freezer and pantry, so you don’t waste food. And avoid buying excess, because even canned goods expire,” she says. “When you do freeze something or store it in the refrigerator, make sure that you label it (with a date), or you’ll end up wasting a lot of money by eventually throwing it out.”

Weiner also suggests creating a meal plan each week based on what you already have in your kitchen and any healthy food items that are on sale at your local grocery store.

“If broccoli and chicken breasts are on special, plan one or more meals using those food items, and include the tomato sauce you have in the pantry,” she says.

2. Use meat as a condiment

Offset the high cost of free-range and grass-fed cuts of meat by serving them in limited quantities. For instance, use a whole organic chicken to make chicken broth, stir-fry and a pasta dish. A hormone-free beef roast can be used to make a stew, casserole and shepherd’s pie.

When you do buy meat as the main course, make it affordable by following the advice of nutrition experts and purchasing small, lean cuts.

3. Highlight cheap protein

A wide variety of inexpensive protein sources besides meats can be used to create healthy meals for just pennies a serving. Build meals around foods such as beans, lentils and legumes, tofu and high-protein grains such as quinoa, which is a complete protein. An internet search for recipes involving these foods will produce many tasty options.

4. Choose generic and store brands

Foods don’t need a high-profile brand name to be wholesome and nutritious. Generic and store brand versions of products such as rice, pasta, grains, yogurt, cottage cheese, beans and cheese cost 30 to 50 percent less on average.

5. Try slow cooking

Cooking with a Crock-Pot can save you money in more ways than one. The long process of slow cooking tenderizes less expensive, tough cuts of meat, such as chuck steak or roasts, beef brisket and pork shoulder. Combine a low-price piece of meat with inexpensive root veggies such as potatoes, carrots and onions or rice, and you can serve up mouthwatering meals for very little money. A slow cooker also uses less energy to power than an oven or stovetop, saving on your utility bill as well.

6. Grow your own fruits and vegetables

Growing and harvesting your own produce can save a substantial amount of money. According to the National Gardening Association, gardens produce an average of half a pound of vegetables per square foot of garden space, and established fruit trees can produce 50 pounds of fruit in one season.

When you harvest an excess of produce or find fruit and veggies on sale in the market, use every means possible to preserve them. Good options include drying, freezing and canning. Some vegetables and fruits, such as tomatoes, peaches and plums, can also be blanched and frozen for future use.

Eating healthy on a budget does take some planning, but the results of dining on good-for-you foods and saving money in the process is worth the effort.

item.title: To get a better deal, just ask
item.dc:creator: Sandra Gordon
item.description: “Is that best price you can offer me?” Have you ever tried this bargaining tactic outside of a car dealership? Major retailers, such as The Home Depot, might be able to offer you a price lower than the advertised price. When you shop online or scan your newspaper circular for sales, you’ll notice that many […]
item.content:encoded:
“Is that best price you can offer me?” Have you ever tried this bargaining tactic outside of a car dealership? Major retailers, such as The Home Depot, might be able to offer you a price lower than the advertised price.

When you shop online or scan your newspaper circular for sales, you’ll notice that many products, such as a 50” Sony TV, for example, are the same price no matter where they’re sold. That’s Minimum Advertised Price, or MAP, at work.

The Federal Trade Commission oversees the legality of MAP policies. MAP is an agreement between suppliers and retailers stipulating the lowest price a product can be advertised at, whether it is on a billboard, a website or a magazine ad. Retailers can incur sizeable fines and/or penalties from their suppliers for violating a MAP contract. Suppliers might also cease doing business with MAP violators. MAP policies can also stipulate how a product is sold. If a manufacturer wants to only do business with small, local retailers, for example, a retailer who advertises the manufacturer’s product to consumers on Amazon.com would be violating the manufacturer’s MAP policy.

But MAP sets the advertised price. If you go into a store, you could buy something below MAP by simply asking for a better deal.

“Retailers can’t advertise a price to the public that’s below MAP,” says Joe Marrapodi. He is the CEO and co-founder of Greentoe.com, a site that allows consumers to negotiate with retailers online instead of haggling face to face on the prices of products in five categories: baby products, photography, home theater, appliances and music. MAP protects manufacturers and restricts retailers from undercutting the competition to register higher sales. It also allows manufacturers to control, to some extent, how retailers handle their products. However, retailers are allowed to sell products below MAP.

“They have the flexibility of going lower than MAP if they’re dealing one on one,” Marrapodi says. That’s why it pays to ask if there’s any room in the deal. In other words, the price you pay for a product can go below the MAP-required advertised price without anybody getting in trouble.

Sidestepping MAP

In addition to direct negotiations, there are other ways retailers can give you a better deal without violating MAP policies with their suppliers. According to the U.S. Small Business Administration, online retailers might offer free shipping or coupon codes. Although both maneuvers affect the price of the product, neither reduces the advertised dollar value of the MAP-protected product.

How much of a price reduction should you try to get? MAP policies can differ among retailers and suppliers. One strategy is to pick a major retailer, such as Amazon, and print out the price its advertising for the product you want. Take that print out to a local business to see if it will match Amazon’s advertised price. That’s a tactic Marrapodi used to buy a new refrigerator at The Home Depot, which shaved about 20 percent off the price.

Even major retailers you’d never think would be willing to negotiate, such as Nordstrom, have pricing wiggle room, especially if you’re buying more than one item, Marrapodi says. All it takes is the courage to ask for a better price.

It’s interesting to know that MAP is an undercurrent in the retail world, isn’t it? Aside from garage sales, where haggling is expected, have you ever tried asking for a better price at a retail store? What was your experience? Let us know in the comments below.

item.title: 10 ways to shop smart for fall
item.dc:creator: Chie Davis
item.description: Dressing the part doesn’t always have to equate to having deep pockets like Daddy Warbucks. A savvy shopper knows how to look the part for less. With fall in full swing and the holidays knocking, Pennywyse asked style experts to weigh in on shopping smarter. Rule No. 1 Pump your breaks before hitting the retail […]
item.content:encoded:
Dressing the part doesn’t always have to equate to having deep pockets like Daddy Warbucks. A savvy shopper knows how to look the part for less. With fall in full swing and the holidays knocking, Pennywyse asked style experts to weigh in on shopping smarter.

Rule No. 1
Pump your breaks before hitting the retail circuit. Before convincing yourself that you have nothing to wear, access your wardrobe. “Do a closet edit first and see what’s missing from your wardrobe,” says Dana Goldberg, wardrobe stylist for Louis Vuitton and Bravo. Taking an inventory will help you determine what to keep, donate or repurpose.

Rule No. 2
Invest in staples. Opt for pieces that can transition through multiple seasons. Make a list of your personal must-haves. Bruno Lima, stylist to comedienne Amy Sedaris, tells shoppers to: “Spend money on a good new pair of shoes. They will last forever and everyone will notice!” Rebecca Brie, who helps many stars glam up for the Grammys adds, “Be sure to have a classic white button up shirt and lightweight scarves in bold prints.”

Rule No. 3
Take advantage of online sales and coupons. Lucky Smyler, a makeup artist for stars such as ABC’s ”Scandal“ star Kerry Washington, won’t buy a product unless he’s searched online for the coupon code. “Check the sale icon. You can find high quality stuff for less than half price. I recently got Stila eye shadow kits, which retail at $45, for $6!”

Rule No. 4
Look beyond the women’s department. British singer-songwriter and actress Rita Ora’s stylist, Jason Rembert, challenges women to lift the veil. “Venture to men’s and find things that work. Belt it, have fun with it! Find a tailor or young designer in your neighborhood. Get the look you want for $200 as opposed to $1,000.”

Rule No. 5
Don’t be afraid to try before you buy. Smyler encourages women to even try on makeup before making a large purchase. “Write everything down and tell them that you need to wear it for the day,” he says. “Get the sales associate’s name and come back. You don’t know how your face may react or oxidize.”

Rule No. 6
Splurge on fall accessories. Lima says they’re “…the cheapest way to update your look. Don’t invest a huge amount on an item that has a seasonal color and will soon be dated.” Rembert suggests surfing discount retailers. “Buy a $10 pashmina scarf on the street. On-trend tribal jewelry can be stacked from Forever 21.”

Rule No. 7
Scope out the sales associates. “I started in retail before I became a celebrity makeup artist,” Smyler says. “Always observe the way the salesperson does her makeup. If it looks questionable, don’t ask for advice.”

Rule No. 8
Search for helpful apps. Brie, who posts fashion trends on her Tumblr blog, is very tech-savvy. “I’m a big fan of Poshmark, an iPhone app that allows women to shop (for) and sell interesting pieces. It’s sort of like eBay, but way cooler because it’s strictly women’s clothes and a community of some really fashionable women,” she says. “If you love a certain brand, register with their site so that you can receive alerts about all of their sales before the public.”

Rule No. 9
Don’t be a billboard. Goldberg warns to stay away from a trend if it doesn’t suit your body type. “You can wear comfortable, timeless pieces, and stay on trend, if you accessorize well. I love the embellished booties from Chloe last season, but Shutz has a great pair at a much lower price point. Throw on a cute leather bag across the shoulder and a fun fall hat and you’re good to go.”

Rule No. 10
Recreate new pieces from your closet. “Pants with holes? Take them to the dry-cleaners. Patch them up and make them your own,” Rembert says.

item.title: Time equals money when it comes to holiday flights
item.dc:creator: Naomi Mannino
item.description: Traveling over the holidays this year? Then you need to know the best way to get the best deal possible on your airfare. Some say the best time to purchase a ticket is 6 weeks before your trip, others say 21 days before your departure and some suggest you should travel on the holiday itself […]
item.content:encoded:
Traveling over the holidays this year? Then you need to know the best way to get the best deal possible on your airfare.

Some say the best time to purchase a ticket is 6 weeks before your trip, others say 21 days before your departure and some suggest you should travel on the holiday itself to save money. So, which is it?

Timing is everything

“There is actually no magic time or date to book holiday airfares because they now change so rapidly and so often,” says George Hobica, founder of airfarewatchdog.com. The website is an expert source of airline deals and the information is researched and verified by a team of airfare industry insiders. “Fares can change daily, weekly and monthly. That’s because the number of seats available in the lowest fare class fluctuates as consumers give up held but (not purchased) seats or because the airlines adjust the number of seats available in the lowest fare class.”

Hobica recommends you sign up for airfare search alerts as soon as you know your exact travel dates. You can elect to have alerts emailed to your inbox on a daily or weekly basis or when a flight reaches a drops below a certain price.

Even better, Hobica advises using the flexible date option whenever possible on airline or flight search websites, such as Kayak or Orbitz. If you don’t have to travel on specific dates, this tool takes into account cheaper fares on days before and after your planned travel dates and sometimes even on the holiday itself, which can result in sizable savings.

“Set up alerts as soon as possible. Then search several sites, in different ways, many times a day until that lower fare choice pops out at you. Then book it fast.” Hobica advises.

You might also try searching for two one-way tickets, either from the same airline or one airline for departure and a different airline for return to see which is cheapest. You can also check with the Bing airfare price predictor, which tracks past fares to see if you should buy now or wait for a better price.

Watch out for add-on fees

In an effort to reduce ticket prices and remain competitive, many airlines have switched to an à la carte menu of fees. Every service outside the seat fare has a specific price, such as baggage fees, extra room fees, early boarding fees as well as change flight fees, among many others. Budget airlines, such as Frontier, even charge drink fees for any option except water.

When you are considering which airline or type of ticket to book, be aware that airline luggage fees for checked bags and sometimes even carry-on fees are tacked on to the ticket prices and must be accounted for in your travel budget.

One of the most extreme examples of this is Spirit Air. While the airfare may seem inexpensive, know that Spirit charges $25 to $100 for a carry-on bag and another $20 to $100 depending on whether you list the bag during the booking process or show up with it at the gate, which could add a substantial amount to your total ticket price, especially if your are traveling with family members.

Some airlines, such as American Airlines, recently announced a new pricing structure that offers bundled packages for fees. For $68, you can check one bag each way and have the option to change your travel dates without a change fee. Hobica says changing your travel dates can cost $100 or more, plus the difference in fares.

“It can be more consumer-friendly with the fee bundle if you would (normally) pay $50 to check your bag anyway and if you often run in to the problem of changing your tickets. Then you can really save some money for only $18 more,” Hobica says.

But if you stick to your travel plans and pack light, no fees is the way to go with airlines such as JetBlue or Southwest, if the airfare is right.

item.title: Gear up for a new baby now
item.dc:creator: Sandra Gordon
item.description: If you’re gearing up for a new baby, now is a great time to get in on some of the best deals of the year. Baby gear is big business in the U.S., generating $6 billion in online sales alone, according to IBIS World, a leading market research firm. The annual All Baby & Kids […]
item.content:encoded:
If you’re gearing up for a new baby, now is a great time to get in on some of the best deals of the year.

Baby gear is big business in the U.S., generating $6 billion in online sales alone, according to IBIS World, a leading market research firm. The annual All Baby & Kids trade show for the baby products industry just wrapped up earlier this month at the Las Vegas Convention Center. It drew more than 10,000 attendees from 66 countries. Nearly 3,000 booths displayed baby gear and products, from strollers, high chairs and car seats, to cribs, play yards and bottles, and everything in between.

Retailers and e-tailers will be clearing out current inventory to make room for the 2014 products, which start arriving in stores and debuting on websites between November and January. What does that mean for you, the consumer? Sales!

Watch for baby products to go on sale before and after the holidays. Check your local newspaper circulars and sign up to receive newsletters and discounts from your favorite baby-gear stores on their websites. Check the baby gear sales sections of websites such as Amazon, then compare that price with other prices you can find on the web. “Like” favorite brands and retailers on Facebook, follow them on Twitter and sign up for a manufacturer’s newsletter or online club for parents, too — three more ways to get insider info.

Chicco (pronounced kee-ko), an Italian manufacturer of stylish and high-quality car seats, strollers and other children’s products, offers the Chicco Club on its corporate website. Members who join the club by signing up with an e-mail address can take advantage of contests, giveaways and special promotions on Chicco products, such as receiving a free Chicco KeyFit car seat base when you purchase a Chicco Cortina travel system, or receiving an extra Playard mattress when you purchase a Chicco Lullaby Playard between specified dates.

With the good deals offered this time of year, you might be buying last year’s model. But some baby products, such as strollers, don’t change that much from one year to the next except for a refresh on the “fashions,” which is baby-gear lingo for fabrics and colors. Last year’s colors will seem new to you anyway if you are a new parent, unless you happen to be a repeat customer.

Manufacturers often offer multiple ways to save. To give you an idea on the amount you can save, check out the relatively new Chicco shopping website.

At the All Baby & Kids show, representatives said the site was the place to go for replacement stroller parts, not good deals. But with a little bit of time spent on the site, you can find the Cortina Keyfit30 Travel System, a stroller and an infant car seat that attach, for $329.99 — the same price it’s listed for on Amazon. But upon paying for products on Chiccoshop.com, it offers $100 off the retail price. And if you sign up with your e-mail address, you’ll receive free shipping if you spend at least $50.

Clearly, Chicco is trying to (quietly) move its Cortina Keyfit30 Travel System and other 2013 products — and slashing $100 off the purchase price is certainly a way to do it, don’t you agree?

So get in on the baby gear sales bonanza by keeping your eyes peeled for great deals like these between now and early January.

item.title: You may be spending more, bagging less
item.dc:creator: Naomi Mannino
item.description: Whether its hamburger buns, a pair of boots or an HDTV, do you have a price in mind when you set out for a shopping trip? Recent research found that most people do, even though you should look at more than just the price to get the best deal for your money. Retailers know you […]
item.content:encoded:
Whether its hamburger buns, a pair of boots or an HDTV, do you have a price in mind when you set out for a shopping trip? Recent research found that most people do, even though you should look at more than just the price to get the best deal for your money.

Retailers know you are focused on the price and try to entice you into the store with appealing advertisements. Many shoppers remain price-fixated and end up spending more instead of comparative shopping while inside the store.

The science of price fixation

Two marketing professors from Brigham Young University and Emory University tested this theory and reported their results in 2012 in Journal of Marketing Research.

They used different types of products, including televisions, pens, laptops, ear buds, garage doors, mattresses, Blu-ray players and luggage. They asked consumers taking part in the study to approach the price in different ways, such as naming a target price, naming a maximum price, choosing a price from a set of choices or determining a budget for a specific purchase.

The result was always the same no matter which product was being considered for purchase. No matter how consumers determined a price, they spent up to 50 percent more when they started shopping with a price in mind than those who didn’t.

“After we screen our choices based on price, we essentially ignore price after that and focus on quality, noticing all the higher-quality choices,” explains the study’s co-author Jeffrey Larson, assistant professor of marketing at BYU’s Marriott School of Management, in his research. “Better quality products usually cost more, enticing us to spend more.”

Pay attention to features, quality and size

When setting a price limit for an item, you have essentially ignored all the possibly lower-priced options that have all of the features and benefits you wanted.

Not only are you probably paying more by focusing solely on the price, but what’s more surprising is you may not looking as carefully at what you are buying because your price was satisfied, says Britt Beemer, who conducted a survey about price satisfaction in the 2011 Consumer Track Back-To-School Shopping Survey.

The study found that more than half of people shopping base their decision solely on price and don’t notice how an item is made.”

You can miss out on even more than quality, too, says James Dion, president of Dionco, a Chicago-based retail consulting firm. “Even with smaller-ticket items, such as food packages, footwear, apparel and household goods, you may overlook a smaller item or package size, a set with fewer items and low-quality ingredients or cheaply-made goods at that lower acceptable price-point you have pre-determined.”

Compare prices last

  • Focus on features and quality first, especially for big-ticket items such as TVs and smartphones, and then focus on the price of products that has the qualities you want.
  • Pay attention to how many pieces are part of each product before focusing on the price to be sure you are getting what you need and how much you are willing to pay. For example: Does the bed set include a skirt with the bedding? How many buns are in that bag of hot dog buns for the cheapest price versus the price you are willing to pay? Count and check before you buy.
  • Look carefully at the quality of an item, especially for footwear and apparel. Notice how attachments are affixed to the product, the tightness of the stitching, the quality of fabrication and number of embellishments before focusing on the price.

This smarter way of shopping will get you exactly what you need and want at a price that just might be less than you had in mind.

item.title: 7 danger zones where expensive home repairs lurk
item.dc:creator: Julie Bawden-Davis
item.description: Your home is your castle; that safe haven where you can pull up the drawbridge, relax with family and friends and take a break from the outside world. But did you know that your retreat may also harbor costly and even dangerous trouble? Ignoring or failing to notice warning signs, such as leaning trees or […]
item.content:encoded:
Your home is your castle; that safe haven where you can pull up the drawbridge, relax with family and friends and take a break from the outside world. But did you know that your retreat may also harbor costly and even dangerous trouble?

Ignoring or failing to notice warning signs, such as leaning trees or a clogged dryer vent, can lead to injuries and expensive repair bills.

Save money, preserve the health of your home and set your mind at ease by checking the following danger zones on a regular basis.

1. Roof

As your home’s first line of defense against the outdoor elements, your roof gets hit hard, and the slightest problem can quickly become a costly disaster.

Visually inspect your roof at the change of every season, checking for loose, broken or missing roof tiles or shingles, which should be replaced as soon as possible. Also, clear your gutters of leaves and debris so that they can flow freely. Make sure that the downspouts emit water away from the foundation.

2. HVAC System

Replacing the filter on your heating and cooling system is an easy preventative measure that can save you thousands of dollars in costly repairs and prevent potentially deadly fires. If a filter becomes clogged with dust and debris, the system works harder and less effectively, potentially burning out the engine. In rare instances, the heating system can catch on fire.

3. Landscape

Plants surrounding your home that are unstable, such as trees and large bushes, create various hazards. Unsteady vegetation or loose limbs can fall on your roof or siding, and plants with an invasive root system can damage the foundation. Stabilize or remove any vegetation that is unsteady or invasive. Also have trees trimmed by 15 to 20 percent in the fall, so that wind flows through them.

4. Laundry room

Malfunctioning of your dryer can result in costly repairs, and some dryer accidents can be life threatening. According to the U.S. Fire Administration, roughly 2,900 clothes dryer fires are reported in residences every year, resulting in about five deaths, 100 injuries and $35 million in property loss. The leading reason for the fires is failure to clean out the vents. Lingering dust, lint and fiber can ignite. Remove lint from the dryer’s trap after every load and keep the area behind the dryer clean. Also ensure that the vent is unobstructed and air flows freely to the outside.

5. Kitchen

Kitchen fires are the number one cause of home fires, the U.S. Fire Administration reports. In 2010, the National Fire Protection Association found that 156,400 homes were damaged as a result of a kitchen fire. The fires resulted in 420 deaths, 5,310 injuries and $993 million in damages. Never leave the kitchen when something is cooking on the stove, and ensure that your appliances and equipment are functioning properly.

6. Fireplace

Before you light a fire, ensure that your chimney’s flue works properly and that the interior of the chimney does not have a build-up of creosote, which is a brown or black substance that is highly flammable. Prevent problems by having the chimney swept yearly by a professional.

7. Wiring

Bad wiring can affect any area of the home. Wires can short out and start a fire. Signs that you may have trouble include flickering lights, frequent blown fuses and feeling a tingling or slight shock when you touch an appliance or wall switch. If you suspect a problem, call in a certified electrician as soon as possible.
Now that you know how to protect your loved ones and your home from potential danger, rest assured in your safe haven.

item.title: Two looks, three ways
item.dc:creator: Chie Davis
item.description: Whether the look is vintage, vamp or vixen, the trending word this fall is repurpose. Once you’ve splurged on a costly item, create a multi-layered style story to give your purchase wings. Inspired by the signature hue of the season — green — here are tips on how to flip your newest stunner into three […]
item.content:encoded:
Whether the look is vintage, vamp or vixen, the trending word this fall is repurpose.

Once you’ve splurged on a costly item, create a multi-layered style story to give your purchase wings. Inspired by the signature hue of the season — green — here are tips on how to flip your newest stunner into three different outfits.

Fashionistas pledge allegiance to one rule: splurge responsibly. Select a classic piece that can be reused and even withstand multiple Facebook appearances without being bombed by the style police. Stellar forest green buys include: a motorcycle jacket, cable knit sweater, faux fur vest, an A-line skirt and leather booties. By boldly pairing your new James Dean moto jacket with low-key accessorizes and pre-existing closet staples, you can continuously rock out without maxing it out.

Celebrities such as Jessica Simpson and Khloe Kardashian support the guilt-free faux fur trend. Kardashian even confessed to fans on her website, “This season, faux fur takes on new life in everything from collars, to vests, to ear muffs … and I’m loving all of it!”

First look

If you’re working your way up to Kardashian bracket ‘kash,’ Los Angeles stylist, Rebecca Brie, has three economical solutions. The wardrobe wiz, who recently styled a Cover Girl campaign featuring real women, favors clean silhouettes over ill-fitting layers. She suggests pairing an emerald faux fur vest “with a fitted turtleneck or blouse. Add in leather leggings. They’re a must have item, especially for a more dressed up look.” Brie suggests checking out Zara or Top Shop for inexpensive leggings, or Rag and Bone or J-Brand for longer-lasting products. “Throw on some short leather ankle boots” and you’re golden.

To celebrate your second fur iteration, embrace your inner flirt. Brie pairs the vest with a “short skirt or dress, with high heel ankle boots.” Depending on the occasion, you can also jazz up the look by synching your waist with a thin animal print belt to accentuate your figure. “You can never have too much animal print in your closet. I’m always looking for cool pieces with leopard, zebra or cheetah prints. It makes a statement and provides a twist to any outfit. I like to say ‘animal print is the new black’ because it goes with everything.” Whip out the faux fur on a Sunday for your last look. “I like to wear mine on a casual day with flats, skinny jeans, and a T-shirt,” she says.

Second look

Versatile styling translates well in bold staples and classics. Couture designer, Christian Dior, initially revealed A-line skirts in 1955. Sewn to hug one’s hips with a sharp flare at the knee, they’ve remained in high rotation ever since. Jason Rembert, the stylist behind captivating looks seen on it-girls like Olivia Palermo and Selita Eubanks, favors the skirt.

To produce three looks, he suggests that women, “do an emerald A-line skirt and wear it to work with a grey sweater or sweatshirt. Belt it and give it a waistline, with a button-up shirt underneath. Add a statement necklace.” To transition to cocktails at night, “take off the button-up and sweater and throw on a silk shirt, with a black fancier belt. That can be a dressier look. Leave the top button unbuttoned and add a simple, personal necklace, perhaps something gifted by a boyfriend or your mother.” Add a “hand full of rings,” to cap it off. You can also channel your inner vixen by toting the A-line along for a weekend getaway. “Pair it with a crop top and sneakers in Miami. Add in some busy earrings,” a la J-Lo, he says.

item.title: Turn your home into a house of haunts for Halloween
item.dc:creator: Chie Davis
item.description: If you’re planning a spine-tingling Halloween affair or hosting a group of eager trick-o-treaters, there’s no reason to put a dent in your budget. Turn your abode into a house of haunts by making it a family affair. Gather your spouse and/or kids to transform average household items into festive decor. First, prepare a craft […]
item.content:encoded:
Photo courtesy of Le living and co


If you’re planning a spine-tingling Halloween affair or hosting a group of eager trick-o-treaters, there’s no reason to put a dent in your budget. Turn your abode into a house of haunts by making it a family affair. Gather your spouse and/or kids to transform average household items into festive decor.

First, prepare a craft area. Cover your dining room table with fabric or butcher paper. Secure the table’s edges with tape or safety pins. Lay an equally impenetrable layer on the floor. Whip out the paint and allow your kids to get splatter paint crazy. Encourage them to create their most ghoulish designs by using white sheets and towels as a canvas. Drape their dried work over furniture or use as decorative pillow covers. You can also create the effect of bloody walls by dipping your hands in red paint and stamping them on white butcher paper. Affix the ghastly designs to the walls of your hallway and line them with colorful, electric candles, varying in height.

Once crafting time has finished, convert the table (splatter paint and all) into a festive art space in preparation of guests. During the soiree, provide your guests with an activity. Provide cheap plastic masks found at any arts store and room to adorn the masks with decorations. Whether it be glitter, buttons from your sewing kit, feathers from a shedding boa or costume jewelry, rummage through your closet to make an offering for the sake of the spook.

No Halloween party would be complete without pumpkins. Put a twist on tradition by using metallic spray paint to spruce up the fruit for its big day. Lay down newspaper in a well-ventilated space. Hold your pumpkin by the stem and spray paint it silver, yellow or rose gold. String name cards from the stems of mini metallic pumpkins to act as placeholders at the dinner table. They also make dynamic party favors.

Harvest a few branches from a tree on your lawn. Leaves can also be spray painted and hung from black gauze curtains to enhance your house of haunts. Don’t be afraid to pluck the feathers from that trusty black boa to create a front door wreath. Boas can also double as staircase wraps.

Entice your visitors with all things creepy crawly by strategically hanging homemade spiders and bats throughout the space. The bodies of the warm-blooded animals can be crafted by stuffing newspaper into black hosiery. Bat ears can be made out of construction paper. Wings and spider legs can be fashioned out of old umbrellas. Your handcrafted, eight-legged wonder can rest comfortably in a web made by strumming yarn from the corners of vacant picture frames. Place them in corners to ante up the fear factor.

Once you and your family are fully costumed, nothing says supernatural-like ‘shrunken heads.’ Apples and pears can be peeled and carved to resemble human faces. Dunk them in a bath of lemon juice and salt for 30 minutes. After drying the fruit overnight, pump up the terror by strategically placing the ‘shrunken heads’ on mantles or even in the bathroom. Placement should depend on how creepy you want the vibe to be.

With screams expected, wet the partygoer’s palettes with ‘witches brew.’ Served from a black cauldron, aka the largest pot in your kitchen, mix a concoction of berries, ginger ale, gelatin and cider with a block of dry ice, which will emit a smoky fog.

To ensure that all are properly spooked, play scary music and horror films in the background. Dust off your Polaroid camera. Email a collage of the snapshots to guests the next day in remembrance of the moment.

For more home decorating tips during the fall, find out how to be how to be chic on the cheap.

item.title: Virgin coconut oil: 11 ways to eat it and wear it
item.dc:creator: Naomi Mannino
item.description: Would you pay $9 for a product that is as beneficial for the outside of your body as it is for the inside of your body? One item can be used as a body moisturizer, lip balm, hair mask and cuticle conditioner. This same product is also a food and is consumed raw, cooked and […]
item.content:encoded:
Would you pay $9 for a product that is as beneficial for the outside of your body as it is for the inside of your body? One item can be used as a body moisturizer, lip balm, hair mask and cuticle conditioner. This same product is also a food and is consumed raw, cooked and baked.

Have you heard of virgin coconut oil or VCO? It is natural, versatile, affordable and readily available. (Warning: Do not want to use coconut oil if you are allergic to nuts or coconuts.)

Use in your food

VCO has been used for generations in the Philippines. A 2011 study conducted by The University of San Carlos Office of Population Studies Foundation in Cebu City, Philippines, tested coconut oil’s affect on cholesterol levels and the risk for cardiac disease. Nearly 2,000 pre-menopausal women were part of the study.

Coconut oil intake was measured by asking the women to recall their coconut oil use over two 24-hour periods and, on average, women reported use of just a little more than 2 teaspoons of coconut oil each day. Coconut oil intake was found to be higher in younger women living in wealthier households in more urban areas with more education.

The study, which was funded by the U.S. National Institutes of Health and published in a 2011 issue of the Asia Pacific Journal of Clinical Nutrition, found that ingesting coconut oil resulted in a positive blood lipid profile especially the increase in high-density lipoprotein levels (HDL, the “good” cholesterol).

“Despite its classification as a saturated fat, its biochemical makeup and smaller molecular size is such that the body metabolizes VCO in a healthier way than other saturated fats,” says Cherie Calbom, nutritionist and author of “The Coconut Diet.”

Use coconut oil to add more of the healthy fat and decrease the unhealthy saturated fats in your diet:

  • Add a couple of tablespoons to any smoothie.
  • Substitute VCO for half the amount of butter called for in any baked goods recipe for muffins, fruit breads or cookies.
  • Sauté vegetables or even cook pancakes in VCO instead of butter or vegetable or corn oil.

Use on your body

“Because VCO is highly absorbed by the skin it’s an effective moisturizer and softener, says dermatological nurse-practitioner Jodi LoGerfo of the Orentreich Medical Group in New York City. “Used at room temperature (in its solid state) it makes an ideal ointment to relieve dehydrated, chapped, rough, scaly and itchy skin.”

LoGerfo also says VCO may improve skin barrier function to protect skin from fungus and bacteria intrusion and improve skin’s ability to retain moisture. In animal studies, coconut oil has even been shown to improve the time it takes for wounds to heal and increase collagen production.

Use VCO as liquid oil or a solid moisturizer, on wet or dry skin in the following ways:

  • An all-over body moisturizer
  • Bath oil
  • Lip balm
  • Cuticle conditioner
  • Massage oil

Apply sparingly as a little goes a long way. Because coconut oil can be greasy, wait a few minutes before getting dressed.

Use for your hair

LoGerfo explains that in addition to its high absorbability, VCO contains lauric acid, which has a high attraction for hair protein. “Any way you use it on hair, VCO has been recognized for having a positive benefit on the tensile strength and properties of hair as it also moisturizes hair and coats hair’s outer cuticle, preventing hair damage and protein loss from combing, brushing and chemical treatments,” she says. Try:

  • A scalp massage
  • A pre-wash scalp treatment, to help or eliminate dandruff
  • A deep conditioning treatment from the roots to tips

Always use VCO on your hair and scalp are dry; otherwise water stops the oil from penetrating the hair effectively. To remove VCO from your hair, do not wash it out the usual way. Instead, lather shampoo in your hands first, apply directly to your hair and scalp, then rinse thoroughly.

Where can you find it?

“Always buy virgin coconut oil because it is minimally processed. It retains the active ingredients and has no preservatives, additives or color. It’s available at any local health food store or online. Plus, only VCO has that tropical, coconut smell,” LoGerfo says.

A 14 oz. jar of organic unrefined expeller-pressed VCO typically costs about $9. You’ll probably need one jar for the kitchen and another for the bathroom.

At room temperature or cooler, coconut oil has a butter-like consistency. But if you place the jar in a warm-water bath, it melts and can be used as massage oil, moisturizer or as a hair mask. You could also pour the warmed oil into a travel-sized container and, when cooled, could be used as a lip balm or a cuticle conditioner.

If you’re looking to cut your beauty costs dramatically or you’re more of a naturalist and don’t want to put anything on your body that you wouldn’t put in it, VCO is the product for you.
