item.content:encoded:
Trumping men’s buying habits, a study conducted by Parks Associates and unveiled at the 2012 Consumer Electronics Show, says that women are more likely to purchase consumer electronic products. They are also more susceptible to breast cancer.

According to the American Cancer Society, 1 in 8 American women will battle the disease over their lifetime. Since 1985, the American Cancer Society has partnered with other charities to champion Breast Cancer Awareness Month. Their goal remains to raise funds for research, education, prevention and treatment in the ongoing race for a cure.

Backed by corporate campaigns, the “Think Pink” ribbon logo is stamped on everything from sneakers to bath products. This year you might notice more electronics donning a pink suit. We’ve compiled a list of the hottest and most economical consumer technology buys that support the cause.


Dell Pink SWITCH Lid

Boasting a lighter weight and 17-inch HD screen, this 4th generation Intel Core processer is sure to make its predecessors envious at $599.

Pop a custom pink lid on this skinny mini for $23.99. Dell will donate $5 to the Susan G. Komen for the Cure Foundation for each cover sold through March 2014, with a guaranteed minimum donation of $100,000.

 


Tracphone Wireless: LG 840G Pink Phone

Cut down your monthly expenses by using a pay-as-you-go phone.

With mobile web capabilities, you won’t risk being cut off mid-conversation with Tracphone, priced at $40.

The touchscreen Airtime Balance Display shows you how much talk-time remains until you need to purchase more minutes. Tracphone donates 10 percent to Komen for the Cure for each phone sold.


iLuv-MobiTour: Portable Bluetooth Wireless Stereo Speaker

Available in bubble gum pink, iLuv’s speaker, at $49.99, streams music from your wireless device via Bluetooth.

This month, 10 percent of all sales from iLuv’s website will benefit the Breast Cancer Research Foundation.

 


U.S. Digital Media accessories

As a one stop-online shop for all of your mobile accessories, U.S. Digital Media is not shy about its support for breast cancer research.

Earbuds, BudBags, mobile chargers, USB drives and iPhone cases, which range from $6.99 to $29.99, are prominently branded with the pink-ribbon logo.

Select a product that suits your style because 10 percent of sales benefit Komen.

Where do your pennies go upon purchase?

Susan G. Komen pledges “$.83 of every dollar donated to Komen goes back to our mission of saving lives and ending breast cancer. These funds cover a number of areas including screening, education, treatment (and) research,” says representative Joni Avery.

Last year alone, Komen’s audited financial records show that they invested $69 million dollars into research and more than $249 million to screening, education and treatment programs for women. This year, the Breast Cancer Research Foundation will top Komen by devoting $.91 of every dollar to research and education. They’re also allocating $45 million to support the work of more 200 researchers at medical institutions globally.

Before buying, read the fine print

Any company can stamp a pink logo on its products. To ensure that they’re truly giving back, make sure its website or packaging details the amount of donations made through sales.

You can also see how your charity of choice stacks up by logging onto Charity Navigator. It offers a snapshot of how funding is allocated, from research to programming. When purchasing products, you can now both “Think Pink” and “Think Smart.”

item.title: Autumn dinner parties can be chic on the cheap
item.dc:creator: Chie Davis
item.description: While we all aspire to be DIY mavens, when juggling families and careers oftentimes convenience wins out. Although you may not have time to bake bread from scratch, when planning this year’s fall soiree, don’t underestimate the power of doing it yourself. Whether you’re planning a swanky Halloween bash or autumn dinner party, here are […]
item.content:encoded:
While we all aspire to be DIY mavens, when juggling families and careers oftentimes convenience wins out. Although you may not have time to bake bread from scratch, when planning this year’s fall soiree, don’t underestimate the power of doing it yourself. Whether you’re planning a swanky Halloween bash or autumn dinner party, here are tips on hosting a simple, cheap and chic affair.

Just because your wallet is thin, doesn’t mean you can’t throw a fabulous event. Party planning extraordinaire, Andre Wells has designed corporate events for Disney, NBC and the White House, yet he admits that the best parties happen at home.

“Whether you are entertaining four guests or 40, preparation is the key to success,” he says. “Keep a good ‘decordrobe’ for your dining room table.”

By investing in seasonal table décor — dinnerware, napkins and tablecloths — you’ll always feel prepared. Buying one setting per season will equal less money and less stress. You’ll avoid having to re-conceptualize your theme each time you plan an event.

When on a budget, hosts should maintain a focal point. Transform your dining room into an eye-catching space by adorning it with all things festive. Fall offers an array of options for dynamic centerpieces.

“Squash, corn, pumpkin, acorns, they make for a really beautiful display,” Wells says. Gorgeous woven baskets of various shapes and sizes can be found at dollar stores. Fill them with hay and stack them with lush vegetables. Spice it up by adding bedazzled fruit. Anchor the basket with a DIY table runner. Sew yarn into a rustic piece of burlap to add simplistic flair.

Fruit, veggies and inexpensive florals are all available at your local farmer’s market. Wells, who has planned more than 4,000 events for celebrities and politicians, has also worked with limited budgets.

“I like magnolia branches and leaves. They take you right through fall — from Halloween to Thanksgiving, Chanukah and Christmas. We gather fall leaves. Throw them on the floor of the party and onto the tables.” In smaller vessels, “add fall colored roses that come in orange, taupe and creams. You can break them at their heads and place them on the table.”

Floral arrangements are paramount to fall dinner parties. The event planner stresses, “Scent is one of the most important yet forgotten senses. It plays a much larger role in entertaining at home than it does at large functions. Be sure that the first breath guests take when they enter is a pleasant one.”

Other natural scents include cranking up your fireplace. Invite guests to cozy up near the burning wood. “It always gives that whole feeling of Halloween and fall. … And I love the smell of warm cider. You can boil it and your home will be filled with all of the scents in the pot. You can also mull red wine and cider” for an enticing medley of scents.

Don’t fret if you have no time to prepare the cider. Take a hint from the Egyptians and pick up incense for less than $5.

If you’re planning to splurge, do so on a timeless incense holder that doubles as a sculpture. Los Angeles artist Suzanne Wright creates hand-cast holders out of whalebone, carried exclusively at Otherwild.

Wells says once the ambience is set turn down the lights.

“Go to a place like Target and get different sized vases. Fill them with water and buy floating candles. Add dye, orange colored food coloring, or even blue, which comes across as black. It will give the water a pool glow. Cut the lights off. Tell all of your guests to put on their masks.”

item.title: Smartphones, tablets can help you save money
item.dc:creator: Naomi Mannino
item.description: It’s no secret that retailers are aggressively vying for our dollars. But did you realize they are constantly adding to their bag of tricks to entice us to buy because we now love shopping on smartphones and tablets? You can beat retailers at their own game, says Niraj Shah, chief executive officer of the e-commerce […]
item.content:encoded:
Technology can help shoppers save money at home and at the store.

It’s no secret that retailers are aggressively vying for our dollars. But did you realize they are constantly adding to their bag of tricks to entice us to buy because we now love shopping on smartphones and tablets? You can beat retailers at their own game, says Niraj Shah, chief executive officer of the e-commerce site Wayfair.com.

He says that using your tablet and/or smartphone while shopping, whether in-store or online, can provide some surprising new ways to find and use discounts you might not get otherwise. Check out these sneaky smartphone tips and tricks:

Find different prices, discounts with different devices

Remember hearing a story last year about Orbitz showing different prices to Apple product users? Shah says retailers are also offering special deals for people shopping from smartphones and tablets and that retailers might show different products, discounts and prices depending on the user, the device and even the location.

Sneaky smartphone solution: Shah advises price-checking and searching for deals and discounts on your mobile devices even if you’re standing in a store or planning to order from your personal computer.

Search smarter

If you’re looking for a specific product by using a search engine, such as Google or Yahoo, you’ll get the best online search results by being as specific as possible when typing in the search box, Shah says. Take the time to focus your search to ferret out hidden sales and discount information.

Sneaky smartphone solution: To find additional discounts, log on to a retailer’s website. Search for the product name you would like to purchase followed by the words gift with purchase. Try swapping out these keywords as well: rebate, bundle, daily deal and coupon code. You can also try this exercise on any search engine. It might take awhile, but the savings could pile up.

Track prices

Be aware that many brands set a Minimum Advertised Price, called MAP, that retailers cannot go below. You can learn that price by tracking a product’s price as well as other similar products over a few weeks. Shah says, this way, you will be able to recognize the lowest possible price when you see it.

Sneaky smartphone solution: If you are planning a medium- to big-ticket item or electronics purchase, set up email or text alerts on Decide.com or Dealnews.com to know when to strike.

Other sneaky savings solutions

  • Check-in with social media: Always check a retailer’s or brand’s Facebook and Twitter accounts for special social media-only flash-deals and daily deals and discounts. Never checkout, online or in-store, before checking in.
  • • Abandon your cart for enticing savings: Online retailers will continue to convince shoppers to buy, especially if you’ve abandoned your online cart or if you’ve set up an account for the first time. A few days before making a large purchase, set up an account on a retailer’s website and you will probably get an introductory savings discount via email. Even better, fill up an online cart and abandon it; retailers hate that. Even Kate Spade will send you a reminder email along with a sweet discount on a hot handbag.

These sneaky savings solutions definitely add a few minutes to your shopping time but so what? Why pay more if you don’t have to?

What sneaky savings solutions could you add to the list? Try these and let us know what discounts you got or how much you saved!

item.title: How to find UGGs for less than retail
item.dc:creator: Naomi Mannino
item.description: Footwear buyers across the retail spectrum have said they have ordered fewer women’s UGG boots for their stores this year. That leaves UGG with plenty of leftovers to go around, which is good news if you’ve always wanted a pair but didn’t want to pay the high price. How come the UGGs I want are […]
item.content:encoded:
Footwear buyers across the retail spectrum have said they have ordered fewer women’s UGG boots for their stores this year. That leaves UGG with plenty of leftovers to go around, which is good news if you’ve always wanted a pair but didn’t want to pay the high price.

How come the UGGs I want are never on sale?

When UGGs first appeared on Oprah Winfrey’s Favorite Things List in 2003, the now-iconic boots were in high demand and in low supply at very few stores, which drove up the price.

Aside from creating a high-quality product made of real leather with sheepskin lining that is truly warm and useful, UGG has been very strict about its pricing and distribution policies. All retailers are supposed to abide by the Minimum Advertised Price, also known as MAP, which stops retailers from advertising UGGs below a set price.

Why UGGs are popping up on sale now

With two warm winters in a row and the fuzzy footwear available just about everywhere, online and in many department stores, there was finally consumer pushback. UGG rolled back its prices last fall instead of traditionally increasing the price of its most-favored “Classic” boot line. If the price had gone up, the “Classic Tall” style would have crossed the $200 threshold.

UGG “Lo-Pro” denim boots, originally $160, now $79.99, at T.J. Maxx in New York.

In an effort to reignite demand for the brand, UGG Australia also created a wide assortment of new styles. Some of the new styles build on the classic UGG look, but now have sparkles, tassels and more colors to choose from.

Other new styles are high-priced, healed fashion boots and clogs in leather and suede. Even though they have the UGG sheepskin lining, they do not have that quintessential UGG look or shape.

“No matter how beautiful those fashion boots are, nobody’s paying $300 for them when you can’t tell they are UGGs,” one buyer said recently.

In January, UGG allowed its retailers to mark down 35 discontinued styles up to 33 percent off the retail price to move the products off the racks. Some of those shoes look exactly like classic UGGs but with little embellishments such as studs or a strap. Now you can find those and more recent styles at up to 60 percent off, if you know where to look.

Here’s the insider scoop

At left, the UGG “Evera Canvas” sneaker, originally 109.95, now $39.99, at Marshalls in Florida. At right, the UGG “Laela Heirloom” sneaker, originally $119.95, is $39.99 at Marshalls in Florida.

Off-price stores such as T.J. Maxx and Marshalls are currently selling some styles for a fraction of the original price. There are also rumors of palettes of men’s slippers being delivered to Costco and some fashion boots on sale at Saks Off 5th.

Another off-price online retailer, 6pm.com, has approximately (at last count, which can change daily) 64 UGG summer wedges and sandals and 32 fashion and snow boots for more than 50 percent off the regular price.

There are several UGG snow boots priced in the $70 range, which is about at 45 percent off the normal retail price.

Managers at Marshalls and T.J. Maxx say they receive shipments of shoes usually about four times a week, but they never know which shoes are being delivered or when. So if you want UGGs, check in often and you just might snag a pair of real UGGs for real cheap.

Are you feeling all warm and fuzzy about a pair of UGGs you found for cheap? Tell us where you snagged them and post a picture in the comments.

item.title: Run your home kitchen like a restaurant
item.dc:creator: Sandra Gordon
item.description: Nobody knows how important it is to stay on budget than restaurant chefs. Whether it’s a local Applebee’s or that chic little French bistro down the street, “a budget is key to every restaurant’s survival,” says Jill Davie, co-host of Shopping with Chefs on the Fine Living Channel. “If we don’t stick to our budget, […]
item.content:encoded:
Whatever veggies are going bad, roast them for tonight’s dinner. Toss them in a little olive oil, salt and pepper and pop them in the oven at 350 degrees for 20 minutes.

Nobody knows how important it is to stay on budget than restaurant chefs. Whether it’s a local Applebee’s or that chic little French bistro down the street, “a budget is key to every restaurant’s survival,” says Jill Davie, co-host of Shopping with Chefs on the Fine Living Channel. “If we don’t stick to our budget, we can have a great month in terms of customers but not make any money,” she says. “Keep that up and we’re out of business.”

The sentiment translates to you, the home cook. You won’t necessarily go under if you blow your food budget, but the money you have to save or spend on fixed costs like car payments, the mortgage or monthly rent, can certainly take a hit.

Whether you’re entertaining this holiday season or just trying to feed your family for less, take some tips from the pros. Here are money-saving secrets from Davie, who has real-world experience as the former Chef de Cuisine at Josie Restaurant in Santa Monica, California.

Use less expensive, quality ingredients

Buying a whole chicken and roasting it is cheaper than buying chicken breasts.

Instead of buying boneless, skinless chicken breasts, which can be very expensive, buy a whole chicken and teach yourself how to break it down. “You’ll pay as much for boneless, skinless chicken breasts as you will for the whole bird,” Chef Davie says.

You can use the core of the carcass for making stock, thighs for chicken salad and the two chicken breasts for a third dish. Your other option is to buy packaged chicken thighs. They’re an inexpensive cut of chicken and full of flavor. Some of Davie’s other favorite inexpensive cuts of meat include flank, skirt, or flat iron steak and pork shoulder.

Stumped about how to break down a chicken or how to prepare these particular cuts of meat? Do a web search on Epicurious.com or even YouTube.com. “There are so many great recipes online,” Davie says.

Waste not

Chef Davie has a passion for fine food and wine, but she’s also mindful of how much she spends on food and how much she throws away, whether she’s at work or cooking at home. “I try to use everything. The sign of a good chef is an empty trash can,” Davie says.

In fact, one of her latest home creations was using leftover hotdog buns from a football party to create orange cream cheese French toast. She’s also been known to use beet greens. “You can cook the tops of the beets and use them just like spinach or broccoli,” she says.

Don’t lose it — use it

Roast vegetables for about 20 minutes for a delicious side dish for tonight’s dinner.

“In the restaurant business, we buy in such bulk that things often start going bad before we can use them,” Davie says. Before that happens at home, take action. “If it’s produce, cook it,” Davie says.

If your tomatoes are on their last legs, for example, make tomato sauce and freeze it for use later. Whatever veggies are going bad, roast them for tonight’s dinner. Toss them in a little olive oil, salt and pepper and pop them in the oven at 350 degrees for 20 minutes. “Pretty much any vegetable can be done that way,” Davie says. If it’s meat or fish, freeze it. “I won’t use frozen fish in the restaurant, but I will make a stock out of it,” Davie says. One idea is to use frozen fish as a base for Asian soups such as pho. Meat and fish will keep in the freezer for 4 to 12 months.

Shop with cash

When it’s slow in the restaurant business, the food budget gets especially tight. “There have been months when I had to be very mindful of everything I spent because I wasn’t sure if I’d have the revenue to pay off a large food bill,” Davie says. That’s when she learned not to use credit. “Using cash forces you to stick to your food budget and not buy a bunch of random stuff,” Davie says.

All you home chefs out there, do you have any secrets for staying within your food budget? Let us know in the comments below.
